question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. Calculate the standard enthalpy of solution of $\mathrm{AgCl}(\mathrm{s})$ in water from the enthalpies of formation of the solid and the aqueous ions.
llm_answer:
For the dissolution process  

AgCl(s)  →  Ag⁺(aq) + Cl⁻(aq)

the standard enthalpy change is obtained from the heats of formation of the species involved:

Δ_sol H°  = Σ Δ_f H°(products) – Σ Δ_f H°(reactants)  

= [Δ_f H°(Ag⁺, aq) + Δ_f H°(Cl⁻, aq)] – Δ_f H°(AgCl, s)

Insert the tabulated 298.15 K values  
Δ_f H°(Ag⁺, aq) = +105.6 kJ mol⁻¹  
Δ_f H°(Cl⁻, aq) = –167.2 kJ mol⁻¹  
Δ_f H°(AgCl, s) = –126.9 kJ mol⁻¹

Δ_sol H°  = (105.6 − 167.2) − (−126.9)  
            = (−61.6) + 126.9  
            ≈ 65.3 kJ mol⁻¹

\boxed{65.3} kJ mol\(^{-1}\)
llm_output:
For the dissolution process  

AgCl(s)  →  Ag⁺(aq) + Cl⁻(aq)

the standard enthalpy change is obtained from the heats of formation of the species involved:

Δ_sol H°  = Σ Δ_f H°(products) – Σ Δ_f H°(reactants)  

= [Δ_f H°(Ag⁺, aq) + Δ_f H°(Cl⁻, aq)] – Δ_f H°(AgCl, s)

Δ_f H°(Ag⁺, aq) = +105.6 kJ mol⁻¹  
Δ_f H°(Cl⁻, aq) = –167.2 kJ mol⁻¹  
Δ_f H°(AgCl, s) = –126.9 kJ mol⁻¹

Δ_sol H°  = (105.6 − 167.2) − (−126.9)  
            = (−61.6) + 126.9  
            ≈ 65.3 kJ mol⁻¹

\boxed{65.3} kJ mol\(^{-1}\)

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the change in chemical potential of a perfect gas when its pressure is increased isothermally from $1.8 \mathrm{~atm}$ to $29.5 \mathrm{~atm}$ at $40^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_answer:
For an ideal (perfect) gas the chemical potential at a given temperature is

\[
\mu(T,P)=\mu^{\circ}(T)+RT\ln\!\left(\frac{P}{P^{\circ}}\right)
\]

Hence, for an isothermal pressure change from \(P_1\) to \(P_2\),

\[
\Delta\mu=\mu(T,P_2)-\mu(T,P_1)=RT\ln\!\left(\frac{P_2}{P_1}\right)
\]

Step-by-step calculation  

1. Convert the temperature to kelvin  
   \(T = 40^{\circ}\mathrm{C}=40+273.15 = 313.15\ \mathrm{K}\)

2. Insert the gas constant (in J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)  
   \(R = 8.314\,\mathrm{J\;mol^{-1}\,K^{-1}}\)

3. Form the pressure ratio  
   \(\dfrac{P_2}{P_1}=\dfrac{29.5\ \mathrm{atm}}{1.8\ \mathrm{atm}}=16.3889\)

4. Evaluate the natural logarithm  
   \(\ln(16.3889)=2.7966\)

5. Compute the change in chemical potential  
   \[
   \Delta\mu = (8.314\ \mathrm{J\;mol^{-1}\,K^{-1}})(313.15\ \mathrm{K})(2.7966)
             \approx 7.281\times10^{3}\ \mathrm{J\;mol^{-1}}
             = 7.28\ \mathrm{kJ\;mol^{-1}}
   \]

Therefore,

\[
\boxed{7.28}\ \mathrm{kJ\;mol^{-1}}
\]
llm_output:
For an ideal (perfect) gas the chemical potential at a given temperature is

   \]

\[
\boxed{7.28}\ \mathrm{kJ\;mol^{-1}}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the change in entropy when $25 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of energy is transferred reversibly and isothermally as heat to a large block of iron at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_answer:
Because the heat transfer is carried out reversibly and isothermally, the entropy change of the block of iron is given directly by  

ΔS = q_rev / T   

1. Convert the temperature to kelvin:  
   T = 100 °C = 100 + 273.15 = 373.15 K  

2. Convert the heat to joules:  
   q_rev = 25 kJ = 25 000 J  

3. Evaluate ΔS:  
   ΔS = 25 000 J / 373.15 K = 6.7 × 10¹ J K⁻¹ (two significant figures)  

\[
\boxed{6.7\times10^{1}}\ \mathrm{J\,K^{-1}}
\]
llm_output:

2. Convert the heat to joules:  
   q_rev = 25 kJ = 25 000 J  

3. Evaluate ΔS:  
   ΔS = 25 000 J / 373.15 K = 6.7 × 10¹ J K⁻¹ (two significant figures)  

\[
\boxed{6.7\times10^{1}}\ \mathrm{J\,K^{-1}}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. A sample of $4.50 \mathrm{~g}$ of methane occupies $12.7 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $310 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the work that would be done if the same expansion occurred reversibly.
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Amount of substance  

M(CH₄) = 12.011 + 4 × 1.008 = 16.043 g mol⁻¹  

n = m/M = 4.50 g / 16.043 g mol⁻¹ = 0.280 mol  

Step 2 – Identify the process  

The temperature is constant (310 K) and the required expansion is to be carried out reversibly, so we treat it as a reversible, isothermal expansion of an ideal gas.

Step 3 – Formula for reversible, isothermal work  

w_rev = – nRT ln(V₂/V₁)

Step 4 – Insert the volumes  

Initial volume: V₁ = 12.7 dm³  
Final volume:  V₂ = 22.4 dm³  
V₂/V₁ = 22.4/12.7 = 1.764  

Step 5 – Calculate the work  

w_rev = – (0.280 mol)(8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)(310 K) ln(1.764)  
         = – (0.280)(8.314)(310)(0.567)  
         ≈ – 4.10 × 10² J  

\[
\boxed{-4.10\times10^{2}}\; \text{J}
\]
llm_output:

M(CH₄) = 12.011 + 4 × 1.008 = 16.043 g mol⁻¹  

n = m/M = 4.50 g / 16.043 g mol⁻¹ = 0.280 mol  

Step 2 – Identify the process  

The temperature is constant (310 K) and the required expansion is to be carried out reversibly, so we treat it as a reversible, isothermal expansion of an ideal gas.

w_rev = – (0.280 mol)(8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)(310 K) ln(1.764)  
         = – (0.280)(8.314)(310)(0.567)  
         ≈ – 4.10 × 10² J  

\[
\boxed{-4.10\times10^{2}}\; \text{J}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. A strip of magnesium of mass $15 \mathrm{~g}$ is placed in a beaker of dilute hydrochloric acid. Calculate the work done by the system as a result of the reaction. The atmospheric pressure is 1.0 atm and the temperature $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_answer:
Number of moles of magnesium  
n(Mg)=m/M=15 g/24.305 g mol⁻¹=0.617 mol

Stoichiometry of the reaction  
Mg(s)+2 HCl(aq)→MgCl₂(aq)+H₂(g)

⇒ n(H₂)=n(Mg)=0.617 mol

Volume of H₂ evolved (ideal-gas law, 25 °C = 298.15 K, P = 1.00 atm)  
V= nRT/P  
 = 0.617 mol × 0.082057 L atm mol⁻¹ K⁻¹ × 298.15 K  
 = 15.1 L

P–V work at constant external pressure  
w = –P ΔV = –(1.00 atm)(15.1 L) = –15.1 L atm

Convert to kJ (1 L atm = 101.325 J)  
w = –15.1 L atm × 101.325 J L⁻¹ atm⁻¹ = –1.53 × 10³ J = –1.53 kJ

\boxed{-1.53} kJ
llm_output:
Number of moles of magnesium  
n(Mg)=m/M=15 g/24.305 g mol⁻¹=0.617 mol

Stoichiometry of the reaction  
Mg(s)+2 HCl(aq)→MgCl₂(aq)+H₂(g)

⇒ n(H₂)=n(Mg)=0.617 mol

Volume of H₂ evolved (ideal-gas law, 25 °C = 298.15 K, P = 1.00 atm)

w = –15.1 L atm × 101.325 J L⁻¹ atm⁻¹ = –1.53 × 10³ J = –1.53 kJ

\boxed{-1.53} kJ

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. For a van der Waals gas, $\pi_T=a / V_{\mathrm{m}}^2$. Calculate $\Delta U_{\mathrm{m}}$ for the isothermal expansion of nitrogen gas from an initial volume of $1.00 \mathrm{dm}^3$ to $24.8 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Internal-pressure of a van der Waals gas  
For a van der Waals gas  
π_T ≡ (∂U_m / ∂V_m)_T = a / V_m^2

Step 2 – Expression for ΔU_m at constant T  
ΔU_m = ∫_{V_1}^{V_2} π_T dV_m  
       = ∫_{V_1}^{V_2} a V_m^{-2} dV_m  
       = a[ -1/V_m ]_{V_1}^{V_2}  
       = a(1/V_1 − 1/V_2)

Step 3 – Insert numerical data  
a(N₂) = 1.352 L² bar mol⁻²  
Convert a to SI:  
1 L = 1 dm³ = 10⁻³ m³ ; 1 bar = 10⁵ Pa = 10⁵ J m⁻³  
a = 1.352(10⁻³ m³)²(10⁵ J m⁻³) = 0.1352 m³ J

V₁ = 1.00 dm³ = 1.00 L = 1.00×10⁻³ m³  
V₂ = 24.8 dm³ = 24.8 L = 2.48×10⁻² m³

1/V₁ − 1/V₂ = 1/(1.00×10⁻³) − 1/(2.48×10⁻²)  
              = 1.000×10³ − 40.32 = 9.5968×10² m⁻³

ΔU_m = 0.1352 m³ J × 9.5968×10² m⁻³  
      ≈ 1.30×10² J mol⁻¹

\[
\boxed{1.3\times10^{2}} \;\text{J mol}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:

For a van der Waals gas  
π_T ≡ (∂U_m / ∂V_m)_T = a / V_m^2

Step 2 – Expression for ΔU_m at constant T

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the molar entropy of a constant-volume sample of neon at $500 \mathrm{~K}$ given that it is $146.22 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
For an ideal gas the molar entropy change at constant volume is  

dS̅ = C̅_V \dfrac{dT}{T}

hence  

ΔS̅ = ∫_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C̅_V}{T}\,dT = C̅_V \ln\!\left(\dfrac{T_2}{T_1}\right)

For a monatomic gas such as neon,  

C̅_V = \dfrac{3}{2}R = \dfrac{3}{2}(8.314\,472\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{ mol}^{-1})  
        = 12.472\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{ mol}^{-1}

Using T₁ = 298 K and T₂ = 500 K,

ΔS̅ = 12.472\,\text{J K}^{-1}\text{ mol}^{-1}\;
       \ln\!\left(\dfrac{500}{298}\right)
     = 12.472 \times 0.5175
     = 6.45\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{ mol}^{-1}

The molar entropy at 500 K is therefore

S̅(500 K) = S̅(298 K) + ΔS̅  
           = 146.22 + 6.45  
           ≈ 152.67\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{ mol}^{-1}

\boxed{152.7} J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹
llm_output:
For an ideal gas the molar entropy change at constant volume is  

dS̅ = C̅_V \dfrac{dT}{T}

hence  

ΔS̅ = ∫_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C̅_V}{T}\,dT = C̅_V \ln\!\left(\dfrac{T_2}{T_1}\right)

For a monatomic gas such as neon,

        = 12.472\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{ mol}^{-1}

       \ln\!\left(\dfrac{500}{298}\right)
     = 12.472 \times 0.5175
     = 6.45\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{ mol}^{-1}

The molar entropy at 500 K is therefore

S̅(500 K) = S̅(298 K) + ΔS̅  
           = 146.22 + 6.45  
           ≈ 152.67\;\text{J K}^{-1}\text{ mol}^{-1}

\boxed{152.7} J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. Calculate the final temperature of a sample of argon of mass $12.0 \mathrm{~g}$ that is expanded reversibly and adiabatically from $1.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $273.15 \mathrm{~K}$ to $3.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$.
llm_answer:
Step 1. Amount of argon  
Molar mass Ar = 39.948 g mol⁻¹  

n = m/M = 12.0 g / 39.948 g mol⁻¹ = 0.300 mol (to three sig. fig.)

(The numerical value of n will not be needed because γ depends only on the type of gas.)

Step 2. Heat-capacity ratio for monatomic ideal gas  
C_v,m = (3/2)R, C_p,m = C_v,m + R = (5/2)R  
γ = C_p,m / C_v,m = (5/2)R / (3/2)R = 5/3 ≈ 1.667  
γ – 1 = 2/3

Step 3. Reversible adiabatic relation for an ideal gas  
T V^{γ–1} = constant   
⇒ T₂ = T₁ (V₁ / V₂)^{γ–1}

Step 4. Insert the data  
T₁ = 273.15 K, V₁ = 1.0 dm³, V₂ = 3.0 dm³  

T₂ = 273.15 K × (1.0/3.0)^{2/3}  
  = 273.15 K × 3^{-2/3}  
  = 273.15 K × e^{(2/3) ln(1/3)}  
  = 273.15 K × e^{-0.732408}  
  = 273.15 K × 0.480755  
  = 1.313 × 10² K

Step 5. Report the final temperature (three significant figures)

\boxed{1.31 \times 10^{2}} K
llm_output:

Molar mass Ar = 39.948 g mol⁻¹  

n = m/M = 12.0 g / 39.948 g mol⁻¹ = 0.300 mol (to three sig. fig.)

Step 2. Heat-capacity ratio for monatomic ideal gas  
C_v,m = (3/2)R, C_p,m = C_v,m + R = (5/2)R  
γ = C_p,m / C_v,m = (5/2)R / (3/2)R = 5/3 ≈ 1.667  
γ – 1 = 2/3

T₁ = 273.15 K, V₁ = 1.0 dm³, V₂ = 3.0 dm³

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the change in entropy when $25 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of energy is transferred reversibly and isothermally as heat to a large block of iron at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_answer:
For a reversible, isothermal heat transfer the entropy change is  

ΔS = q_rev / T.

1. Convert the heat to joules:  
   q_rev = 25 kJ = 2.50 × 10⁴ J

2. Use the temperature of the iron block:  
   T = 0 °C = 273.15 K

3. Substitute:  
   ΔS = (2.50 × 10⁴ J) / (273.15 K)  
        ≈ 9.15 × 10¹ J K⁻¹

\[
\boxed{9.15 \times 10^{1}}
\] J K\(^{-1}\)

question: A gas at $250 \mathrm{~K}$ and $15 \mathrm{~atm}$ has a molar volume 12 per cent smaller than that calculated from the perfect gas law. Calculate the molar volume of the gas.
llm_answer:
For an ideal gas the molar volume is  

\[
V_{\text{ideal}}=\frac{RT}{P}
\]

Using  
\(R = 0.082057\ \mathrm{L\,atm\,mol^{-1}\,K^{-1}}\),  
\(T = 250\ \mathrm{K}\),  
\(P = 15\ \mathrm{atm}\):

\[
V_{\text{ideal}}=\frac{0.082057 \times 250}{15}
               =\frac{20.5143}{15}
               =1.3676\ \mathrm{dm^{3}\,mol^{-1}}
\]

The real gas volume is 12 % smaller:

\[
V_{\text{real}} = V_{\text{ideal}}\left(1-0.12\right) 
                = 1.3676 \times 0.88
                = 1.2035\ \mathrm{dm^{3}\,mol^{-1}}
\]

Rounded to three significant figures:

\[
\boxed{1.20}\ \mathrm{dm^{3}\,mol^{-1}
}
\]
llm_output:
For an ideal gas the molar volume is  

\[
V_{\text{ideal}}=\frac{RT}{P}
\]

Using  
\(R = 0.082057\ \mathrm{L\,atm\,mol^{-1}\,K^{-1}}\),  
\(T = 250\ \mathrm{K}\),  
\(P = 15\ \mathrm{atm}\):

\[

\]

\[
\boxed{1.20}\ \mathrm{dm^{3}\,mol^{-1}
}
\]

question: Calculate the mass of water vapour present in a room of volume $400 \mathrm{m}^3$ that contains air at $27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ on a day when the relative humidity is 60 percent.'
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Saturation vapour pressure of water at 27 °C  
Using the Antoine equation (water, 1–100 °C range)

log₁₀ P_sat (mm Hg) = 8.14019 − 1810.94 / (T + 244.485), T in °C

T = 27 °C ⇒  
log₁₀ P_sat = 8.14019 − 1810.94 / (27 + 244.485)  
             = 8.14019 − 6.67230 = 1.46789

P_sat = 10^{1.46789} = 29.38 mm Hg  
Convert to kPa: 1 mm Hg = 0.133322 kPa  
P_sat = 29.38 × 0.133322 = 3.916 kPa

Step 2 – Actual partial pressure of water vapour  
Relative humidity φ = 60 % = 0.60  
P_v = φ P_sat = 0.60 × 3.916 kPa = 2.350 kPa

Step 3 – Density of the water vapour (ideal-gas assumption)  
ρ = P_v M / (R T)

M (H₂O) = 18.015 kg kmol⁻¹  
R = 8.314 kPa m³ kmol⁻¹ K⁻¹  
T = 27 °C = 300.15 K

ρ = (2.350 kPa)(18.015 kg kmol⁻¹) / [(8.314 kPa m³ kmol⁻¹ K⁻¹)(300.15 K)]  
   = 0.01718 kg m⁻³

Step 4 – Mass of water vapour in the room  
Room volume V = 400 m³  

m = ρ V = 0.01718 kg m⁻³ × 400 m³ = 6.87 kg

\[
\boxed{6.87}\ \text{kg}
\]

m = ρ V = 0.01718 kg m⁻³ × 400 m³ = 6.87 kg

\[
\boxed{6.87}\ \text{kg}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. The enthalpy of vaporization of chloroform $\left(\mathrm{CHCl}_3\right)$ is $29.4 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at its normal boiling point of $334.88 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the entropy of vaporization of chloroform at this temperature.
llm_answer:
To find the entropy of vaporization (Δ₍vap₎S) at the boiling point, use the definition  

Δ₍vap₎S = Δ₍vap₎H / T

1. Convert the given enthalpy from kilojoules to joules:  
   Δ₍vap₎H = 29.4 kJ mol⁻¹ = 29.4 × 10³ J mol⁻¹ = 2.94 × 10⁴ J mol⁻¹

2. Insert the boiling‐point temperature:  
   T = 334.88 K

3. Compute the entropy change:  
   Δ₍vap₎S = (2.94 × 10⁴ J mol⁻¹) / (334.88 K) ≈ 87.8 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹

\[
\boxed{87.8} \ \text{J K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. The enthalpy of vaporization of chloroform $\left(\mathrm{CHCl}_3\right)$ is $29.4 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at its normal boiling point of $334.88 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the entropy change of the surroundings.
A gas at $250 \mathrm{~K}$ and $15 \mathrm{~atm}$ has a molar volume 12 per cent smaller than that calculated from the perfect gas law. Calculate the compression factor under these conditions.

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Suppose that $3.0 \mathrm{mmol} \mathrm{N}_2$ (g) occupies $36 \mathrm{~cm}^3$ at $300 \mathrm{~K}$ and expands to $60 \mathrm{~cm}^3$. Calculate $\Delta G$ for the process.
llm_answer:
For an isothermal change of a perfect gas, the molar Gibbs energy varies with pressure (or volume) according to  

ΔG = nRT ln(P₂/P₁) = nRT ln(V₁/V₂)

because P V is constant at fixed T.

Given  
n = 3.0 mmol = 0.003 mol  
T = 300 K  
V₁ = 36 cm³  
V₂ = 60 cm³

Calculate the volume ratio:  

V₁ / V₂ = 36 cm³ / 60 cm³ = 0.60

Insert the data:

ΔG = (0.003 mol)(8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)(300 K) ln(0.60)

First compute the constant factor:  

0.003 mol × 8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹ × 300 K = 7.48 J

Then include the logarithm (ln 0.60 = –0.5108):

ΔG = 7.48 J × (–0.5108) ≈ –3.82 J

\[
\boxed{-3.82}\ \text{J}
\]

question: A vessel of volume $22.4 \mathrm{dm}^3$ contains $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{H}_2$ and $1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~N}_2$ at $273.15 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate their total pressure.
llm_answer:
First find the total amount of gas in the vessel.

Total moles  
n = n(H₂) + n(N₂) = 2.0 mol + 1.0 mol = 3.0 mol

Apply the ideal-gas equation pV = nRT.

Given  
V = 22.4 dm³ = 22.4 L  
T = 273.15 K  
R = 0.082057 L atm mol⁻¹ K⁻¹

Pressure  
p = nRT / V  
  = (3.0 mol)(0.082057 L atm mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)(273.15 K) / 22.4 L  
  ≈ 3.00 atm

\boxed{3.00} atm

n = n(H₂) + n(N₂) = 2.0 mol + 1.0 mol = 3.0 mol

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the total change in entropy, when a sample of nitrogen gas of mass $14 \mathrm{~g}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ and $1.00 \mathrm{bar}$ doubles its volume in an adiabatic reversible expansion.
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Moles of nitrogen  
Molar mass of N₂ ≈ 28.0 g mol⁻¹.  
n = 14 g / 28.0 g mol⁻¹ = 0.50 mol.

Step 2 – Molar heat capacities at 298 K  
For a diatomic ideal gas  
Cₚ,m ≈ 29.1 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹  
Cᵥ,m = Cₚ,m − R ≈ 29.1 − 8.314 = 20.8 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹  
γ = Cₚ,m / Cᵥ,m ≈ 1.40.

Step 3 – Entropy change of the gas  
For any ideal gas  
ΔS = n Cᵥ,m ln(T₂/T₁) + n R ln(V₂/V₁).     (1)

Because the expansion is reversible and adiabatic,  
T V^{γ-1} = constant ⇒ T₂/T₁ = (V₁/V₂)^{γ-1}.  
With V₂ = 2 V₁, T₂/T₁ = 2^{-(γ-1)}.               (2)

Insert (2) into (1):

ΔS = n Cᵥ,m [ln 2^{-(γ-1)}] + n R ln 2  
  = n ln 2 [ −Cᵥ,m(γ-1) + R ].

But (γ-1) = (Cₚ,m − Cᵥ,m)/Cᵥ,m = R/Cᵥ,m, hence  
Cᵥ,m(γ-1) = R, making the bracket zero:

ΔS = n ln 2 (−R + R) = 0.

Thus the entropy of the gas does not change.

Step 4 – Entropy change of the surroundings  
The process is adiabatic; no heat is exchanged, so  
ΔS_surroundings = 0.

Step 5 – Total entropy change  
ΔS_total = ΔS_gas + ΔS_surroundings = 0 + 0 = 0.

\[
\boxed{0}
\;\text{J K}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the Carnot efficiency of a modern steam turbine that operates with steam at $300^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and discharges at $80^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Convert the two temperatures to kelvin  
T_h = 300 °C + 273.15 = 573.15 K  
T_c =  80 °C + 273.15 = 353.15 K  

Step 2 – Carnot efficiency  
η_Carnot = 1 − (T_c / T_h)  
       = 1 − (353.15 K / 573.15 K)  
       = (573.15 K − 353.15 K) / 573.15 K  
       = 220.00 / 573.15 ≃ 0.384

Hence the ideal (Carnot) efficiency of the steam turbine is  

\[
\boxed{0.384}
\]

which corresponds to about 38 %.

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. When a certain freon used in refrigeration was expanded adiabatically from an initial pressure of $32 \mathrm{~atm}$ and $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to a final pressure of $1.00 \mathrm{~atm}$, the temperature fell by $22 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the Joule-Thomson coefficient, $\mu$, at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, assuming it remains constant over this temperature range.
llm_answer:
For a Joule–Thomson (adiabatic throttling) experiment the enthalpy of the gas remains essentially constant, so by definition  

μ ≡ (∂T/∂P)_H ≈ ΔT/ΔP (enthalpy held constant)

Given  
Initial pressure, P₁ = 32 atm  
Final pressure,  P₂ = 1 atm  

Initial temperature, T₁ = 0 °C = 273.15 K  
Temperature drop on expansion, ΔT = T₂ – T₁ = –22 K  

Hence  
ΔP = P₂ – P₁ = 1 atm – 32 atm = –31 atm

μ = ΔT / ΔP = (–22 K)/(–31 atm) = 22/31 K atm⁻¹  
 = 0.709 7 K atm⁻¹ ≈ 0.71 K atm⁻¹

\boxed{0.71} K atm^{-1}
llm_output:

\boxed{0.71} K atm^{-1}

question:
Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. The volume of a certain liquid varies with temperature as
$$
V=V^{\prime}\left\{0.75+3.9 \times 10^{-4}(T / \mathrm{K})+1.48 \times 10^{-6}(T / \mathrm{K})^2\right\}
$$
where $V^{\prime}$ is its volume at $300 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate its expansion coefficient, $\alpha$, at $320 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
The coefficient of (volumetric) thermal expansion is defined as  

\[
\alpha(T)=\frac{1}{V}\left(\frac{\partial V}{\partial T}\right)_P .
\]

Given  

\[
V(T)=V'\,f(T),\qquad 
f(T)=0.75+3.9\times10^{-4}T+1.48\times10^{-6}T^{2},
\]

the derivative is  

\[
\frac{\partial V}{\partial T}=V'\,f'(T),\qquad 
f'(T)=3.9\times10^{-4}+2(1.48\times10^{-6})T .
\]

Because \(V=V' f(T)\), the factor \(V'\) cancels:

\[
\alpha(T)=\frac{f'(T)}{f(T)} .
\]

Evaluate at \(T = 320\;\text{K}\).

1.  Compute \(f(320\,\text{K})\):
   \[
   \begin{aligned}
   f(320) &= 0.75 + (3.9\times10^{-4})(320) + (1.48\times10^{-6})(320)^{2} \\
          &= 0.75 + 0.1248 + 0.151552 \\
          &= 1.026352 .
   \end{aligned}
   \]

2.  Compute \(f'(320\,\text{K})\):
   \[
   \begin{aligned}
   f'(320) &= 3.9\times10^{-4} + 2(1.48\times10^{-6})(320) \\
           &= 3.9\times10^{-4} + 9.472\times10^{-4} \\
           &= 1.3372\times10^{-3}.
   \end{aligned}
   \]

3.  Calculate \(\alpha(320\,\text{K})\):
   \[
   \alpha(320)=\frac{1.3372\times10^{-3}}{1.026352}=1.30\times10^{-3}\;\text{K}^{-1}.
   \]

\[
\boxed{1.30\times10^{-3}} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:

\]

\]

   \]

2.  Compute \(f'(320\,\text{K})\):
   \[
   \begin{aligned}
   f'(320) &= 3.9\times10^{-4} + 2(1.48\times10^{-6})(320) \\
           &= 3.9\times10^{-4} + 9.472\times10^{-4} \\
           &= 1.3372\times10^{-3}.
   \end{aligned}
   \]

3.  Calculate \(\alpha(320\,\text{K})\):
   \[
   \alpha(320)=\frac{1.3372\times10^{-3}}{1.026352}=1.30\times10^{-3}\;\text{K}^{-1}.
   \]

\[
\boxed{1.30\times10^{-3}} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}
\]

question: In an attempt to determine an accurate value of the gas constant, $R$, a student heated a container of volume $20.000 \mathrm{dm}^3$ filled with $0.25132 \mathrm{g}$ of helium gas to $500^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and measured the pressure as $206.402 \mathrm{cm}$ of water in a manometer at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Calculate the value of $R$ from these data. (The density of water at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ is $0.99707 \mathrm{g} \mathrm{cm}^{-3}$; a manometer consists of a U-shaped tube containing a liquid. One side is connected to the apparatus and the other is open to the atmosphere. The pressure inside the apparatus is then determined from the difference in heights of the liquid.)
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Amount of helium   
M(He)=4.002 602 g mol⁻¹  
n= m/M = 0.251 32 g / 4.002 602 g mol⁻¹ = 6.2789 × 10⁻² mol

Step 2 – Absolute temperature   
T = 500 °C + 273.15 = 7.7315 × 10² K

Step 3 – Volume in SI units   
V = 20.000 dm³ = 20.000 × 10⁻³ m³ = 2.0000 × 10⁻² m³

Step 4 – Pressure from the water–column reading   
ρ (25 °C) = 0.99707 g cm⁻³ = 9.9707 × 10² kg m⁻³  
h = 206.402 cm = 2.06402 m  
g = 9.80665 m s⁻²  

P = ρgh = (9.9707 × 10² kg m⁻³)(9.80665 m s⁻²)(2.06402 m)  
  = 2.0182 × 10⁴ Pa

Step 5 – Gas constant from PV = nRT   
R = PV/(nT)  
  = (2.0182 × 10⁴ Pa)(2.0000 × 10⁻² m³) / [(6.2789 × 10⁻² mol)(7.7315 × 10² K)]  
  ≈ 8.31 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹

\[
\boxed{8.31}\ \text{J\,K}^{-1}\,\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. The standard enthalpy of combustion of solid phenol $\left(\mathrm{C}_6 \mathrm{H}_5 \mathrm{OH}\right)$ is $-3054 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}_{\text {and }}$ its standard molar entropy is $144.0 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. Calculate the standard Gibbs energy of formation of phenol at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
Combustion reaction of solid phenol  

C₆H₅OH(s)+7 O₂(g) ⟶ 6 CO₂(g)+3 H₂O(l)

1.  Standard enthalpy of formation of phenol  
   Δ_fH°(Ph) = 6Δ_fH°(CO₂) + 3Δ_fH°(H₂O) − Δ_cH°(Ph)

   = 6(−393.51) + 3(−285.83) − (−3054)  
   = −164.6 kJ mol⁻¹

2.  Standard entropy of formation of phenol  
   S°(elements): 6 C(s) 5.74; 3 H₂(g) 130.68; ½ O₂(g) 205.0  (J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹)

   ΣS°(elements)=6(5.74)+3(130.68)+0.5(205.0)=528.98 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹

   Δ_fS°(Ph)=S°(Ph)−ΣS°(elements)=144.0−528.98=−384.98 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹
             =−0.38498 kJ K⁻¹ mol⁻¹

3.  Standard Gibbs energy of formation  
   Δ_fG°(Ph)=Δ_fH°−TΔ_fS°  
   = −164.6 kJ mol⁻¹ − 298.15 K(−0.38498 kJ K⁻¹ mol⁻¹)  
   = −164.6 kJ mol⁻¹ + 114.8 kJ mol⁻¹  
   ≈ −49.8 kJ mol⁻¹

\boxed{-4.98\times10^{1}} kJ mol⁻¹
llm_output:

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the Carnot efficiency of a primitive steam engine operating on steam at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and discharging at $60^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_answer:
For a reversible (Carnot) heat engine the thermal efficiency is  

η = 1 − Tc / Th

where  
Th = absolute temperature of the hot reservoir  
Tc = absolute temperature of the cold reservoir.

Convert the given temperatures to Kelvin:  
Th = 100 °C + 273.15 = 373.15 K  
Tc = 60 °C  + 273.15 = 333.15 K

Insert in the Carnot formula:  
η = 1 − (333.15 K)/(373.15 K)  
  = 1 − 0.89283  
  = 0.10717 ≈ 0.107

Hence the maximum (Carnot) efficiency of the steam engine is  

\boxed{0.107}

or about 10.7 %.

\boxed{0.107}

or about 10.7 %.

question:
Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. A sample of $4.50 \mathrm{~g}$ of methane occupies $12.7 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $310 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the work done when the gas expands isothermally against a constant external pressure of 200 Torr until its volume has increased by
$3.3 \mathrm{dm}^3$.
llm_answer:
For expansion against a constant external pressure the (chemical‐sign) work is  

w = −P_ext ΔV  

Step 1 – Convert the external pressure to pascals  
P_ext = 200  Torr × (101 325 Pa / 760 Torr) = 26 664 Pa

Step 2 – Convert the volume change to cubic metres  
ΔV = 3.3 dm³ × (10⁻³ m³ / 1 dm³) = 0.0033 m³

Step 3 – Calculate the work  
w = −(26 664 Pa)(0.0033 m³) = −87.992 J ≈ −8.8 × 10¹ J

\[
\boxed{-8.8\times 10^{1}}
\] J

P_ext = 200  Torr × (101 325 Pa / 760 Torr) = 26 664 Pa

Step 2 – Convert the volume change to cubic metres  
ΔV = 3.3 dm³ × (10⁻³ m³ / 1 dm³) = 0.0033 m³

Step 3 – Calculate the work  
w = −(26 664 Pa)(0.0033 m³) = −87.992 J ≈ −8.8 × 10¹ J

\[
\boxed{-8.8\times 10^{1}}
\] J

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the maximum non-expansion work per mole that may be obtained from a fuel cell in which the chemical reaction is the combustion of methane at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Write the cell reaction  
CH₄(g) + 2 O₂(g) ⟶ CO₂(g) + 2 H₂O(l)

Step 2 – Tabulate standard Gibbs energies of formation, ΔG°f (298 K)  
CH₄(g) : –50.8 kJ mol⁻¹  
O₂(g)  :   0  
CO₂(g) : –394.4 kJ mol⁻¹  
H₂O(l) : –237.1 kJ mol⁻¹

Step 3 – Calculate the standard Gibbs energy change of reaction  
ΔG° = [ΔG°f(CO₂) + 2 ΔG°f(H₂O)] – [ΔG°f(CH₄) + 2 ΔG°f(O₂)]

ΔG° = [ (–394.4) + 2(–237.1) ] – [ (–50.8) + 0 ] kJ mol⁻¹  
ΔG° = (–394.4 – 474.2) – (–50.8)  
ΔG° = –868.6 + 50.8  
ΔG° = –8.18 × 10² kJ mol⁻¹

Step 4 – Relate ΔG° to the maximum non-expansion (electrical) work  
w_non-exp,max = –ΔG°

|ΔG°| = 8.18 × 10² kJ mol⁻¹

\[
\boxed{8.18\times 10^{2}} \text{ kJ\,mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the change in Gibbs energy of $35 \mathrm{~g}$ of ethanol (mass density $0.789 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$ ) when the pressure is increased isothermally from $1 \mathrm{~atm}$ to $3000 \mathrm{~atm}$.
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Volume of the ethanol sample  
ρ = 0.789 g cm⁻³  
m = 35 g  
V = m/ρ = 35 g ÷ 0.789 g cm⁻³ = 44.4 cm³ = 44.4 × 10⁻⁶ m³ = 4.44 × 10⁻⁵ m³  

Step 2 – Pressure change  
P₁ = 1 atm  
P₂ = 3000 atm  
ΔP = P₂ – P₁ = 2999 atm  
1 atm = 1.01325 × 10⁵ Pa  
ΔP = 2999 atm × 1.01325 × 10⁵ Pa atm⁻¹ = 3.03873675 × 10⁸ Pa  

Step 3 – Isothermal, incompressible relation  
For an incompressible liquid at constant T, dG = V dP ⇒ ΔG = V ΔP  
ΔG = (4.44 × 10⁻⁵ m³)(3.03873675 × 10⁸ Pa) = 1.35 × 10⁴ J = 13.5 kJ  

Final result  
\boxed{13.5} kJ

question: Calculate the pressure exerted by $1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{Xe}$ when it is confined to $1.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.
llm_answer:
To determine the pressure, apply the ideal-gas equation  

P V = n R T.

1. Convert all quantities to appropriate SI/ideal-gas units  
   • n = 1.0 mol  
   • V = 1.0 dm³ = 1.0 L  
   • T = 25 °C = 25 + 273.15 = 298.15 K  
   • R = 0.082 057 L atm mol⁻¹ K⁻¹  

2. Solve for P:  

P = (n R T) / V  
  = (1.0 mol)(0.082 057 L atm mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)(298.15 K) / (1.0 L)  
  ≈ 24.47 atm

Rounded to three significant figures (matching the given data):

\[
\boxed{24.5} \text{ atm}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the total change in entropy, when a sample of nitrogen gas of mass $14 \mathrm{~g}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ and $1.00 \mathrm{bar}$ doubles its volume in an isothermal reversible expansion.
llm_answer:
Step 1.  Number of moles of N₂  
Molar mass of N₂ ≈ 28.0 g mol⁻¹  
n = 14 g / 28.0 g mol⁻¹ = 0.50 mol  

Step 2.  Entropy change for an isothermal, reversible expansion of an ideal gas  
ΔS = n R ln(V₂/V₁)  

Step 3.  Insert V₂ = 2 V₁ and the gas constant R = 8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹  
ΔS = 0.50 mol × 8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹ × ln 2  
ΔS = 4.157 J K⁻¹ × 0.6931  
ΔS ≈ 2.88 J K⁻¹  

Hence, the total change in entropy is  

\[
\boxed{2.88}\ \text{J K}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate $\Delta H$ when two copper blocks, each of mass $10.0 \mathrm{~kg}$, one at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and the other at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, are placed in contact in an isolated container. The specific heat capacity of copper is $0.385 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~g}^{-1}$ and may be assumed constant over the temperature range involved.
llm_answer:
Given  
m₁ = m₂ = 10.0 kg = 1.00 × 10⁴ g  
cₚ(Cu) = 0.385 J K⁻¹ g⁻¹  
T₁ = 100 °C = 373.15 K  
T₂ =   0 °C = 273.15 K  

1. Final equilibrium temperature  
Because the blocks have equal mass and the same, temperature-independent heat capacity, energy conservation inside the isolated container gives  

T_f = (m₁cₚT₁ + m₂cₚT₂)/(m₁cₚ + m₂cₚ)  
     = (T₁ + T₂)/2  
     = (373.15 K + 273.15 K)/2  
     = 323.15 K  (50 °C)

2. Enthalpy change of each block  
ΔH_hot  = m₁ cₚ (T_f – T₁)  
         = (1.00 × 10⁴ g)(0.385 J K⁻¹ g⁻¹)(323.15 K – 373.15 K)  
         = –1.93 × 10⁵ J  

ΔH_cold = m₂ cₚ (T_f – T₂)  
         = (1.00 × 10⁴ g)(0.385 J K⁻¹ g⁻¹)(323.15 K – 273.15 K)  
         = +1.93 × 10⁵ J  

3. Total enthalpy change of the system  
ΔH_total = ΔH_hot + ΔH_cold  
          = –1.93 × 10⁵ J + 1.93 × 10⁵ J  
          = 0 J

(Alternatively, since H ∝ m cₚ T,   
ΔH_total = m cₚ(2T_f – T₁ – T₂) = 0.)

\[
\boxed{0}
\; \text{J}
\]
llm_output:
Given

cₚ(Cu) = 0.385 J K⁻¹ g⁻¹

1. Final equilibrium temperature  
Because the blocks have equal mass and the same, temperature-independent heat capacity, energy conservation inside the isolated container gives  

T_f = (m₁cₚT₁ + m₂cₚT₂)/(m₁cₚ + m₂cₚ)  
     = (T₁ + T₂)/2  
     = (373.15 K + 273.15 K)/2  
     = 323.15 K  (50 °C)

2. Enthalpy change of each block  
ΔH_hot  = m₁ cₚ (T_f – T₁)  
         = (1.00 × 10⁴ g)(0.385 J K⁻¹ g⁻¹)(323.15 K – 373.15 K)  
         = –1.93 × 10⁵ J  

ΔH_cold = m₂ cₚ (T_f – T₂)  
         = (1.00 × 10⁴ g)(0.385 J K⁻¹ g⁻¹)(323.15 K – 273.15 K)  
         = +1.93 × 10⁵ J  

3. Total enthalpy change of the system  
ΔH_total = ΔH_hot + ΔH_cold  
          = –1.93 × 10⁵ J + 1.93 × 10⁵ J  
          = 0 J

(Alternatively, since H ∝ m cₚ T,   
ΔH_total = m cₚ(2T_f – T₁ – T₂) = 0.)

\[

\]

question: A perfect gas undergoes isothermal compression, which reduces its volume by $2.20 \mathrm{dm}^3$. The final pressure and volume of the gas are $5.04 \mathrm{bar}$ and $4.65 \mathrm{dm}^3$, respectively. Calculate the original pressure of the gas in atm.
llm_answer:
Isothermal condition: P₁V₁ = P₂V₂  

1. Find the initial volume  
 ΔV = V₁ – V₂  ⇒ V₁ = V₂ + ΔV = 4.65 dm³ + 2.20 dm³ = 6.85 dm³

2. Solve for the initial pressure in bar  
 P₁ = P₂ V₂ / V₁ = 5.04 bar × 4.65 dm³ / 6.85 dm³ = 3.42 bar

3. Convert bar → atm (1 bar = 0.986 923 atm)  
 P₁(atm) = 3.42 bar × 0.986 923 atm bar⁻¹ = 3.38 atm

\boxed{3.38} atm
llm_output:

1. Find the initial volume

2. Solve for the initial pressure in bar  
 P₁ = P₂ V₂ / V₁ = 5.04 bar × 4.65 dm³ / 6.85 dm³ = 3.42 bar

 P₁(atm) = 3.42 bar × 0.986 923 atm bar⁻¹ = 3.38 atm

\boxed{3.38} atm

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the total change in entropy, when a sample of nitrogen gas of mass $14 \mathrm{~g}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ and $1.00 \mathrm{bar}$ doubles its volume in an isothermal irreversible expansion against $p_{\mathrm{ex}}=0$.
llm_answer:
Step 1: Amount of substance  
Molar mass of N₂ ≈ 28 g mol⁻¹  
n = 14 g / 28 g mol⁻¹ = 0.50 mol  

Step 2: Entropy change of the gas (system) for an isothermal expansion of an ideal gas  
ΔS_sys = n R ln(V₂/V₁)  
Since the volume doubles, V₂/V₁ = 2:

ΔS_sys = (0.50 mol)(8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹) ln 2  
      = 4.157 J K⁻¹ × 0.6931  
      ≈ 2.88 J K⁻¹  

Step 3: Entropy change of the surroundings  
The expansion is against vacuum (p_ex = 0), so w = 0.  
For an ideal gas at constant T, ΔU = 0 ⇒ q = ΔU – w = 0.  
Therefore, ΔS_surr = q/T = 0.

Step 4: Total entropy change  
ΔS_total = ΔS_sys + ΔS_surr  
      = 2.88 J K⁻¹ + 0  
      = 2.88 J K⁻¹  

\boxed{2.88} J K⁻¹
llm_output:

Molar mass of N₂ ≈ 28 g mol⁻¹  
n = 14 g / 28 g mol⁻¹ = 0.50 mol  

Step 2: Entropy change of the gas (system) for an isothermal expansion of an ideal gas  
ΔS_sys = n R ln(V₂/V₁)  
Since the volume doubles, V₂/V₁ = 2:

ΔS_sys = (0.50 mol)(8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹) ln 2  
      = 4.157 J K⁻¹ × 0.6931  
      ≈ 2.88 J K⁻¹

Therefore, ΔS_surr = q/T = 0.

Step 4: Total entropy change  
ΔS_total = ΔS_sys + ΔS_surr  
      = 2.88 J K⁻¹ + 0  
      = 2.88 J K⁻¹  

\boxed{2.88} J K⁻¹

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate the change in the molar Gibbs energy of hydrogen gas when its pressure is increased isothermally from $1.0 \mathrm{~atm}$ to 100.0 atm at $298 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
For a perfect gas the molar Gibbs energy (chemical potential) at temperature \(T\) is  

\[
\mu(T,P)=\mu^{\circ}(T)+RT\ln\!\left(\frac{P}{P^{\circ}}\right)
\]

Hence, for an isothermal pressure change from \(P_1\) to \(P_2\)

\[
\Delta G_m = \mu(T,P_2)-\mu(T,P_1)=RT\ln\!\left(\frac{P_2}{P_1}\right)
\]

Insert the given data  

\(P_1 = 1.0\ \text{atm},\; P_2 = 100.0\ \text{atm},\; T = 298.15\ \text{K},\; R = 8.314462618\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta G_m &= (8.314462618\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(298.15\ \text{K})
             \ln\!\left(\frac{100.0}{1.0}\right) \\[4pt]
           &= 2478.96\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\times 4.605170186 \\[4pt]
           &= 1.1416\times 10^{4}\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\\[4pt]
           &= 11.416\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
\]

Rounded to an appropriate number of significant figures:

\[
\boxed{11.42}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:

             \ln\!\left(\frac{100.0}{1.0}\right) \\[4pt]

\]

\;\text{bar}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate $\Delta S$ (for the system) when the state of $3.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ of perfect gas atoms, for which $C_{p, \mathrm{~m}}=\frac{5}{2} R$, is changed from $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and 1.00 atm to $125^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $5.00 \mathrm{~atm}$.
llm_answer:
For an ideal gas the molar entropy change between two states 1 and 2 is  

\[
\Delta S_{\mathrm m}=C_{p,\mathrm m}\,\ln\!\left(\frac{T_2}{T_1}\right)-R\ln\!\left(\frac{P_2}{P_1}\right)
\]

Given  
n = 3.00 mol, \(C_{p,\mathrm m}= \dfrac{5}{2}R\), \(T_1=25^{\circ}\mathrm C=298.15\;\mathrm K\), \(T_2=125^{\circ}\mathrm C=398.15\;\mathrm K\),  
\(P_1 = 1.00\;\mathrm{atm}\), \(P_2 = 5.00\;\mathrm{atm}\),

1. Calculate the temperature and pressure ratios:

\[
\frac{T_2}{T_1}= \frac{398.15}{298.15}=1.3354 ,\qquad
\frac{P_2}{P_1}=5.00
\]

2. Insert in the entropy‐change expression:

\[
\Delta S_{\mathrm m}= \frac{5}{2}R\ln(1.3354)-R\ln(5.00)
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\ln(1.3354)&=0.289\;,\\
\ln(5.00)&=1.609
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\Delta S_{\mathrm m}= \frac{5}{2}(8.314)\,(0.289)\;-\;8.314\,(1.609)
            = 6.02 - 13.38
            = -7.36\;\mathrm{J\,K^{-1}\,mol^{-1}}
\]

3. Multiply by the amount of substance:

\[
\Delta S = n\,\Delta S_{\mathrm m}= 3.00\;(-7.36)= -22.1\;\mathrm{J\,K^{-1}}
\]

\[
\boxed{-22.1}\ \mathrm{J\,K^{-1}}
\]
llm_output:
For an ideal gas the molar entropy change between two states 1 and 2 is  

\[
\Delta S_{\mathrm m}=C_{p,\mathrm m}\,\ln\!\left(\frac{T_2}{T_1}\right)-R\ln\!\left(\frac{P_2}{P_1}\right)
\]

Given  
n = 3.00 mol, \(C_{p,\mathrm m}= \dfrac{5}{2}R\), \(T_1=25^{\circ}\mathrm C=298.15\;\mathrm K\), \(T_2=125^{\circ}\mathrm C=398.15\;\mathrm K\),  
\(P_1 = 1.00\;\mathrm{atm}\), \(P_2 = 5.00\;\mathrm{atm}\),

\[

\]

\[
\Delta S_{\mathrm m}= \frac{5}{2}R\ln(1.3354)-R\ln(5.00)
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\ln(1.3354)&=0.289\;,\\
\ln(5.00)&=1.609
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\Delta S_{\mathrm m}= \frac{5}{2}(8.314)\,(0.289)\;-\;8.314\,(1.609)
            = 6.02 - 13.38
            = -7.36\;\mathrm{J\,K^{-1}\,mol^{-1}}
\]

3. Multiply by the amount of substance:

\[
\Delta S = n\,\Delta S_{\mathrm m}= 3.00\;(-7.36)= -22.1\;\mathrm{J\,K^{-1}}
\]

\[
\boxed{-22.1}\ \mathrm{J\,K^{-1}}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. A chemical reaction takes place in a container of cross-sectional area $100 \mathrm{~cm}^2$. As a result of the reaction, a piston is pushed out through $10 \mathrm{~cm}$ against an external pressure of $1.0 \mathrm{~atm}$. Calculate the work done by the system.
llm_answer:
Step 1 Convert the geometric data to SI units  
Area: A = 100 cm² = 100 × 10⁻⁴ m² = 1.0 × 10⁻² m²  
Displacement of the piston: Δl = 10 cm = 0.10 m  

Step 2 Calculate the change in volume  
ΔV = A Δl = (1.0 × 10⁻² m²)(0.10 m) = 1.0 × 10⁻³ m³  

Step 3 Convert the external pressure to pascals  
P_ext = 1.0 atm = 1.01325 × 10⁵ Pa  

Step 4 Compute the work done by the system  
(For expansion against a constant external pressure, work done by the system is W = P_ext ΔV.)  

W = (1.01325 × 10⁵ Pa)(1.0 × 10⁻³ m³)  
  = 1.01325 × 10² J  
  ≈ 1.01 × 10² J  

\[
\boxed{1.01 \times 10^{2}}
\] J

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. When $229 \mathrm{~J}$ of energy is supplied as heat to $3.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{Ar}(\mathrm{g})$ at constant pressure, the temperature of the sample increases by $2.55 \mathrm{~K}$. Calculate the molar heat capacities at constant pressure of the gas.

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. The change in the Gibbs energy of a certain constant-pressure process was found to fit the expression $\Delta G / \text{J}=-85.40+36.5(T / \text{K})$. Calculate the value of $\Delta S$ for the process.
llm_answer:
For a constant-pressure process the temperature dependence of the Gibbs energy is  

dG = –S dT ⇒ S = –(∂G/∂T)_P.

Given ΔG(T) = –85.40 J + 36.5 J K⁻¹·T,

differentiate with respect to T at constant pressure:

∂(ΔG)/∂T = 36.5 J K⁻¹.

Hence

ΔS = –(∂ΔG/∂T)_P = –36.5 J K⁻¹.

\[
\boxed{-36.5}\ \mathrm{J\,K^{-1}}
\]

differentiate with respect to T at constant pressure:

∂(ΔG)/∂T = 36.5 J K⁻¹.

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Calculate $\Delta S_\text{tot}$ when two copper blocks, each of mass $10.0 \mathrm{~kg}$, one at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and the other at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, are placed in contact in an isolated container. The specific heat capacity of copper is $0.385 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~g}^{-1}$ and may be assumed constant over the temperature range involved.
llm_answer:
Step 1 Convert the initial temperatures to kelvin  
T₁ = 100 °C = 373.15 K  
T₂ =   0 °C = 273.15 K  

Step 2 Final equilibrium temperature (energy conservation; the blocks have the same heat capacity C = mc)  
T_f = (T₁ + T₂)/2  
T_f = (373.15 K + 273.15 K)/2 = 323.15 K  

Step 3 Entropy change of each block (c = 0.385 J K⁻¹ g⁻¹, m = 10.0 kg = 1.00 × 10⁴ g)  
C = mc = (1.00 × 10⁴ g)(0.385 J K⁻¹ g⁻¹) = 3.85 × 10³ J K⁻¹  

Hot block (373.15 → 323.15 K)  
ΔS₁ = C ln(T_f/T₁)

Cold block (273.15 → 323.15 K)  
ΔS₂ = C ln(T_f/T₂)

Step 4 Total entropy change  
ΔS_tot = C [ln(T_f/T₁) + ln(T_f/T₂)]
        = (3.85 × 10³ J K⁻¹) [ln(323.15/373.15) + ln(323.15/273.15)]

Numerical evaluation  
ln(323.15/373.15) ≈ –0.1439  
ln(323.15/273.15) ≈  +0.1681  

ΔS_tot ≈ (3.85 × 10³)(0.02419) J K⁻¹  
ΔS_tot ≈ 9.31 × 10¹ J K⁻¹  

\boxed{9.31\times10^{1}} J K^{-1}

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. The standard enthalpy of formation of ethylbenzene is $-12.5 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. Calculate its standard enthalpy of combustion.
llm_answer:
The combustion reaction for ethylbenzene (C₈H₁₀, ℓ) is  

C₈H₁₀(ℓ) + 21/2 O₂(g) → 8 CO₂(g) + 5 H₂O(ℓ)

Using standard heats of formation (kJ mol⁻¹, 298 K):
Δ_fH°[C₈H₁₀(ℓ)] = –12.5  
Δ_fH°[CO₂(g)]   = –393.5  
Δ_fH°[H₂O(ℓ)]   = –285.8  
Δ_fH°[O₂(g)]    =   0  

Δ_cH° = Σ ν Δ_fH°(products) – Σ ν Δ_fH°(reactants)

= [8(–393.5) + 5(–285.8)] – [ (–12.5) + 0 ]

= (–3148.0 – 1429.0) + 12.5

= –4564.5

Hence, rounded to three significant figures,

\boxed{-4.56\times10^{3}} kJ mol⁻¹

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. The standard enthalpy of decomposition of the yellow complex $\mathrm{H}_3 \mathrm{NSO}_2$ into $\mathrm{NH}_3$ and $\mathrm{SO}_2$ is $+40 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. Calculate the standard enthalpy of formation of $\mathrm{H}_3 \mathrm{NSO}_2$.
llm_answer:
For the decomposition reaction  

H₃NSO₂(𝐲) → NH₃(g) + SO₂(g)    ΔH° = +40 kJ mol⁻¹

the standard reaction enthalpy equals the difference between the standard enthalpies of formation of products and reactant:

ΔH° = [ΔH_f°(NH₃) + ΔH_f°(SO₂)] − ΔH_f°(H₃NSO₂)

Re-arranging,

ΔH_f°(H₃NSO₂) = [ΔH_f°(NH₃) + ΔH_f°(SO₂)] − ΔH°

Using the tabulated 298 K values  
ΔH_f°(NH₃(g)) = −46.1 kJ mol⁻¹  
ΔH_f°(SO₂(g)) = −296.8 kJ mol⁻¹

ΔH_f°(H₃NSO₂) = [−46.1 + (−296.8)] − 40  
          = −342.9 − 40  
          = −382.9 kJ mol⁻¹

Rounded to three significant figures,

\boxed{-3.83\times10^{2}} kJ mol⁻¹
llm_output:

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. Calculate the work needed for a $65 \mathrm{~kg}$ person to climb through $4.0 \mathrm{~m}$ on the surface of the Earth.
llm_answer:
The minimum mechanical work required equals the increase in gravitational potential energy:

1. Gravitational potential energy change  
   ΔU = m g h

2. Insert the data  
   m = 65 kg  
   g = 9.81 m s⁻²  
   h = 4.0 m  

   ΔU = (65 kg)(9.81 m s⁻²)(4.0 m)

3. Calculate  
   ΔU = 2.55 × 10³ J

Hence, the work needed is

\boxed{2.55\times10^{3}}
\] J

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. Calculate the work needed for a $65 \mathrm{~kg}$ person to climb through $4.0 \mathrm{~m}$ on the surface of the Moon $\left(g=1.60 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}\right)$.
llm_answer:
To raise a body of mass m through a height h against a constant gravitational field g, the minimum work required is the gravitational potential-energy change:

1. Identify the given data  
• m = 65 kg  
• h = 4.0 m  
• g (Moon) = 1.60 m s⁻²  

2. Use the expression for gravitational work  
W = m g h

3. Substitute the numbers  
W = (65 kg)(1.60 m s⁻²)(4.0 m)  
W = 65 × 1.60 × 4.0 J  
W = 416 J

\[
\boxed{416}
\; \text{J}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. Calculate the final pressure of a sample of carbon dioxide that expands reversibly and adiabatically from $57.4 \mathrm{kPa}$ and $1.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ to a final volume of $2.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$. Take $\gamma=1.4$.
llm_answer:
For a reversible adiabatic (i.e., isentropic) change of an ideal gas,

  P V^{\gamma}= \text{constant}

Hence, for the initial state (1) and final state (2),

  P_{1}V_{1}^{\gamma}=P_{2}V_{2}^{\gamma}
  \Longrightarrow P_{2}=P_{1}\left(\dfrac{V_{1}}{V_{2}}\right)^{\gamma}

Given  
P₁ = 57.4 kPa, V₁ = 1.0 dm³, V₂ = 2.0 dm³, γ = 1.4  

Compute the volume ratio:

  V₁ / V₂ = 1.0 / 2.0 = 0.5

Raise to the γ power:

  (0.5)^{1.4} = \exp\!\bigl[\,1.4\,\ln(0.5)\bigr] ≈ \exp(-0.9704) ≈ 0.379

Now evaluate P₂:

  P₂ = 57.4 kPa × 0.379 ≈ 21.8 kPa

Therefore,

\[
\boxed{21.8}\, \text{kPA}
\]
llm_output:

Calculate the molar heat capacities at constant volume.

Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. The fugacity coefficient of a certain gas at $200 \mathrm{~K}$ and 50 bar is 0.72. Calculate the difference of its molar Gibbs energy from that of a perfect gas in the same state.
llm_answer:
For a real gas the molar Gibbs energy differs from that of a perfect gas at the same T and P by  

\[
\Delta \bar G = \bar G - \bar G^{\text{ideal}} = RT\ln\left(\frac{f}{P}\right)=RT\ln\phi .
\]

Given  
T = 200 K, φ = 0.72, and R = 8.314 462 618 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹,

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \bar G &= (8.314462618\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(200\ \text{K})\,
               \ln(0.72) \\[4pt]
              &= 1662.8925236\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\,
               (-0.328504067) \\[4pt]
              &= -546.4\ \text{J mol}^{-1} \\[4pt]
              &= -0.546\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Therefore,

\[
\boxed{-0.546}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Unless otherwise stated, thermodynamic data are for 298.15 K. For the reaction $\mathrm{C}_2 \mathrm{H}_5 \mathrm{OH}(\mathrm{l})+3 \mathrm{O}_2(\mathrm{~g}) \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})+3 \mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{g})$, $\Delta_{\mathrm{r}} U^\ominus=-1373 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at $298 \mathrm{~K}$, calculate $\Delta_{\mathrm{r}} H^{\ominus}$.
llm_answer:
For an ideal gas mixture, the relation between the standard reaction enthalpy and the standard reaction internal-energy change is  

Δ₍r₎H° = Δ₍r₎U° + Δn_g RT ,

where  
Δn_g = (total stoichiometric moles of gaseous products) − (total stoichiometric moles of gaseous reactants).

1. Determine Δn_g  
   Reactant gases: 3 O₂(g)  → 3 mol  
   Product gases: 2 CO₂(g) + 3 H₂O(g)  → 5 mol  

   Δn_g = 5 − 3 = 2

2. Evaluate Δn_g RT at 298 K  
   R = 8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹  
   T = 298.15 K  

   Δn_g RT = 2 × 8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹ × 298.15 K
            ≈ 4.96 × 10³ J mol⁻¹
            = 4.96 kJ mol⁻¹

3. Obtain Δ₍r₎H°  
   Δ₍r₎H° = Δ₍r₎U° + Δn_g RT  
           = (−1373 kJ mol⁻¹) + (4.96 kJ mol⁻¹)  
           ≈ −1368 kJ mol⁻¹

\[
\boxed{-1.37 \times 10^{3}} \text{ kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Note that 1 atm = 1.013 25 bar. Unless otherwise stated, thermochemical data are for 298.15 K. A sample consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2$ occupies a fixed volume of $15.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $300 \mathrm{~K}$. When it is supplied with $2.35 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of energy as heat its temperature increases to $341 \mathrm{~K}$. Assume that $\mathrm{CO}_2$ is described by the van der Waals equation of state, and calculate $w$.
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Identify the kind of work involved  
For a closed system containing a gas, the only mechanical work possible is boundary (pressure–volume) work  

w = ∫ P_ext dV .

Step 2 – Examine the process conditions  
The problem states that the sample “occupies a fixed volume of 15.0 dm³”.  
Hence, during the heating process  

dV = 0  ⇒ ∫ P_ext dV = 0 .

Step 3 – Conclude  
Because the volume is rigid, no pressure-volume work is performed, independent of the equation of state used to describe the gas.

\; \text{J}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Note that 1 atm = 1.01325 bar. Unless otherwise stated, thermochemical data are for 298.15 K. Take nitrogen to be a van der Waals gas with $a=1.352 \mathrm{dm}^6 \mathrm{~atm} \mathrm{\textrm {mol } ^ { - 2 }}$ and $b=0.0387 \mathrm{dm}^3 \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, and calculate $\Delta H_{\mathrm{m}}$ when the pressure on the gas is decreased from $500 \mathrm{~atm}$ to $1.00 \mathrm{~atm}$ at $300 \mathrm{~K}$. For a van der Waals gas, $\mu=\{(2 a / R T)-b\} / C_{p, \mathrm{~m}}$. Assume $C_{p, \mathrm{~m}}=\frac{7}{2} R$.
llm_answer:
For one mole of a van der Waals gas the Joule-Thomson coefficient is  

\[
\mu = \frac{\displaystyle\frac{2a}{RT}-b}{C_{p,m}}
\]

and the general relation  

\[
\left(\frac{\partial H}{\partial P}\right)_T=-C_{p,m}\mu
\]

gives the molar enthalpy change at constant temperature:

\[
\Delta H_m=\int_{P_i}^{P_f}\left(\frac{\partial H}{\partial P}\right)_T dP
          =-C_{p,m}\mu\,(P_f-P_i)
          =-\Bigl(\tfrac{2a}{RT}-b\Bigr)(P_f-P_i)
\]

(the factor \(C_{p,m}\) cancels out).

Data (N₂, 300 K)   
 \(a = 1.352\;\text{dm}^6\text{ atm mol}^{-2}\)   
 \(b = 0.0387\;\text{dm}^3\text{ mol}^{-1}\)   
 \(R = 0.082057\;\text{dm}^3\text{ atm K}^{-1}\text{ mol}^{-1}\)

1. Calculate the bracketed term  

\[
\frac{2a}{RT}-b
        =\frac{2(1.352)}{(0.082057)(300)}-0.0387
        =0.1099-0.0387
        =0.0712\;\text{dm}^3\text{ mol}^{-1}.
\]

2. Insert the pressures (\(P_i=500\;\text{atm},\;P_f=1.00\;\text{atm}\))  

\[
\Delta H_m
 =-\,(0.0712\;\text{dm}^3)(1.00-500)\;\text{atm}
 =\;(0.0712)(499)\;\text{dm}^3\text{ atm}
 = 35.53\;\text{L atm}.
\]

3. Convert \( \text{L atm}\to\text{J}\;(1\;\text{L atm}=101.325\;\text{J})\)

\[
\Delta H_m = 35.53 \times 101.325 = 3.60\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
           = 3.60\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

Hence, on expanding the nitrogen from 500 atm to 1 atm at 300 K,

\[
\boxed{3.60}\text{ kJ}
\]

For one mole of a van der Waals gas the Joule-Thomson coefficient is  

\[
\mu = \frac{\displaystyle\frac{2a}{RT}-b}{C_{p,m}}
\]

and the general relation  

\[
\left(\frac{\partial H}{\partial P}\right)_T=-C_{p,m}\mu
\]

gives the molar enthalpy change at constant temperature:

\[
\Delta H_m=\int_{P_i}^{P_f}\left(\frac{\partial H}{\partial P}\right)_T dP
          =-C_{p,m}\mu\,(P_f-P_i)
          =-\Bigl(\tfrac{2a}{RT}-b\Bigr)(P_f-P_i)
\]

(the factor \(C_{p,m}\) cancels out).

Data (N₂, 300 K)   
 \(a = 1.352\;\text{dm}^6\text{ atm mol}^{-2}\)   
 \(b = 0.0387\;\text{dm}^3\text{ mol}^{-1}\)   
 \(R = 0.082057\;\text{dm}^3\text{ atm K}^{-1}\text{ mol}^{-1}\)

1. Calculate the bracketed term  

\[
\frac{2a}{RT}-b
        =\frac{2(1.352)}{(0.082057)(300)}-0.0387
        =0.1099-0.0387
        =0.0712\;\text{dm}^3\text{ mol}^{-1}.
\]

2. Insert the pressures (\(P_i=500\;\text{atm},\;P_f=1.00\;\text{atm}\))  

\[
\Delta H_m
 =-\,(0.0712\;\text{dm}^3)(1.00-500)\;\text{atm}
 =\;(0.0712)(499)\;\text{dm}^3\text{ atm}
 = 35.53\;\text{L atm}.
\]

3. Convert \( \text{L atm}\to\text{J}\;(1\;\text{L atm}=101.325\;\text{J})\)

\[
\Delta H_m = 35.53 \times 101.325 = 3.60\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}
           = 3.60\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

Hence, on expanding the nitrogen from 500 atm to 1 atm at 300 K,

\[
\boxed{3.60}\text{ kJ}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Note that 1 atm = 1.013 25 bar. Unless otherwise stated, thermochemical data are for 298.15 K. A sample consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2$ occupies a fixed volume of $15.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $300 \mathrm{~K}$. When it is supplied with $2.35 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of energy as heat its temperature increases to $341 \mathrm{~K}$. Assume that $\mathrm{CO}_2$ is described by the van der Waals equation of state, and calculate $\Delta H$.
llm_answer:
The van der Waals constants for CO₂ are  
a = 3.640 L² bar mol⁻²  b = 0.04267 L mol⁻¹  
R = 0.08314 L bar K⁻¹ mol⁻¹

1. Molar volume (constant throughout the process)  
 V = 15.0 L, n = 2.0 mol ⇒ Vₘ = V/n = 7.5 L mol⁻¹  

2. Pressures at the two temperatures  
 P = RT /(Vₘ – b) – a / Vₘ²  

 P₁ (T₁ = 300 K):  
  P₁ = (0.08314·300)/(7.5 − 0.04267) − 3.640/7.5²  
  P₁ = 3.28 bar  

 P₂ (T₂ = 341 K):  
  P₂ = (0.08314·341)/(7.5 − 0.04267) − 3.640/7.5²  
  P₂ = 3.74 bar  

3. Change in the PV term at constant volume  
 Δ(PV) = V (P₂ − P₁)  
     = 15.0 L × (3.74 − 3.28) bar  
     = 6.88 L·bar = 0.688 kJ  (1 L·bar = 0.100 kJ)

4. Internal-energy change (constant-volume heating)  
 ΔU = q_V = +2.35 kJ  

5. Enthalpy change  
 ΔH = ΔU + Δ(PV)  
    = 2.35 kJ + 0.688 kJ  
    = 3.04 kJ

\[
\boxed{3.04}\,\text{kJ}
\]

w = −P_ext ΔV

w ≈ −20.3 J

question: Use the van der Waals parameters for chlorine to calculate approximate values of the radius of a $\mathrm{Cl}_2$ molecule regarded as a sphere.
llm_answer:
Step 1 Gather the van der Waals constant b for chlorine  
b(Cl₂)=0.0562 L mol⁻¹=0.0562×10⁻³ m³ mol⁻¹=5.62×10⁻⁵ m³ mol⁻¹.

Step 2 Convert the “covolume’’ to the actual volume of one molecule  
For a van der Waals gas the covolume b equals four times the real volume occupied by one mole of molecules:  

 V_real (per molecule)= b ⁄ (4N_A)

  = 5.62×10⁻⁵ m³ mol⁻¹ ⁄ (4×6.022 140 76×10²³ mol⁻¹)  
  = 2.33×10⁻²⁹ m³.

Step 3 Relate that volume to a spherical radius  
V_real = (4⁄3)πr³  ⇒ r = [3V_real/(4π)]^{1/3}

 r = [3(2.33×10⁻²⁹ m³)/(4π)]^{1/3}  
   = [5.57×10⁻³⁰ m³]^{1/3}  
   = 1.77×10⁻¹⁰ m.

Step 4 Convert to nanometres  
1 m = 10⁹ nm → r = 1.77×10⁻¹⁰ m = 0.177 nm.

\[
\boxed{0.177}\ \text{nm}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. A sample consisting of $3.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ of diatomic perfect gas molecules at $200 \mathrm{~K}$ is compressed reversibly and adiabatically until its temperature reaches $250 \mathrm{~K}$. Given that $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=27.5 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate $\Delta U$.
llm_answer:
For an ideal gas the molar internal energy depends only on temperature:

ΔU = n C_{V,m}(T₂ – T₁)

Given  
n = 3.00 mol  
C_{V,m} = 27.5 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹  
T₁ = 200 K  
T₂ = 250 K

Temperature change  
ΔT = T₂ – T₁ = 250 K – 200 K = 50 K

Substitute:

ΔU = (3.00 mol)(27.5 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹)(50 K)
    = 3.00 × 27.5 × 50 J
    = 3.00 × 1 375 J
    = 4 125 J

Convert to kilojoules:

ΔU = 4 125 J × (1 kJ / 1 000 J) = 4.125 kJ

Rounded to three significant figures:

\boxed{4.13} kJ
llm_output:

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Consider a system consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})$, initially at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $10 \mathrm{~atm}$ and confined to a cylinder of cross-section $10.0 \mathrm{~cm}^2$. It is allowed to expand adiabatically against an external pressure of 1.0 atm until the piston has moved outwards through $20 \mathrm{~cm}$. Assume that carbon dioxide may be considered a perfect gas with $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=28.8 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ and calculate $\Delta U$.
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Volume change produced by the piston  
Area of piston:  
A = 10.0 cm² = 10.0 × 10⁻⁴ m² = 1.0 × 10⁻³ m²  

Distance moved:  
d = 20 cm = 0.20 m  

ΔV = A d = (1.0 × 10⁻³ m²)(0.20 m) = 2.0 × 10⁻⁴ m³  
  (= 0.20 L)

Step 2 – Work done in the irreversible adiabatic expansion  
External pressure (constant):  
P_ext = 1.0 atm = 1.01325 × 10⁵ Pa  

w = –P_ext ΔV  
  = –(1.01325 × 10⁵ Pa)(2.0 × 10⁻⁴ m³)  
  = –2.0265 × 10¹ J  
  ≈ –20.3 J

Step 3 – Internal-energy change  
Because the process is adiabatic, q = 0, so  

ΔU = q + w = w = –20.3 J

(Optional check)  
ΔT = ΔU / (n C_V) = (–20.3 J)/(2.0 mol × 28.8 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹) ≈ –0.35 K, confirming a slight cooling.

Final result  
\boxed{-2.03\times10^{1}} J

question: The mass density of water vapour at $327.6 \mathrm{~atm}$ and $776.4 \mathrm{~K}$ is $133.2 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$. Given that for water $T_{\mathrm{c}}=647.4 \mathrm{~K}, p_{\mathrm{c}}=218.3 \mathrm{~atm}, a=5.464 \mathrm{dm}^6 \mathrm{~atm} \mathrm{~mol}^{-2}$, $b=0.03049 \mathrm{dm}^3 \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, and $M=18.02 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate the molar volume.
llm_answer:
Step 1.  Convert the given density to convenient units.  
1 m³ = 1000 dm³, 1 kg = 1000 g  
ρ = 133.2 kg m⁻³ = 133.2 g dm⁻³  

Step 2.  Relate molar volume to density.  
V_m = mass of one mole / density = M / ρ  

Step 3.  Insert the molar mass of water (M = 18.02 g mol⁻¹).  
V_m = 18.02 g mol⁻¹ / 133.2 g dm⁻³  
V_m = 0.1353 dm³ mol⁻¹  

\[
\boxed{0.1353}
\] dm³ mol⁻¹

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. A sample consisting of $3.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ of diatomic perfect gas molecules at $200 \mathrm{~K}$ is compressed reversibly and adiabatically until its temperature reaches $250 \mathrm{~K}$. Given that $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=27.5 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate $\Delta S$.
llm_answer:
For a closed system containing an ideal gas the molar entropy change between two states 1 (T₁ , V₁) and 2 (T₂ , V₂) can always be written as  

ΔS = n [C_{V,m} ln(T₂/T₁) + R ln(V₂/V₁)]                     (1)

Step 1.  Relate V₂/V₁ for a reversible adiabatic change  
For an ideal gas undergoing a reversible adiabatic process

T V^{γ-1} = constant with γ = C_{p}/C_{v} = (C_{V,m}+R)/C_{V,m}

C_{V,m} = 27.5 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹ → γ = (27.5 + 8.314)/27.5 = 1.30234

Hence  

V₂/V₁ = (T₁/T₂)^{1/(γ-1)}
      = (200 K / 250 K)^{1/(1.30234−1)}
      = 0.8^{1/0.30234} = 0.8^{3.308} = 0.479    (2)

Step 2.  Insert the ratios in equation (1)

ln(T₂/T₁) = ln(250/200) = ln(1.25) = 0.22314  
ln(V₂/V₁) = ln(0.479)   = −0.73700

ΔS = n [ C_{V,m} ln(T₂/T₁) + R ln(V₂/V₁) ]
    = 3.00 mol [ 27.5 (0.22314) + 8.314 (−0.73700) ] J K⁻¹
    = 3.00 mol [ 6.136 − 6.132 ] J K⁻¹
    ≈ 3.00 mol × 0.004 J K⁻¹ ≈ 0 J K⁻¹

(The tiny non-zero number stems only from rounding.)

Step 3.  Physical interpretation  
Because the process is both reversible and adiabatic, δq_rev = 0 throughout, so the entropy of the system cannot change. The calculation above confirms this.

Final result  

\boxed{0}\; \text{J K}^{-1}

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Consider a system consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})$, initially at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $10 \mathrm{~atm}$ and confined to a cylinder of cross-section $10.0 \mathrm{~cm}^2$. It is allowed to expand adiabatically against an external pressure of 1.0 atm until the piston has moved outwards through $20 \mathrm{~cm}$. Assume that carbon dioxide may be considered a perfect gas with $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=28.8 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ and calculate $\Delta S$.
llm_answer:
Step 1.  Geometric volume change  
Area of the piston  
A = 10.0 cm² = 10.0 × 10⁻⁴ m² = 1.00 × 10⁻³ m²  
Displacement  
d = 20 cm = 0.200 m  
ΔV = A·d = (1.00 × 10⁻³ m²)(0.200 m) = 2.00 × 10⁻⁴ m³  

Step 2.  Temperature after the adiabatic, irreversible expansion  
q = 0  (adiabatic)  
w = –P_ext ΔV = –(1.00 atm)(2.00 × 10⁻⁴ m³)  
   = –(101 325 Pa)(2.00 × 10⁻⁴ m³) = –20.265 J  

ΔU = q + w = w = nC_V ΔT  
ΔT = w /(nC_V) = (–20.265 J)/(2.0 mol × 28.8 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)  
   = –0.353 K  

T₂ = T₁ + ΔT = 298.15 K – 0.353 K = 297.80 K  

Step 3.  Initial and final volumes  
Ideal-gas law (SI units)  
V₁ = nRT₁ / P₁ = (2.0 mol)(8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)(298.15 K)/(10 atm × 101 325 Pa atm⁻¹)  
   = 4.892 × 10⁻³ m³  

V₂ = V₁ + ΔV = 4.892 × 10⁻³ m³ + 2.00 × 10⁻⁴ m³  
   = 5.093 × 10⁻³ m³  

Step 4.  Entropy change of the gas  
For a perfect gas of constant C_V,  
ΔS = n[C_V ln(T₂/T₁) + R ln(V₂/V₁)]

ln(T₂/T₁) = ln(297.80/298.15) = –0.00118  
ln(V₂/V₁) = ln(5.093 × 10⁻³ / 4.892 × 10⁻³) = ln(1.0409) = 0.0401  

ΔS = 2.0 mol[28.8 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹(–0.00118) + 8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹(0.0401)]  
   = 2.0 mol[–0.0341 J K⁻¹ + 0.333 J K⁻¹]  
   = 2.0 mol(0.299 J K⁻¹)  
   = 0.598 J K⁻¹

question: The mass density of water vapour at $327.6 \mathrm{~atm}$ and $776.4 \mathrm{~K}$ is $133.2 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$. Given that for water $T_{\mathrm{c}}=647.4 \mathrm{~K}, p_{\mathrm{c}}=218.3 \mathrm{~atm}, a=5.464 \mathrm{dm}^6 \mathrm{~atm} \mathrm{~mol}^{-2}$, $b=0.03049 \mathrm{dm}^3 \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, and $M=18.02 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate the compression factor from the virial expansion of the van der Waals equation.
llm_answer:
The van der Waals equation for one mole of gas is  

\[
\left(p+\frac{a}{\bar V^{2}}\right)(\bar V-b)=RT
\]

With  
\(p\;\) pressure, \(T\;\) temperature, \(a,\,b\) the van der Waals constants and \(\bar V\) the molar volume.  
Expanding the equation as a virial series in powers of \(1/\bar V\) gives

\[
Z\equiv\frac{p\bar V}{RT}=1+\frac{B}{\bar V}+\frac{C}{\bar V^{2}}+\dots
\]

where, for the van der Waals equation,

\[
B = b-\frac{a}{RT},\qquad C = b^{2}.
\]

Step 1 – Molar volume from the density  
\[
\rho = 133.2\;\text{kg\,m}^{-3},\qquad M = 18.02\;\text{g\,mol}^{-1}=0.01802\;\text{kg\,mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\bar V=\frac{M}{\rho}= \frac{0.01802\;\text{kg\,mol}^{-1}}{133.2\;\text{kg\,m}^{-3}}
          =1.353\times10^{-4}\;\text{m}^{3}\text{\,mol}^{-1}
          =0.1353\;\text{dm}^{3}\text{\,mol}^{-1}
\]

Step 2 – First and second virial coefficients  
(Use \(R = 0.082057\;\text{atm\,dm}^{3}\text{mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1},\;T = 776.4\;\text{K}\))

\[
\frac{a}{RT} = \frac{5.464\;\text{dm}^{6}\text{atm\,mol}^{-2}}
                     {(0.082057)(776.4)} = 0.08578\;\text{dm}^{3}\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
B = b-\frac{a}{RT}=0.03049-0.08578 = -0.05529\;\text{dm}^{3}\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
C=b^{2}=(0.03049)^{2}=9.296\times10^{-4}\;\text{dm}^{6}\text{mol}^{-2}
\]

Step 3 – Compression factor to the second virial term  

\[
\frac{B}{\bar V} = \frac{-0.05529}{0.1353} = -0.4087,\qquad
\frac{C}{\bar V^{2}} = \frac{9.296\times10^{-4}}{(0.1353)^{2}} = 0.0508
\]

\[
Z = 1 + \frac{B}{\bar V} + \frac{C}{\bar V^{2}}
   = 1 - 0.4087 + 0.0508 = 0.642
\]

Hence, the compression (compressibility) factor predicted from the virial expansion of the van der Waals equation is  

\[
\boxed{0.642}
\]
llm_output:

question: The mass density of water vapour at $327.6 \mathrm{~atm}$ and $776.4 \mathrm{~K}$ is $133.2 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}$. Given that for water $T_{\mathrm{c}}=647.4 \mathrm{~K}, p_{\mathrm{c}}=218.3 \mathrm{~atm}, a=5.464 \mathrm{dm}^6 \mathrm{~atm} \mathrm{~mol}^{-2}$, $b=0.03049 \mathrm{dm}^3 \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, and $M=18.02 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate the compression factor from the data.

A certain gas obeys the van der Waals equation with $a=0.50 \mathrm{~m}^6 \mathrm{~Pa}$ $\mathrm{mol}^{-2}$. Its volume is found to be $5.00 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~m}^3 \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ at $273 \mathrm{~K}$ and $3.0 \mathrm{MPa}$. From this information calculate the van der Waals constant $b$. What is the compression factor for this gas at the prevailing temperature and pressure?
llm_answer:
Step-by-step solution

1.  Write the van der Waals equation for one mole of gas  
   (P + a/V²)(V – b) = RT

2.  Insert the given data  
   P = 3.0 MPa = 3.0 × 10⁶ Pa  
   V = 5.00 × 10⁻⁴ m³ mol⁻¹  
   T = 273 K  
   a = 0.50 m⁶ Pa mol⁻²  
   R = 8.314 Pa m³ mol⁻¹ K⁻¹

3.  Evaluate the pressure correction  
   a/V² = 0.50 /(5.00 × 10⁻⁴)²  
        = 0.50 /(2.50 × 10⁻⁷)  
        = 2.0 × 10⁶ Pa = 2.0 MPa

   P + a/V² = 3.0 MPa + 2.0 MPa = 5.0 MPa = 5.0 × 10⁶ Pa

4.  Solve for b  
   b = V – RT /(P + a/V²)

   RT = 8.314 × 273 = 2.2697 × 10³ Pa m³ mol⁻¹  

   RT /(P + a/V²) = 2.2697 × 10³ / 5.0 × 10⁶  
                  = 4.54 × 10⁻⁴ m³ mol⁻¹

   b = 5.00 × 10⁻⁴ – 4.54 × 10⁻⁴  
     = 4.6 × 10⁻⁵ m³ mol⁻¹

5.  Compression (compressibility) factor  
   Z = PV / RT  
     = (3.0 × 10⁶)(5.00 × 10⁻⁴) / 2.2697 × 10³  
     = 1.5 × 10³ / 2.2697 × 10³  
     ≈ 0.66

Final answers

\[
\boxed{b = 4.6 \times 10^{-5}\ \text{m}^3\text{ mol}^{-1}},\qquad
\boxed{Z = 0.66}
\]
llm_output:

2.  Insert the given data

   V = 5.00 × 10⁻⁴ m³ mol⁻¹  
   T = 273 K  
   a = 0.50 m⁶ Pa mol⁻²  
   R = 8.314 Pa m³ mol⁻¹ K⁻¹

3.  Evaluate the pressure correction  
   a/V² = 0.50 /(5.00 × 10⁻⁴)²  
        = 0.50 /(2.50 × 10⁻⁷)  
        = 2.0 × 10⁶ Pa = 2.0 MPa

   P + a/V² = 3.0 MPa + 2.0 MPa = 5.0 MPa = 5.0 × 10⁶ Pa

4.  Solve for b  
   b = V – RT /(P + a/V²)

   RT = 8.314 × 273 = 2.2697 × 10³ Pa m³ mol⁻¹  

   RT /(P + a/V²) = 2.2697 × 10³ / 5.0 × 10⁶  
                  = 4.54 × 10⁻⁴ m³ mol⁻¹

   b = 5.00 × 10⁻⁴ – 4.54 × 10⁻⁴  
     = 4.6 × 10⁻⁵ m³ mol⁻¹

5.  Compression (compressibility) factor  
   Z = PV / RT  
     = (3.0 × 10⁶)(5.00 × 10⁻⁴) / 2.2697 × 10³  
     = 1.5 × 10³ / 2.2697 × 10³  
     ≈ 0.66

Final answers

\[
\boxed{b = 4.6 \times 10^{-5}\ \text{m}^3\text{ mol}^{-1}},\qquad
\boxed{Z = 0.66}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. A sample consisting of $3.00 \mathrm{~mol}$ of diatomic perfect gas molecules at $200 \mathrm{~K}$ is compressed reversibly and adiabatically until its temperature reaches $250 \mathrm{~K}$. Given that $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=27.5 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$, calculate $\Delta H$.
llm_answer:
Step 1:  Relate Cp,m to Cv,m  

For an ideal gas  
Cp,m = Cv,m + R  

Cv,m = 27.5 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹  
R = 8.314 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹  

Cp,m = 27.5 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹ + 8.314 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹  
Cp,m = 35.814 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹  

Step 2:  Calculate ΔT  

ΔT = Tf − Ti = 250 K − 200 K = 50 K  

Step 3:  Calculate ΔH for n = 3.00 mol  

ΔH = n Cp,m ΔT  
ΔH = (3.00 mol)(35.814 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹)(50 K)  
ΔH = 5.37 × 10³ J  

Convert to kJ: ΔH = 5.37 kJ  

Final result  
\[
\boxed{5.37}
\] kJ

question: A sample of $255 \mathrm{mg}$ of neon occupies $3.00 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $122 \mathrm{K}$. Use the perfect gas law to calculate the pressure of the gas.
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Convert the given quantities to the units used with the gas constant  
• Mass: 255 mg = 0.255 g  
• Volume: 3.00 dm³ = 3.00 L (1 dm³ = 1 L)  

Step 2 – Moles of neon  
Molar mass of Ne = 20.18 g mol⁻¹  

n = m / M = 0.255 g / 20.18 g mol⁻¹ ≈ 0.0126 mol  

Step 3 – Ideal-gas calculation  
P = nRT / V  

Use R = 0.082057 L atm mol⁻¹ K⁻¹ and T = 122 K:

P = (0.0126 mol)(0.082057 L atm mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)(122 K) / (3.00 L)  
  ≈ 0.0422 atm  

Final answer  

\[
\boxed{0.0422}\ \text{atm}
\]

question: Use the van der Waals parameters for chlorine to calculate approximate values of the Boyle temperature of chlorine.
llm_answer:
The Boyle temperature, T_B, is defined as the temperature at which the second virial coefficient B(T) becomes zero.  
For a van der Waals gas the equation of state  

  (P + a /V_m²)(V_m – b) = RT  

can be rearranged to a virial expansion of the form  

  P V_m = RT + (b – a/RT)P + …  

Hence the second virial coefficient is  

  B(T) = b – a /(RT).  

Setting B(T_B)=0 gives the Boyle temperature  

  b – a /(R T_B) = 0   ⟹  T_B = a /(R b).

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––

Van der Waals constants for chlorine (Cl₂)  
  a = 6.579 L² bar mol⁻²  
  b = 0.05622 L mol⁻¹  

Universal gas constant (consistent units)  
  R = 0.08314 L bar mol⁻¹ K⁻¹  

Substituting:

T_B = a /(R b) = 
      6.579 L² bar mol⁻²
     ──────────────────────
      (0.08314 L bar mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)(0.05622 L mol⁻¹)

     = 6.579
       ───────────────
       0.00467412  

     ≈ 1.41 × 10³.

Therefore,

\[
\boxed{1.41\times 10^{3}} \ \text{K}
\]

question: Assume that all gases are perfect and that data refer to 298.15 K unless otherwise stated. Consider a system consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})$, initially at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $10 \mathrm{~atm}$ and confined to a cylinder of cross-section $10.0 \mathrm{~cm}^2$. It is allowed to expand adiabatically against an external pressure of 1.0 atm until the piston has moved outwards through $20 \mathrm{~cm}$. Assume that carbon dioxide may be considered a perfect gas with $C_{V, \mathrm{~m}}=28.8 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$ and calculate $\Delta T$.
llm_answer:
For an adiabatic process  
q = 0  ⇒ ΔU = w = nC_{V,m} ΔT.

1. Volume change produced by the piston  
 Area A = 10.0 cm² = 1.0 × 10⁻³ m²  
 Displacement Δh = 20 cm = 0.20 m  
 ΔV = A Δh = (1.0 × 10⁻³ m²)(0.20 m) = 2.0 × 10⁻⁴ m³ = 0.200 L

2. Work done on the gas (constant external pressure)  
 P_ext = 1.0 atm = 1.01325 × 10⁵ Pa  
 w = –P_ext ΔV  
 w = –(1.01325 × 10⁵ Pa)(2.0 × 10⁻⁴ m³) = –20.265 J

3. Temperature change  
 n = 2.0 mol, C_{V,m} = 28.8 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹  
 ΔT = w / (nC_{V,m})  
 ΔT = (–20.265 J) / [2.0 mol × 28.8 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹]  
 ΔT = –0.352 K

The temperature therefore falls by 0.352 K.

\[
\boxed{-0.352}\ \text{K}
\]

question: Assume all gases are perfect unless stated otherwise. Note that 1 atm = 1.013 25 bar. Unless otherwise stated, thermochemical data are for 298.15 K. A sample consisting of $2.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{CO}_2$ occupies a fixed volume of $15.0 \mathrm{dm}^3$ at $300 \mathrm{~K}$. When it is supplied with $2.35 \mathrm{~kJ}$ of energy as heat its temperature increases to $341 \mathrm{~K}$. Assume that $\mathrm{CO}_2$ is described by the van der Waals equation of state, and calculate $\Delta U$.
llm_answer:
The system is closed and its volume is kept strictly constant.  
For any simple compressible substance the exact differential of the internal
energy is  

dU = C_V dT + [T(∂P/∂T)_V − P] dV .

Because the volume is fixed, dV = 0 and the second term vanishes, so along the
present path

dU = C_V dT .

From the first law

ΔU = q + w .

At constant volume w = −∫P dV = 0, hence

ΔU = q_V = q .

The only energy exchanged with the surroundings is the heat supplied,
q = + 2.35 kJ.

Therefore

\[
\boxed{2.35}
\text{ kJ}
\]

question: The change in molar internal energy when $\mathrm{CaCO}_3(\mathrm{~s})$ as calcite converts to another form, aragonite, is $+0.21 \mathrm{~kJ} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}$. Calculate the difference between the molar enthalpy and internal energy changes when the pressure is 1.0 bar given that the densities of the polymorphs are $2.71 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$ and $2.93 \mathrm{~g} \mathrm{~cm}^{-3}$, respectively.
llm_answer:
Step 1  Determine the molar volumes.  
Molar mass of CaCO₃  
M = 40.078 + 12.011 + 3 × 15.999 = 100.086 g mol⁻¹

Vₘ(calcite) = M / ρ = 100.086 g mol⁻¹ ⁄ 2.71 g cm⁻³ = 36.93 cm³ mol⁻¹  
Vₘ(aragonite) = 100.086 g mol⁻¹ ⁄ 2.93 g cm⁻³ = 34.16 cm³ mol⁻¹

Step 2  Calculate the molar volume change.  
ΔVₘ = Vₘ(aragonite) – Vₘ(calcite)  
ΔVₘ = 34.16 cm³ mol⁻¹ – 36.93 cm³ mol⁻¹ = –2.78 cm³ mol⁻¹  
Convert to m³ mol⁻¹: –2.78 cm³ mol⁻¹ × 10⁻⁶ m³ cm⁻³ = –2.78 × 10⁻⁶ m³ mol⁻¹

Step 3  Relate enthalpy and internal energy.  
At constant pressure, ΔHₘ – ΔUₘ = p ΔVₘ.

Step 4  Insert p = 1.0 bar = 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa.  
ΔHₘ – ΔUₘ = (1.0 × 10⁵ Pa)(–2.78 × 10⁻⁶ m³ mol⁻¹)  
ΔHₘ – ΔUₘ = –2.78 × 10⁻¹ Pa m³ mol⁻¹

Step 5  Report the result (to two significant figures).  

\boxed{-0.28} Pa m³ mol⁻¹

Step 3  Relate enthalpy and internal energy.  
At constant pressure, ΔHₘ – ΔUₘ = p ΔVₘ.

Step 4  Insert p = 1.0 bar = 1.0 × 10⁵ Pa.  
ΔHₘ – ΔUₘ = (1.0 × 10⁵ Pa)(–2.78 × 10⁻⁶ m³ mol⁻¹)  
ΔHₘ – ΔUₘ = –2.78 × 10⁻¹ Pa m³ mol⁻¹

Step 5  Report the result (to two significant figures).  

\boxed{-0.28} Pa m³ mol⁻¹

question: Suppose the concentration of a solute decays exponentially along the length of a container. Calculate the thermodynamic force on the solute at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ given that the concentration falls to half its value in $10 \mathrm{~cm}$.
llm_answer:
Step-by-step solution

1.  Exponential concentration profile  
   The concentration decreases exponentially along the x–direction:

   c(x)=c_0 e^{-kx}

   After 10 cm (0.10 m) the concentration is one half of its initial value:

   ½c_0 = c_0 e^{-k(0.10)}  ⟹  e^{-0.10k}=½  ⟹  k = \dfrac{\ln 2}{0.10\;\text{m}} = 6.931\;\text{m}^{-1}

2.  Chemical-potential gradient  
   For an ideal dilute solute,

   μ = μ^{\circ}+RT\ln c

   so

   \dfrac{dμ}{dx} = RT\dfrac{d\ln c}{dx}= -RTk

3.  Thermodynamic force  
   The (magnitude of the) thermodynamic force driving diffusion is the gradient of chemical potential:

   F_{\text{th}} = \left| \dfrac{dμ}{dx}\right| = RTk

4.  Numerical evaluation at 25 °C (T = 298 K)  

   R = 8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹  

   RT = 8.314 × 298 = 2.478 × 10³ J mol⁻¹  

   Hence  

   F_{\text{th}} = (2.478 × 10³ J mol⁻¹)(6.931 m⁻¹)  
   = 1.717 × 10⁴ J mol⁻¹ m⁻¹  
   = 1.717 × 10⁴ N mol⁻¹  
   = 17.2 kN mol⁻¹

Final result

\[
\boxed{17.2}\ \mathrm{kN\,mol^{-1}}
\]

question: A container is divided into two equal compartments. One contains $3.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{H}_2(\mathrm{~g})$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$; the other contains $1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{~N}_2(\mathrm{~g})$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Calculate the Gibbs energy of mixing when the partition is removed. Assume perfect behaviour.
llm_answer:
Step 1 – total amount of gas after mixing  
n = n(H₂)+n(N₂)=3.0 mol+1.0 mol=4.0 mol

Step 2 – mole fractions  
x(H₂)=3.0/4.0=0.75  
x(N₂)=1.0/4.0=0.25

Step 3 – expression for the Gibbs energy of mixing (ideal gases)  
ΔG_mix = nRT [ x(H₂) ln x(H₂) + x(N₂) ln x(N₂) ]

Step 4 – insert numerical values (T = 25 °C = 298 K, R = 8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)  
ΔG_mix = 4.0 mol × 8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹ × 298 K × [0.75 ln 0.75 + 0.25 ln 0.25]

Calculate the bracket:  
0.75 ln 0.75 = 0.75(–0.287682) = –0.215762  
0.25 ln 0.25 = 0.25(–1.386294) = –0.346573  
Sum = –0.562335

Now evaluate ΔG_mix:  
ΔG_mix = 4 × 8.314 × 298 × (–0.562335) J  
ΔG_mix ≈ –5.58 × 10³ J  
ΔG_mix ≈ –5.58 kJ

\[
\boxed{-5.58}\ \text{kJ}
\]
llm_output:

x(H₂)=3.0/4.0=0.75

ΔG_mix = 4 × 8.314 × 298 × (–0.562335) J

question: Caesium (m.p. $29^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, b.p. $686^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ) was introduced into a container and heated to $500^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. When a hole of diameter $0.50 \mathrm{~mm}$ was opened in the container for $100 \mathrm{~s}$, a mass loss of $385 \mathrm{mg}$ was measured. Calculate the vapour pressure of liquid caesium at $500 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Convert the experimental data  

Diameter of hole : d = 0.50 mm = 0.50 × 10⁻³ m  
Area of hole : A = πd²/4  
  A = π(0.50 × 10⁻³ m)² /4 = 1.96 × 10⁻⁷ m²  

Mass lost : Δm = 385 mg = 0.385 g = 3.85 × 10⁻⁴ kg  
Molar mass of Cs : M = 132.9 g mol⁻¹ = 0.1329 kg mol⁻¹  

Time : Δt = 100 s  

Step 2 – Molar rate of effusion  

\dot n = (Δm / Δt) / M  
  \dot n = (3.85 × 10⁻⁴ kg / 100 s) / 0.1329 kg mol⁻¹  
  \dot n = 2.90 × 10⁻⁵ mol s⁻¹  

Step 3 – Effusion equation (Hertz–Knudsen expression)  

\dot n = (P A)/√(2πRTM)  

Solve for P : P = \dot n √(2πRTM) / A  

Step 4 – Insert the numerical values (T = 500 K)  

2πRTM = 2π(8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)(500 K)(0.1329 kg mol⁻¹)  
     = 3.47 × 10³ J kg mol⁻²  

√(2πRTM) = 58.96 kg¹ᐟ² m s⁻¹ mol⁻¹ᐟ²  

P = (2.90 × 10⁻⁵ mol s⁻¹)(58.96) / (1.96 × 10⁻⁷ m²)  
 P = 8.70 × 10³ Pa  

Convert to kPa : P = 8.70 kPa  

\[
\boxed{8.70}\ \text{kPa}
\]

Step 3 – Effusion equation (Hertz–Knudsen expression)

P = (2.90 × 10⁻⁵ mol s⁻¹)(58.96) / (1.96 × 10⁻⁷ m²)  
 P = 8.70 × 10³ Pa  

Convert to kPa : P = 8.70 kPa  

\[

\]

question: Calculate the typical wavelength of neutrons that have reached thermal equilibrium with their surroundings at $373 \mathrm{~K}$.
llm_answer:
Typical (most probable) speed of a gas-phase particle at temperature T is obtained from  
½ m v² = k_B T  ⇒ v = √(2 k_B T / m)

For a neutron (mass m_n) the corresponding de Broglie wavelength is  

λ = h / p = h / (m_n v) = h / √(2 m_n k_B T)

Insert the constants  
h = 6.626 070 15 × 10⁻³⁴ J s  
k_B = 1.380 649 × 10⁻²³ J K⁻¹  
m_n = 1.674 927 5 × 10⁻²⁷ kg  
T = 373 K

Denominator:  
2 m_n k_B T = 2(1.674 927 5×10⁻²⁷)(1.380 649×10⁻²³)(373)  
      = 1.726 × 10⁻⁴⁷ kg² m² s⁻²

Momentum magnitude:  
p = √(2 m_n k_B T) = √(1.726×10⁻⁴⁷) = 1.313×10⁻²³ kg m s⁻¹

Wavelength:  
λ = (6.626 070 15×10⁻³⁴) / (1.313×10⁻²³)  
  = 1.596×10⁻¹⁰ m = 1.596×10⁻¹⁰ m × 10¹² pm/m  
  = 1.60×10² pm

Hence

\boxed{160} pm

question: Calculate the separation of the $\{123\}$ planes of an orthorhombic unit cell with $a=0.82 \mathrm{~nm}, b=0.94 \mathrm{~nm}$, and $c=0.75 \mathrm{~nm}$.

Calculate the moment of inertia of an $\mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O}$ molecule around the axis defined by the bisector of the $\mathrm{HOH}$ angle (3). The $\mathrm{HOH}$ bond angle is $104.5^{\circ}$ and the bond length is $95.7 \mathrm{pm}$.
llm_answer:
The bisector of the H–O–H angle lies in the molecular plane and passes through the oxygen atom; the two hydrogen atoms are symmetrically placed with respect to this axis.  
Because the oxygen nucleus and the centre of mass are both located on the bisector, the oxygen does not contribute to the moment of inertia about this axis.  
Hence only the two equivalent H atoms need be considered.

1. Geometric parameters  
   Bond length R = 95.7 pm = 9.57 × 10⁻¹¹ m  
   Half angle  θ = ½(104.5°) = 52.25°  
   Perpendicular distance of each H from the axis  
   ρ = R sin θ = (9.57 × 10⁻¹¹ m)·sin 52.25°  
   sin 52.25° = 0.7907 ⇒ ρ = 9.57 × 10⁻¹¹ m × 0.7907 = 7.56 × 10⁻¹¹ m

2. Mass of a hydrogen atom  
   m_H = 1.007825 u = 1.6735 × 10⁻²⁷ kg

3. Moment of inertia about the bisector (axis 3)  
   I₃ = Σ m_i ρ_i² = 2 m_H ρ²  
   I₃ = 2 (1.6735 × 10⁻²⁷ kg) (7.56 × 10⁻¹¹ m)²  
        = 3.347 × 10⁻²⁷ kg × 5.73 × 10⁻²¹ m²  
        = 1.92 × 10⁻⁴⁷ kg m²

\[
\boxed{1.92}\;10^{-47}\; \text{kg\,m}^{2}
\]

question:
The data below show the temperature variation of the equilibrium constant of the reaction $\mathrm{Ag}_2 \mathrm{CO}_3(\mathrm{~s}) \rightleftharpoons \mathrm{Ag}_2 \mathrm{O}(\mathrm{s})+\mathrm{CO}_2(\mathrm{~g})$. Calculate the standard reaction enthalpy of the decomposition.
$\begin{array}{lllll}T / \mathrm{K} & 350 & 400 & 450 & 500 \\ K & 3.98 \times 10^{-4} & 1.41 \times 10^{-2} & 1.86 \times 10^{-1} & 1.48\end{array}$
llm_answer:
The temperature dependence of an equilibrium constant is given by the van’t Hoff equation  

\[
\frac{d\ln K}{dT}=\frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{RT^{2}}
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
\ln K = -\frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{R}\frac{1}{T}+\frac{\Delta S^{\circ}}{R}
\]

Hence, a plot of \(\ln K\) versus \(1/T\) is linear with slope  

\[
m=\frac{d(\ln K)}{d(1/T)}=-\frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{R}.
\]

1.  Convert the data to \(\ln K\) and \(1/T\):

\[
\begin{array}{ccc}
T\;(\text{K}) & 1/T\;(\text{K}^{-1}) & \ln K \\[2pt]\hline
350 & 2.8571\times10^{-3} & -7.8288\\
400 & 2.5000\times10^{-3} & -4.2612\\
450 & 2.2222\times10^{-3} & -1.6826\\
500 & 2.0000\times10^{-3} & \phantom{-}0.3910
\end{array}
\]

2.  Perform a linear least-squares fit of \(\ln K\) versus \(1/T\) (or use any two points for an approximate value).  
    The regression gives  

\[
m = -9.58\times10^{3}\;\text{K}.
\]

3.  Relate the slope to the enthalpy change:

\[
\Delta H^{\circ} = -m\,R
               = (9.58\times10^{3}\,\text{K})(8.314\;\text{J\,mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})
               = 7.96\times10^{4}\;\text{J\,mol}^{-1}.
\]

4.  Convert to kilojoules per mole:

\[
\Delta H^{\circ} \approx 7.96\times10^{4}\;\text{J\,mol}^{-1}=79.6\;\text{kJ\,mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{79.6}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]
