Solve for nk using λ = 2 :

λ − λ⁻² = 2 − ¼ = 1.75  
nk = (0.02857 MPa K⁻¹) / 1.75 = 0.01633 MPa K⁻¹

Step 2:  Obtain the small-strain Young’s (tensile) modulus at 23 °C

with T = 23 °C = 296 K :

question: Calculate the shear modulus (GPa) of a polymer sample in a torsion pendulum with a period of 1.0 sec. The specimen is 10 cm long, 2 cm wide, and 7.5 mm thick and the moment of inertia is 5000 g¡¤cm?.
llm_answer:
Given a torsion pendulum, the period T is related to the torsional spring constant k by  

  T = 2\pi\sqrt{\dfrac{I}{k}}

For a straight rectangular bar acting as the torsion rod  

  k = \dfrac{GJ}{L}

where  
G = shear modulus (Pa)  
J = torsion constant (m⁴)  
L = gauge length of specimen (m)

Eliminating k,

  T = 2\pi\sqrt{\dfrac{IL}{GJ}}
  \Longrightarrow\; G = \dfrac{4\pi^{2}IL}{JT^{2}}

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Convert the given data to SI units  

 I = 5000 g·cm² = 5000(10⁻³ kg)(10⁻² m)² = 5.0×10⁻⁴ kg·m²  
 L = 10 cm = 0.10 m  
 b = 2 cm = 0.020 m (width)  
 t = 7.5 mm = 0.0075 m (thickness)  
 T = 1.0 s  

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Torsion constant for a rectangular bar  
For t ≤ b the accurate approximation is  

 J = b\,t^{3}\!\left[\frac13 - 0.21\frac{t}{b}\!\left(1-\frac{t^{4}}{12b^{4}}\right)\right]

Compute the terms  

 t/b = 0.0075/0.020 = 0.375  
 t³   = 0.0075³ = 4.21875×10⁻⁷ m³  
 bt³  = 0.020(4.21875×10⁻⁷) = 8.4375×10⁻⁹ m⁴  

Coefficient inside brackets:  

 (1/3) − 0.21(0.375)(1 − t⁴/(12b⁴))  
 = 0.333333 − 0.21(0.375)(0.99835)  
 ≈ 0.333333 − 0.07863 = 0.254703  

Thus  

 J = 8.4375×10⁻⁹(0.254703) ≈ 2.15×10⁻⁹ m⁴

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Insert values into the G–T relation  

 G = \dfrac{4\pi^{2}IL}{JT^{2}}
   = \dfrac{4\pi^{2}(5.0\times10^{-4})(0.10)}{(2.15\times10^{-9})(1.0)^{2}}
   ≈ 9.2×10^{5}\;\text{Pa}

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4. Convert to MPa  

 G = 9.2×10⁵ Pa = 0.92 MPa

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{0.92}\text{ MPa}
\]
llm_output:

  T = 2\pi\sqrt{\dfrac{I}{k}}

For a straight rectangular bar acting as the torsion rod  

  k = \dfrac{GJ}{L}

where  
G = shear modulus (Pa)  
J = torsion constant (m⁴)  
L = gauge length of specimen (m)

 ≈ 0.333333 − 0.07863 = 0.254703

--------------------------------------------------------------------

   = \dfrac{4\pi^{2}(5.0\times10^{-4})(0.10)}{(2.15\times10^{-9})(1.0)^{2}}
   ≈ 9.2×10^{5}\;\text{Pa}

question: Molten polystyrene flows through a circular tube at \(210^\circ\text{C}\) under a pressure drop of 1,000 psi. Given that the inside diameter of the tube is 0.25 in. and that the tube is 3 in. in length, calculate the following: the (nominal) shear stress at the wall in units of \(\text{N m}^{-2}\)
llm_answer:
For laminar, pressure-driven flow in a circular tube the wall shear stress is  

\[
\tau_w = \frac{R}{2}\left(\frac{\Delta P}{L}\right)=\frac{\Delta P\,R}{2L}
\]

1. Convert the data to SI units  
 Pressure drop: \(\Delta P = 1000\ \text{psi}\,(6894.76\ \text{Pa/psi}) = 6.895\times10^{6}\ \text{Pa}\)  
 Diameter: \(D = 0.25\ \text{in}\,(0.0254\ \text{m/in}) = 0.00635\ \text{m}\)  
 Radius: \(R = D/2 = 0.003175\ \text{m}\)  
 Length: \(L = 3\ \text{in}\,(0.0254\ \text{m/in}) = 0.0762\ \text{m}\)

2. Insert the numbers  

\[
\tau_w = \frac{(6.895\times10^{6}\ \text{Pa})(0.003175\ \text{m})}{2(0.0762\ \text{m})}
       = 1.44\times10^{5}\ \text{Pa}
\]

3. Express in the requested form  

\[
\boxed{1.44\times10^{5}}\; \text{Nm}^{-2}
\]
llm_output:

question: An asymmetric hollow fiber of polysulfone has a surface pore area, \( A_3/A_2 \), of \( 1.9 \times 10^{-6} \) and an effective skin thickness of 1000 ?. If the fiber is coated with a \( 1-\mu\text{m} \) layer of silicone rubber, calculate the effective \( P/\ell \) for the coated membrane for \( \text{CO}_2 \) and the permselectivity for \( \text{CO}_2/\text{CH}_4 \).
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Convert thicknesses to centimetres  
 polysulfone skin ℓ₁ = 1000 Å = 1 × 10⁻⁷ m = 1 × 10⁻⁵ cm  
 silicone coating ℓ₂ = 1 µm  = 1 × 10⁻⁶ m = 1 × 10⁻⁴ cm  

Step 2 – Adopt literature permeabilities (Barrer = 10⁻¹⁰ cm³(STP) cm / (cm² s cm Hg))  
  P_PSf(CO₂) = 7 Barrer, P_PSf(CH₄) = 0.4 Barrer  
  P_PDMS(CO₂) = 3.8 × 10³ Barrer, P_PDMS(CH₄) = 6.0 × 10² Barrer  

Step 3 – Resistance of each layer (R = ℓ/P)  
 CO₂ : R₁ = ℓ₁/P_PSf = 1×10⁻⁵/7 = 1.43×10⁻⁶ cm/Barrer  
    R₂ = ℓ₂/P_PDMS = 1×10⁻⁴/3.8×10³ = 2.63×10⁻⁸ cm/Barrer  
    R_tot = 1.46×10⁻⁶ cm/Barrer  

 CH₄ : R₁ = 1×10⁻⁵/0.4 = 2.50×10⁻⁵ cm/Barrer  
    R₂ = 1×10⁻⁴/6.0×10² = 1.67×10⁻⁷ cm/Barrer  
    R_tot = 2.52×10⁻⁵ cm/Barrer  

Step 4 – Serial permeance of the dense region  
 (P/ℓ)serial = 1/R_tot  
  CO₂ : 1/(1.46×10⁻⁶) = 6.87×10⁵ Barrer cm⁻¹ = 68.7 GPU  
  CH₄ : 1/(2.52×10⁻⁵) = 3.97×10⁴ Barrer cm⁻¹ = 3.97 GPU  

Step 5 – Include the pin-hole (pore) area (φ = A₃/A₂ = 1.9×10⁻⁶)  
 Only the silicone layer covers the pores, so their permeance is  
  (P/ℓ)pore(CO₂) = P_PDMS/ℓ₂ = 3.8×10³/1×10⁻⁴ = 3.8×10⁷ Barrer cm⁻¹ = 3.8 × 10³ GPU  
  (P/ℓ)pore(CH₄) = 6.0×10²/1×10⁻⁴ = 6.0×10⁶ Barrer cm⁻¹ = 6.0 × 10² GPU  

 Overall permeance (parallel paths)  
  (P/ℓ)eff = (1 – φ)(P/ℓ)serial + φ(P/ℓ)pore  

 CO₂ : (1 – 1.9×10⁻⁶)(68.7) + (1.9×10⁻⁶)(3.8×10³) = 6.87×10¹ GPU  
 CH₄ : (1 – 1.9×10⁻⁶)(3.97) + (1.9×10⁻⁶)(6.0×10²) = 3.97×10⁰ GPU  

Step 6 – Permselectivity  
 α_CO₂/CH₄ = (P/ℓ)eff(CO₂) / (P/ℓ)eff(CH₄)  
     = 68.7 / 3.97 ≈ 17  

Final result  

\[
\boxed{(P/\ell)_{\text{CO}_{2}} \approx 6.9\times10^{1}\ \text{GPU},\qquad
\alpha_{\text{CO}_{2}/\text{CH}_{4}}\approx 17}
\]
llm_output:
Step 1 – Convert thicknesses to centimetres  
 polysulfone skin ℓ₁ = 1000 Å = 1 × 10⁻⁷ m = 1 × 10⁻⁵ cm  
 silicone coating ℓ₂ = 1 µm  = 1 × 10⁻⁶ m = 1 × 10⁻⁴ cm  

Step 2 – Adopt literature permeabilities (Barrer = 10⁻¹⁰ cm³(STP) cm / (cm² s cm Hg))  
  P_PSf(CO₂) = 7 Barrer, P_PSf(CH₄) = 0.4 Barrer  
  P_PDMS(CO₂) = 3.8 × 10³ Barrer, P_PDMS(CH₄) = 6.0 × 10² Barrer  

Step 3 – Resistance of each layer (R = ℓ/P)  
 CO₂ : R₁ = ℓ₁/P_PSf = 1×10⁻⁵/7 = 1.43×10⁻⁶ cm/Barrer  
    R₂ = ℓ₂/P_PDMS = 1×10⁻⁴/3.8×10³ = 2.63×10⁻⁸ cm/Barrer  
    R_tot = 1.46×10⁻⁶ cm/Barrer  

 CH₄ : R₁ = 1×10⁻⁵/0.4 = 2.50×10⁻⁵ cm/Barrer

    R_tot = 2.52×10⁻⁵ cm/Barrer

  (P/ℓ)pore(CO₂) = P_PDMS/ℓ₂ = 3.8×10³/1×10⁻⁴ = 3.8×10⁷ Barrer cm⁻¹ = 3.8 × 10³ GPU  
  (P/ℓ)pore(CH₄) = 6.0×10²/1×10⁻⁴ = 6.0×10⁶ Barrer cm⁻¹ = 6.0 × 10² GPU  

 Overall permeance (parallel paths)  
  (P/ℓ)eff = (1 – φ)(P/ℓ)serial + φ(P/ℓ)pore  

 CO₂ : (1 – 1.9×10⁻⁶)(68.7) + (1.9×10⁻⁶)(3.8×10³) = 6.87×10¹ GPU  
 CH₄ : (1 – 1.9×10⁻⁶)(3.97) + (1.9×10⁻⁶)(6.0×10²) = 3.97×10⁰ GPU  

Step 6 – Permselectivity  
 α_CO₂/CH₄ = (P/ℓ)eff(CO₂) / (P/ℓ)eff(CH₄)  
     = 68.7 / 3.97 ≈ 17  

Final result  

\[
\boxed{(P/\ell)_{\text{CO}_{2}} \approx 6.9\times10^{1}\ \text{GPU},\qquad
\alpha_{\text{CO}_{2}/\text{CH}_{4}}\approx 17}
\]

question: Styrene is polymerized by free-radical mechanism in solution. The initial monomer and initiator concentrations are 1 \( M \) (molar) and 0.001 \( M \), respectively. At the polymerization temperature of \( 60^\circ\text{C} \), the initiator efficiency is 0.30. The rate constants at the polymerization temperature are as follows:   \[ \begin{align*} k_{\text{d}} &= 1.2 \times 10^{-5} \ \text{s}^{-1} \\ k_{\text{p}} &= 176 \ M^{-1} \text{s}^{-1} \\ k_{\text{t}} &= 7.2 \times 10^7 \ M^{-1} \text{s}^{-1} \\ \end{align*} \]   Given this information, determine the following:   Rate of initiation at 1 min and at 16.6 h

Assume that a polyesterification is conducted in the absence of solvent or catalyst and that the monomers are present in stoichiometric ratios. Calculate the time (min) required to obtain a number-average degree of polymerization of 50 given that the initial dicarboxylic acid concentration is \( 3 \ \text{mol L}^{-1} \) and that the polymerization rate constant is \( 10^{-2} \ \text{L mol}^{-1} \text{s}^{-1} \).
llm_answer:
For an equimolar, uncatalyzed step-growth polyesterification the kinetics are second order in functional groups:

d[A]/dt = -k[A]^2

Let  

[A]₀ = initial concentration of each functional group = 3 mol L⁻¹  
[A]   = concentration at time t  
k     = 1.0 × 10⁻² L mol⁻¹ s⁻¹

1. Relate [A] to the extent of reaction p.

p = ([A]₀ – [A])/[A]₀    and   Xₙ = 1/(1 – p)

Given Xₙ = 50 ⇒  
1 – p = 1/Xₙ = 1/50 = 0.02 ⇒ p = 0.98

Therefore  
[A] = [A]₀(1 – p) = 3 mol L⁻¹ × 0.02 = 0.06 mol L⁻¹

2. Integrate the second-order rate law.

∫[A]₀^[A] d[A]/[A]² = -k ∫₀^t dt  
⇒ 1/[A] – 1/[A]₀ = k t  
⇒ t = (1/k)(1/[A] – 1/[A]₀)

3. Insert the numbers.

1/[A]   = 1/0.06 = 16.6667 L mol⁻¹  
1/[A]₀ = 1/3     = 0.3333 L mol⁻¹  

Δ = 16.6667 – 0.3333 = 16.3333 L mol⁻¹

t = (1/1.0 × 10⁻² L mol⁻¹ s⁻¹) × 16.3333 L mol⁻¹  
  = 100 × 16.3333  
  = 1.63 × 10³ s

\[
\boxed{1.63\times 10^{3}}
\] s
llm_output:

question: Give your best estimate for the weight fraction of plasticizer required to lower the \( T_{\text{g}} \) of poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC) to \( 30^\circ\text{C} \). Assume that the \( T_{\text{g}} \) of PVC is 356 K and that of the plasticizer is 188 K. No other information is available.
llm_answer:
For a miscible binary mixture of a polymer (1) and a plasticizer (2), the glass-transition temperature is often estimated with the Fox equation  

\[
\frac{1}{T_{\text{g, mix}}}= \frac{w_1}{T_{\text{g},1}}+\frac{w_2}{T_{\text{g},2}},
\qquad w_1+w_2=1
\]

where  
Tg,1 = 356 K  (PVC)  
Tg,2 = 188 K  (plasticizer)  
Tg,mix = 30 °C = 303 K

Let  
w1 = weight fraction of PVC  
w2 = weight fraction of plasticizer = 1 − w1.

Insert the values:

\[
\frac{1}{303}= \frac{w_1}{356} + \frac{1-w_1}{188}.
\]

Solve for w1:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{303} &= \frac{w_1}{356} +\frac{1}{188}-\frac{w_1}{188}\\
\frac{1}{303}-\frac{1}{188} &= w_1\!\left(\frac{1}{356}-\frac{1}{188}\right)\\
w_1 &= \frac{\displaystyle\frac{1}{303}-\frac{1}{188}}
           {\displaystyle\frac{1}{356}-\frac{1}{188}}
       \approx 0.804.
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence  

\[
w_2 = 1 - w_1 \approx 1 - 0.804 = 0.196.
\]

Convert to weight percent:

\[
w_2 \times 100\% \approx 19.6\%.
\]

\[
\boxed{19.6}\ \text{wt\%}
\]
llm_output:

\[

\qquad w_1+w_2=1
\]

question: The 1% secant modulus of a polystyrene sample is 3 GPa. What is the nominal stress (MPa) of this sample at a nominal strain of 0.01?
llm_answer:
Given  
Secant modulus at 1 % strain:  
E_s = 3 GPa = 3 × 10⁹ Pa = 3000 MPa  

Nominal strain at which the modulus is defined:  
ε = 0.01  

For a secant modulus,  
E_s = σ / ε  ⇒ σ = E_s ε  

Substitute:  
σ = (3000 MPa)(0.01) = 30 MPa  

\[
\boxed{30}\ \text{MPa}
\]

question: Assume all processes take place at \pu{298 K}. The enthalpy change of formation of \ce{CH4(g)} is \pu{-74.8 kJ mol^{-1}} and of \ce{H2O(l)} is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the standard enthalpy change of combustion of \ce{H2} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Write the balanced combustion reaction for hydrogen (per mole of H₂):

H₂(g) + ½ O₂(g) → H₂O(l)

Step 2 – Apply Hess’s law (heats of formation):

ΔH° = Σ ΔH°f(products) – Σ ΔH°f(reactants)

The standard enthalpies of formation of the elements in their reference states are zero:

ΔH°f[H₂(g)] = 0  
ΔH°f[O₂(g)] = 0

Given value:

ΔH°f[H₂O(l)] = –285.8 kJ mol⁻¹

Step 3 – Insert the numbers:

ΔH°comb(H₂) = (–285.8 kJ mol⁻¹) – [0 + 0]  
ΔH°comb(H₂) = –285.8 kJ mol⁻¹

Thus, the standard enthalpy change of combustion of hydrogen at 298 K is

\[
\boxed{-285.8}
\; \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:

H₂(g) + ½ O₂(g) → H₂O(l)

\]

question: In the reaction \ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}, an initial mixture of \pu{40 mol} of \ce{CO}, \pu{20 mol} of \ce{H2}, and \pu{20 mol} of \ce{CO2} in contact with \pu{40 mol} of steam was allowed to come to equilibrium in a reactor at \pu{1100 K}. At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{H2} leaving the reactor after equilibration?
llm_answer:
Let ξ be the extent of reaction (in moles) for  

CO + H₂O ⇌ CO₂ + H₂.

Initial moles  
CO : 40  H₂O : 40  CO₂ : 20  H₂ : 20

After the reaction reaches equilibrium  

nCO   = 40 − ξ  
nH₂O  = 40 − ξ  
nCO₂  = 20 + ξ  
nH₂   = 20 + ξ

Because one mole of gas is converted to one mole of gas, the total number of moles remains constant:

n_tot = (40 − ξ) + (40 − ξ) + (20 + ξ) + (20 + ξ) = 120

For ideal gases the partial pressure is P_i = y_iP_tot, where y_i = n_i/n_tot.  
With Δn = 0 the total pressure cancels out and

K_p = (P_CO₂ P_H₂)/(P_CO P_H₂O)  
   = (n_CO₂ n_H₂)/(n_CO n_H₂O) = 0.64

Insert the mole expressions:

(20 + ξ)(20 + ξ) / [(40 − ξ)(40 − ξ)] = 0.64

Take the square root:

(20 + ξ)/(40 − ξ) = √0.64 = 0.8

Solve for ξ:

20 + ξ = 0.8(40 − ξ)  
20 + ξ = 32 − 0.8ξ  
1.8ξ = 12  
ξ = 12 / 1.8 = 20/3 ≈ 6.67

Equilibrium moles of H₂:

n_H₂ = 20 + ξ = 20 + 20/3 = 80/3 ≈ 26.7 mol

\[
\boxed{\dfrac{80}{3}}\ \text{mol}
\]
llm_output:
Let ξ be the extent of reaction (in moles) for  

CO + H₂O ⇌ CO₂ + H₂.

Initial moles  
CO : 40  H₂O : 40  CO₂ : 20  H₂ : 20

After the reaction reaches equilibrium  

nCO   = 40 − ξ  
nH₂O  = 40 − ξ  
nCO₂  = 20 + ξ  
nH₂   = 20 + ξ

Because one mole of gas is converted to one mole of gas, the total number of moles remains constant:

n_tot = (40 − ξ) + (40 − ξ) + (20 + ξ) + (20 + ξ) = 120

For ideal gases the partial pressure is P_i = y_iP_tot, where y_i = n_i/n_tot.  
With Δn = 0 the total pressure cancels out and

K_p = (P_CO₂ P_H₂)/(P_CO P_H₂O)  
   = (n_CO₂ n_H₂)/(n_CO n_H₂O) = 0.64

Insert the mole expressions:

(20 + ξ)(20 + ξ) / [(40 − ξ)(40 − ξ)] = 0.64

(20 + ξ)/(40 − ξ) = √0.64 = 0.8

Solve for ξ:

20 + ξ = 0.8(40 − ξ)  
20 + ξ = 32 − 0.8ξ  
1.8ξ = 12  
ξ = 12 / 1.8 = 20/3 ≈ 6.67

Equilibrium moles of H₂:

n_H₂ = 20 + ξ = 20 + 20/3 = 80/3 ≈ 26.7 mol

\[

\]

question: The density of pure water is \pu{1 g cm^{-3}}. What is its concentration in \pu{mol dm^{-3}}?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Convert the density from g cm⁻³ to g dm⁻³  
1 dm³ = 1000 cm³, therefore  

ρ = 1 g cm⁻³ × 1000 cm³ dm⁻³ = 1000 g dm⁻³  

Step 2 – Convert the mass of water in 1 dm³ to moles  
Molar mass H₂O = 18.015 g mol⁻¹  

n = (1000 g) / (18.015 g mol⁻¹) = 55.5 mol  

Step 3 – Express as concentration in mol dm⁻³  
Since these moles are contained in exactly 1 dm³, the concentration equals the number of moles:

c = 55.5 mol dm⁻³

\[
\boxed{55.5}\ \mathrm{mol\ dm^{-3}}
\]

question: Lactic acid has an acid dissociation constant, $K_a$, of \pu{1.38E-4}. What is the pKa of lactic acid?
llm_answer:
To convert an acid-dissociation constant ($K_a$) to its corresponding p$K_a$, use the definition  

\[
\mathrm{p}K_a = -\log_{10}(K_a)
\]

Given  
\[
K_a = 1.38 \times 10^{-4}
\]

1. Express the logarithm as a sum:  
   \[
   \log_{10}(1.38 \times 10^{-4}) = \log_{10}(1.38) + \log_{10}(10^{-4})
   \]

2. Evaluate each term:  
   • \(\log_{10}(1.38) \approx 0.1399\)  
   • \(\log_{10}(10^{-4}) = -4\)

   Therefore,  
   \[
   \log_{10}(1.38 \times 10^{-4}) \approx 0.1399 - 4 = -3.8601
   \]

3. Apply the negative sign to obtain p$K_a$:  
   \[
   \mathrm{p}K_a = -(-3.8601) \approx 3.86
   \]

\[
\boxed{3.86}
\]
llm_output:

\[

\]

\]

   \]

\[
\boxed{3.86}
\]

question: An adult poisoned by a nerve agent requires an hourly dose of \pu{3 mmol} of Pralidoxime (PAM) for every kilogram of body mass. The molar mass of PAM is \pu{172.612 g mol^{-1}}. What is the mass, in grams, of PAM required for an \pu{80 kg} person over a treatment period of \pu{24 h}?
llm_answer:
Hourly amount of Pralidoxime (PAM)
3 mmol kg⁻¹ h⁻¹ × 80 kg = 240 mmol h⁻¹

Total amount for 24 h
240 mmol h⁻¹ × 24 h = 5 760 mmol = 5.76 mol

Mass of PAM needed
5.76 mol × 172.612 g mol⁻¹ = 9.94 × 10² g

\[
\boxed{9.94\times 10^{2}}\;\text{g}
\]

3 mmol kg⁻¹ h⁻¹ × 80 kg = 240 mmol h⁻¹

\]

question: Avogadro's constant is \pu{6.02E23 mol^{-1}}. Gold has only one isotope, which has a relative mass of 197. The density of gold is \pu{19.3 g cm-3}. What is the mass (in \pu{g}) of one gold atom?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – mass of one mole of Au  
The relative atomic mass of gold is 197, so

m(1 mol Au)=197 g

Step 2 – number of atoms in one mole  
By definition, 1 mol contains NA=6.02 E 23 atoms.

Step 3 – mass of one atom  

m(1 atom)=
\[

      =\frac{197}{6.02}\times10^{-23}\ \text{g}
      \approx3.27\times10^{-22}\ \text{g}
\]

Expressed in “E” (scientific-notation) form:

m(1 atom)=3.27 E –22 g

\[
\boxed{3.27E-22}\ \text{E}
\]

question: The energy released when \pu{1 L} of the E10 fuel is burnt is \pu{30680 kJ} and the energy released when \pu{1 L} of the E5 fuel is burnt is \pu{31170 kJ}. Taking the energy released from burning \pu{1 L} of E5 as \pu{100 %}, what is the percentage of the energy released from burning \pu{1 L} of E10 fuel?
llm_answer:
First express the energy delivered by 1 L of E10 as a fraction of that delivered by 1 L of E5 and convert the fraction to percent.

Fraction = (energy per litre, E10) / (energy per litre, E5)  
       = 30680 kJ / 31170 kJ

Percentage = Fraction × 100 %  
      = (30680 kJ / 31170 kJ) × 100 %  
      ≈ 0.9843 × 100 %  
      ≈ 98.4 %

\[
\boxed{98.4}\,\%
\]

question: What is the oxidation number of hydrogen in the reactants of Sabatier reaction?
llm_answer:
Step 1:  Write the balanced Sabatier reaction  
CO₂ + 4 H₂ → CH₄ + 2 H₂O

Step 2:  Locate hydrogen in the reactants  
The only source of hydrogen on the reactant side is molecular hydrogen, H₂.

Step 3:  Assign the oxidation number to hydrogen in H₂  
For any element in its free (uncombined) elemental form—including diatomic molecules such as H₂—the oxidation number is defined as 0.

Therefore, the oxidation number of hydrogen in the reactants of the Sabatier reaction is  

\[
\boxed{0}
\]

question: The mass of one gold atom is \pu{3.27E-22 g} and the density of gold is \pu{19.3 g cm^{-3}}. What is the molar volume of gold in \pu{cm^{3} mol^{-1}}?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Determine the molar mass of gold  
Mass of one atom: m₁ = 3.27 × 10⁻²² g  
Avogadro’s number: N_A = 6.022 × 10²³ mol⁻¹  

Molar mass  
M = m₁ × N_A  
 = (3.27 × 10⁻²² g)(6.022 × 10²³ mol⁻¹)  
 = (3.27 × 6.022) × 10⁻²²+²³ g mol⁻¹  
 = 19.69194 × 10¹ g mol⁻¹  
 ≈ 1.969 × 10² g mol⁻¹  
 ≈ 196.9 g mol⁻¹

Step 2 – Compute the molar volume  
Density of gold: ρ = 19.3 g cm⁻³  

Molar volume  
V_m = M/ρ  
 = 196.9 g mol⁻¹  / 19.3 g cm⁻³  
 ≈ 10.2 cm³ mol⁻¹

\[
\boxed{10.2}
\] cm³ mol⁻¹

question: The standard enthalpy change of the reaction \ce{NaOH + HCl -> NaCl + H2O} is \pu{-56.7 kJ mol^{-1}}, the standard enthalpy change of the reaction \ce{SiO2 + 6HF -> H2SiF6 + 2H2O} is \pu{-100.3 kJ mol^{-1}} and the standard enthalpy change of the reaction \ce{NaOH + HF -> H2O + NaF} is \pu{-61.5 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the standard enthalpy change of the reaction \ce{SiO2 + 6NaF + 6HCl -> H2SiF6 + 6NaCl + 2H2O} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
llm_answer:
Given data  

1. NaOH + HCl → NaCl + H₂O           ΔH₁° = –56.7 kJ  
2. SiO₂ + 6 HF → H₂SiF₆ + 2 H₂O       ΔH₂° = –100.3 kJ  
3. NaOH + HF → H₂O + NaF          ΔH₃° = –61.5 kJ  

Step 1 – invert and scale reaction 3 to obtain 6 NaF on the reactant side:  
NaF + H₂O → NaOH + HF          ΔH = +61.5 kJ  
6 NaF + 6 H₂O → 6 NaOH + 6 HF      ΔH = +6 × 61.5 = +369.0 kJ  

Step 2 – scale reaction 1 by 6 to cancel NaOH:  
6 NaOH + 6 HCl → 6 NaCl + 6 H₂O    ΔH = 6 × (–56.7) = –340.2 kJ  

Add the two results:  
6 NaF + 6 HCl → 6 NaCl + 6 HF      ΔH = +369.0 kJ – 340.2 kJ = +28.8 kJ  

Step 3 – add reaction 2; the 6 HF cancel:  
SiO₂ + 6 HF → H₂SiF₆ + 2 H₂O      ΔH = –100.3 kJ  

Overall sum:  
SiO₂ + 6 NaF + 6 HCl → H₂SiF₆ + 6 NaCl + 2 H₂O  

Net enthalpy change:  
ΔH° = +28.8 kJ + (–100.3 kJ) = –71.5 kJ  

\[
\boxed{-71.5}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:

3. NaOH + HF → H₂O + NaF          ΔH₃° = –61.5 kJ  

Step 1 – invert and scale reaction 3 to obtain 6 NaF on the reactant side:  
NaF + H₂O → NaOH + HF          ΔH = +61.5 kJ

\]

question: At \pu{25 deg C}, the partial pressure of \ce{CO2} gas in a \pu{250 cm^{3}} fizzy drink can is \pu{3 atm}. The Henry's law constant for \ce{CO2} is \pu{0.033 mol dm^{-3} atm^{-1}}. The can contains only \pu{1.09 g} of \ce{CO2} as a gas. What is the pressure in the can at \pu{25 deg C} in \pu{kPa}?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Amount of carbon dioxide  
Molar mass of CO₂ : M = 44.0 g mol⁻¹  

n = m/M = 1.09 g / 44.0 g mol⁻¹ = 2.48 × 10⁻² mol

Step 2 – Concentration of CO₂ in the drink (volume of the can = 250 cm³ = 0.250 dm³)  

c = n / V = 2.48 × 10⁻² mol / 0.250 dm³ = 9.91 × 10⁻² mol dm⁻³

Step 3 – Pressure from Henry’s law  

c = k_H P  ⇒  P = c / k_H  
P = (9.91 × 10⁻² mol dm⁻³) / (0.033 mol dm⁻³ atm⁻¹) = 3.0 atm

Step 4 – Convert to kilopascals  

P = 3.0 atm × 101.325 kPa atm⁻¹ = 3.04 × 10² kPa

\[
\boxed{3.0 \times 10^{2}} \text{ kPa}
\]
llm_output:

Molar mass of CO₂ : M = 44.0 g mol⁻¹

Step 4 – Convert to kilopascals  

P = 3.0 atm × 101.325 kPa atm⁻¹ = 3.04 × 10² kPa

\[
\boxed{3.0 \times 10^{2}} \text{ kPa}
\]

question: The molar volume of gold is \pu{10.2 cm^{3} mol^{-1}}. The gold atoms occupy 74 % of the volume of the cubic unit cell. What is the radius of the gold atom in \pu{\A}?
llm_answer:
The fcc unit cell of gold contains  

n = 4 atoms  

and the packing efficiency is  

η = 0.74 = (volume occupied by the 4 atoms)/(volume of the cell).

Step 1 – volume of one unit cell  
Molar volume V_m = 10.2 cm³ mol⁻¹  

Volume per atom v_atom = V_m / N_A  

Volume per cell V_cell = n v_atom = 4 V_m / N_A

 V_cell = 4·10.2 cm³ mol⁻¹ / 6.022 × 10²³ mol⁻¹  
 V_cell = 6.776 × 10⁻²³ cm³  
     = 6.776 × 10⁻²³ cm³ × 10²⁴ Å³ cm⁻³  
 V_cell = 67.76 Å³

Step 2 – volume occupied by the 4 atoms in the cell  
V_atoms = η V_cell = 0.74 × 67.76 Å³ = 50.14 Å³

Step 3 – atomic radius  
Each atom is assumed spherical: V_atoms = 4 × (4/3)πr³ = (16/3)πr³  

r³ = V_atoms × (3 / (16π))  
  = 50.14 Å³ × (3 / (16π))  
  = 2.99 Å³  

r = (2.99 Å³)^{1/3} ≈ 1.44 Å

Final result  

\[
\boxed{1.44}\,\text{\AA}
\]

\[
\boxed{1.44}\,\text{\AA}
\]

question: The enthalpy of combustion of ethanol is \pu{-1276 kJ mol^{-1}} and the enthalpy of combustion of an isomer of octane is \pu{-5144 kJ mol^{-1}}. Assume that \pu{1 L} of E10 fuel contains \pu{100 mL} of ethanol and \pu{900 mL} of octane isomers. The density of pure ethanol is \pu{0.789 g cm^{-3}} and the density of pure octane isomers is \pu{0.703 g cm^{-3}}. What is the energy, in \pu{kJ}, released when \pu{1 L} of the E10 fuel is burnt?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – convert the given volumes to masses  
(1 mL = 1 cm³)

Ethanol:  
m = ρV = (0.789 g cm⁻³)(100 cm³) = 78.9 g

Octane isomer:  
m = ρV = (0.703 g cm⁻³)(900 cm³) = 632.7 g


Step 2 – convert the masses to moles  

Molar masses: M(C₂H₅OH)=46.07 g mol⁻¹,  M(C₈H₁₈)=114.23 g mol⁻¹

n(C₂H₅OH)=78.9 g / 46.07 g mol⁻¹ = 1.713 mol  
n(C₈H₁₈)=632.7 g / 114.23 g mol⁻¹ = 5.540 mol


Step 3 – calculate the heat released by each component  

ΔH_c(C₂H₅OH)= –1276 kJ mol⁻¹  
ΔH_c(C₈H₁₈)= –5144 kJ mol⁻¹

q_ethanol = (1.713 mol)(1276 kJ mol⁻¹)= 2.19 ×10³ kJ  
q_octane  = (5.540 mol)(5144 kJ mol⁻¹)= 2.85 ×10⁴ kJ


Step 4 – total heat released by burning 1 L of E10  

q_total = q_ethanol + q_octane  
q_total = 2.19 ×10³ kJ + 2.85 ×10⁴ kJ ≈ 3.07 ×10⁴ kJ


Final result  

\[
\boxed{3.07\times10^{4}}\ \text{kJ}
\]
llm_output:
Step 1 – convert the given volumes to masses  
(1 mL = 1 cm³)

Ethanol:  
m = ρV = (0.789 g cm⁻³)(100 cm³) = 78.9 g

Octane isomer:  
m = ρV = (0.703 g cm⁻³)(900 cm³) = 632.7 g


Step 2 – convert the masses to moles

n(C₂H₅OH)=78.9 g / 46.07 g mol⁻¹ = 1.713 mol

\]

question: A plastic was degraded, resulting in a sample of mass \pu{1.044 g}, and titrations were used to determine the composition of this sample. The sample was dissolved in \pu{100 cm^{3}} of water to make a stock solution. \pu{19.40 cm^{3}} of \pu{0.100 mol dm^{-3}} NaOH solution was needed to neutralize \pu{20.00 cm^{3}} of this stock solution. What is the amount of acid in the sample (in moles)?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Moles of NaOH used in the titration  
Volume of NaOH = 19.40 cm³ = 0.01940 dm³  
Concentration of NaOH = 0.100 mol dm⁻³  

n(NaOH) = C × V = 0.100 mol dm⁻³ × 0.01940 dm³ = 1.94 × 10⁻³ mol

Step 2 – Moles of acid in the 20.00 cm³ aliquot  
Assuming a monoprotic acid, the reaction ratio with NaOH is 1 : 1, so

n(acid in aliquot) = n(NaOH) = 1.94 × 10⁻³ mol

Step 3 – Scale up to the whole 100 cm³ stock solution  
The aliquot represents 20.00 cm³ out of 100 cm³, i.e. one-fifth of the stock.

n(acid in full stock) = 1.94 × 10⁻³ mol × (100 cm³ / 20.00 cm³)  
                       = 1.94 × 10⁻³ mol × 5  
                       = 9.70 × 10⁻³ mol

Therefore, the amount of acid originally present in the degraded plastic sample is

\[
\boxed{9.70 \times 10^{-3}}
\] mol
llm_output:
Step 1 – Moles of NaOH used in the titration  
Volume of NaOH = 19.40 cm³ = 0.01940 dm³  
Concentration of NaOH = 0.100 mol dm⁻³  

n(NaOH) = C × V = 0.100 mol dm⁻³ × 0.01940 dm³ = 1.94 × 10⁻³ mol

                       = 9.70 × 10⁻³ mol

Therefore, the amount of acid originally present in the degraded plastic sample is

\[
\boxed{9.70 \times 10^{-3}}
\] mol

question: \pu{286000 tonnes} of polylactic acid (PLA) are manufactured each year. What is the mass of NaOH, in tonnes, needed to completely degrade all the PLA manufactured in one year to sodium lactate, assume the PLA is pure and ignoring the contribution from any end groups?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Reaction stoichiometry  
A saponification (alkaline hydrolysis) of one PLA repeat unit occurs as  

C₃H₄O₂  +  NaOH  ⟶  C₃H₅O₃Na  

Hence 1 mol of NaOH is required per 1 mol of PLA repeat unit.

Step 2 – Molar masses  
PLA repeat unit (C₃H₄O₂):  
M = 3(12.01) + 4(1.01) + 2(16.00) ≈ 72 g mol⁻¹  

NaOH:  
M = 22.99 + 15.999 + 1.008 ≈ 40 g mol⁻¹  

Step 3 – Moles of PLA produced in one year  
Mass of PLA: 286 000 tonnes = 286 000 × 10⁶ g = 2.86 × 10¹¹ g  

n(PLA) = 2.86 × 10¹¹ g / 72 g mol⁻¹ ≈ 3.97 × 10⁹ mol  

Step 4 – Mass of NaOH required  
Because the molar ratio is 1 : 1, the same number of moles of NaOH is needed:

m(NaOH) = n × M(NaOH)  
          = 3.97 × 10⁹ mol × 40 g mol⁻¹  
          ≈ 1.59 × 10¹¹ g  

Convert to tonnes:  
1.59 × 10¹¹ g ÷ 10⁶ g t⁻¹ ≈ 1.59 × 10⁵ t  

Step 5 – Result (to two significant figures)

\[
\boxed{1.6 \times 10^{5}}
\] tonnes
llm_output:
Step 1 – Reaction stoichiometry  
A saponification (alkaline hydrolysis) of one PLA repeat unit occurs as  

C₃H₄O₂  +  NaOH  ⟶  C₃H₅O₃Na  

Hence 1 mol of NaOH is required per 1 mol of PLA repeat unit.

Step 2 – Molar masses

NaOH:

          ≈ 1.59 × 10¹¹ g  

Convert to tonnes:

Step 5 – Result (to two significant figures)

\[
\boxed{1.6 \times 10^{5}}
\] tonnes

question: There are \pu{7.1E6} virus particles per \pu{cm^{3}} in the test solution. Each virus particle has approximately 20 spike proteins on its surface. What is the concentration of spike proteins, [SP], in the test sample in \pu{mol dm^{-3}}?
llm_answer:
Number of spike proteins per cm³  
\(7.1\times10^{6}\,\text{virus cm}^{-3}\times 20\,\text{SP virus}^{-1}=1.42\times10^{8}\,\text{SP cm}^{-3}\)

Convert to per dm³ (1 dm³ = 1000 cm³)  
\(1.42\times10^{8}\,\text{SP cm}^{-3}\times1000=1.42\times10^{11}\,\text{SP dm}^{-3}\)

Convert particles to moles (Avogadro’s number \(N_A=6.022\times10^{23}\,\text{mol}^{-1}\))  
\[
[{\rm SP}]
=\frac{1.42\times10^{11}}{6.022\times10^{23}}
=2.36\times10^{-13}
\]

\[
\boxed{2.36\times10^{-13}}\ \text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]

question: In the reaction \ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}, an initial mixture of \pu{40 mol} of \ce{CO}, \pu{20 mol} of \ce{H2}, and \pu{20 mol} of \ce{CO2} in contact with \pu{40 mol} of steam was allowed to come to equilibrium in a reactor at \pu{1100 K}. At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{H2O} leaving the reactor after equilibration?
llm_answer:
Let  

CO + H₂O ⇄ CO₂ + H₂ , ξ = extent of reaction (mol)

Initial moles  
n₀(CO)=40 n₀(H₂O)=40 n₀(CO₂)=20 n₀(H₂)=20  

At equilibrium  
n(CO)=40−ξ  
n(H₂O)=40−ξ  
n(CO₂)=20+ξ  
n(H₂)=20+ξ  

Because Δn = 0, the total pressure cancels in Kp:

K_p = (P_{CO₂} P_{H₂}) /(P_{CO} P_{H₂O})
     = (y_{CO₂} y_{H₂}) /(y_{CO} y_{H₂O})
     = (n_{CO₂} n_{H₂}) /(n_{CO} n_{H₂O})

Hence at 1100 K:

(n_{CO₂} n_{H₂}) /(n_{CO} n_{H₂O}) = 0.64

Substitute the equilibrium mole numbers:

(20+ξ)(20+ξ) / (40−ξ)(40−ξ) = 0.64  
∴ (20+ξ)/(40−ξ) = √0.64 = 0.8  
20 + ξ = 0.8(40 − ξ)  
20 + ξ = 32 − 0.8ξ  
1.8ξ = 12 ⇒ ξ = 12/1.8 = 20/3 mol

Moles of water after equilibration:

n(H₂O) = 40 − ξ = 40 − 20/3 = 100/3 mol ≈ 33.3 mol

\boxed{\dfrac{100}{3}} mol
llm_output:

CO + H₂O ⇄ CO₂ + H₂ , ξ = extent of reaction (mol)

Initial moles  
n₀(CO)=40 n₀(H₂O)=40 n₀(CO₂)=20 n₀(H₂)=20  

At equilibrium  
n(CO)=40−ξ  
n(H₂O)=40−ξ  
n(CO₂)=20+ξ  
n(H₂)=20+ξ  

Because Δn = 0, the total pressure cancels in Kp:

K_p = (P_{CO₂} P_{H₂}) /(P_{CO} P_{H₂O})
     = (y_{CO₂} y_{H₂}) /(y_{CO} y_{H₂O})
     = (n_{CO₂} n_{H₂}) /(n_{CO} n_{H₂O})

Hence at 1100 K:

(n_{CO₂} n_{H₂}) /(n_{CO} n_{H₂O}) = 0.64

Substitute the equilibrium mole numbers:

(20+ξ)(20+ξ) / (40−ξ)(40−ξ) = 0.64  
∴ (20+ξ)/(40−ξ) = √0.64 = 0.8  
20 + ξ = 0.8(40 − ξ)  
20 + ξ = 32 − 0.8ξ  
1.8ξ = 12 ⇒ ξ = 12/1.8 = 20/3 mol

Moles of water after equilibration:

n(H₂O) = 40 − ξ = 40 − 20/3 = 100/3 mol ≈ 33.3 mol

\boxed{\dfrac{100}{3}} mol

question: The enthalpy change of vaporization of methane is \pu{8.2 kJ mol^{-1}} and the enthalpy change of vaporization of oxygen is \pu{6.8 kJ mol^{-1}}. The enthalpy change of combustion of methane, \ce{CH4(g) + 2O2(g) -> CO2(g) + 2H2O(g)}, is \pu{-890.8 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the enthalpy change of reaction, in \pu{kJ}, when one mole of liquid methane reacts with liquid oxygen to form gaseous carbon dioxide and gaseous water?
llm_answer:
Step 1:  Relate the desired reaction to the tabulated combustion reaction.

Tabulated combustion reaction (all gases)  
CH₄(g) + 2 O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2 H₂O(g)  ΔH° = −890.8 kJ mol⁻¹

Desired reaction (liquid reactants)  
CH₄(l) + 2 O₂(l) → CO₂(g) + 2 H₂O(g)  ΔH° = ?

Step 2:  Express the desired reaction as a Hess cycle.

CH₄(l) + 2 O₂(l)
  ⟶ (CH₄(g) + 2 O₂(g))         ΔH₁ = ΔHvap(CH₄) + 2 ΔHvap(O₂)
  ⟶ CO₂(g) + 2 H₂O(g)         ΔH₂ = −890.8 kJ

Step 3:  Insert the vaporization enthalpies.

ΔH₁ = +8.2 kJ mol⁻¹ + 2 (+6.8 kJ mol⁻¹)  
   = +8.2 kJ + 13.6 kJ  
   = +21.8 kJ

Step 4:  Sum the steps to obtain the desired enthalpy change.

ΔH°(desired) = ΔH₁ + ΔH₂  
       = (+21.8 kJ) + (−890.8 kJ)  
       = −869.0 kJ

Step 5:  Report the result.

\[
\boxed{-8.69\times10^{2}} \text{ kJ}
\]
llm_output:

       = −869.0 kJ

Step 5:  Report the result.

\[

\]

question: A small snack bag typically weighs \pu{22 g}. The entire content of this bag was crushed and dissolved in distilled water, resulting in a solution. This solution was then adjusted to a volume of \pu{250 cm^{3}} in a volumetric flask. A \pu{25.0 cm^{3}} portion of this solution underwent titration with \pu{0.1 mol dm^{-3}} aqueous silver nitrate(V), applying potassium chromate(VI) as the indicator. To reach the red-brown endpoint, \pu{8.20 cm^{3}} of the aqueous silver nitrate(V) solution was required. What is the mass of sodium chloride in a small snack bag in grams?
llm_answer:
Step 1  – Calculate moles of AgNO₃ used in the titration  
V(AgNO₃) = 8.20 cm³ = 8.20 × 10⁻³ dm³  
C(AgNO₃) = 0.100 mol dm⁻³  

n(AgNO₃) = C × V  
  = 0.100 mol dm⁻³ × 8.20 × 10⁻³ dm³  
  = 8.20 × 10⁻⁴ mol  

Step 2  – Moles of NaCl in the 25.0 cm³ aliquot

M(NaCl) = 58.44 g mol⁻¹  

m(NaCl) = n × M

  = 0.479 g (to three significant figures)  

\boxed{0.479} g

llm_answer:

question: What is the bond enthalpy of the \ce{O=O} bond in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}, given that the bond enthalpy of the \ce{H-H} bond is \pu{432 kJ mol^{-1}}, the average bond enthalpy of \ce{O-H} is \pu{460 kJ mol^{-1}}, and the enthalpy change for the reaction \ce{H2 + 0.5 O2 -> H2O} is \pu{-241 kJ} per mole of hydrogen gas?
llm_answer:
For the reaction  
\[
\ce{H2 + \tfrac12 O2 -> H2O(g)}
\]  
apply the bond-enthalpy relation  

\[
\Delta H_{\text{rxn}}
= \bigl[\text{energy to break bonds in reactants}\bigr]
- \bigl[\text{energy released on forming bonds in products}\bigr].
\]

1. Bonds broken  
   • one \(\ce{H–H}\): \(D_{\ce{H–H}} = 432\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\)  
   • half an \(\ce{O=O}\): \(\tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}}\)

   Total energy in = \(432 + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}}\).

2. Bonds formed  
   • two \(\ce{O–H}\): \(2 D_{\ce{O–H}} = 2(460) = 920\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\).

3. Insert the given reaction enthalpy  
   \[
   -241 = \bigl(432 + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}}\bigr) - 920.
   \]

4. Solve for \(D_{\ce{O=O}}\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
-241 &= 432 - 920 + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}} \\
-241 &= -488 + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}} \\
247 &= \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}} \\
D_{\ce{O=O}} &= 2(247) = 494.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{494}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:
For the reaction  
\[
\ce{H2 + \tfrac12 O2 -> H2O(g)}
\]  
apply the bond-enthalpy relation  

\[
\Delta H_{\text{rxn}}
= \bigl[\text{energy to break bonds in reactants}\bigr]
- \bigl[\text{energy released on forming bonds in products}\bigr].
\]

1. Bonds broken  
   • one \(\ce{H–H}\): \(D_{\ce{H–H}} = 432\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\)  
   • half an \(\ce{O=O}\): \(\tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}}\)

   Total energy in = \(432 + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}}\).

2. Bonds formed  
   • two \(\ce{O–H}\): \(2 D_{\ce{O–H}} = 2(460) = 920\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\).

3. Insert the given reaction enthalpy  
   \[
   -241 = \bigl(432 + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}}\bigr) - 920.
   \]

4. Solve for \(D_{\ce{O=O}}\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
-241 &= 432 - 920 + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}} \\
-241 &= -488 + \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}} \\
247 &= \tfrac12 D_{\ce{O=O}} \\
D_{\ce{O=O}} &= 2(247) = 494.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{494}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

question: What is the oxidation number of carbon in the reactants of Sabatier reaction?
llm_answer:
Step 1 : Write the Sabatier reaction  
\[
\mathrm{CO_2 + 4\,H_2 \;\longrightarrow\; CH_4 + 2\,H_2O}
\]

Step 2 : Identify where carbon is located in the reactants  
Carbon appears only in carbon dioxide, CO₂.

Step 3 : Assign oxidation numbers in CO₂  
• Oxygen almost always has an oxidation number of –2.  
• There are two oxygens, so their total contribution is \(2 \times (-2) = -4\).  
• The molecule is neutral, so the sum of oxidation numbers equals 0.

Let \(x\) be the oxidation number of carbon:
\[
x + (-4) = 0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad x = +4
\]

Therefore, the oxidation number of carbon in the reactants of the Sabatier reaction is

\[
\boxed{+4}
\]

\]

\]

\[
\boxed{+4}
\]

question: The standard enthalpy change of formation at \pu{298 K} is \pu{-393.5 kJ mol^{-1}} for \ce{CO2}, \pu{-424.8 kJ mol^{-1}} for \ce{KOH}, \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}} for \ce{H2O} and \pu{-1151.2 kJ mol^{-1}} for \ce{K2CO3}. What is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction \ce{CO2 + 2KOH -> H2O + K2CO3} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Write the balanced reaction  
CO₂ (g) + 2 KOH (s) → H₂O (l) + K₂CO₃ (s)

Step 2 – List the standard enthalpies of formation, ΔH°f (kJ mol⁻¹)  
CO₂ (g) = −393.5  
KOH (s) = −424.8  
H₂O (l) = −285.8  
K₂CO₃ (s) = −1151.2

Step 3 – Sum the ΔH°f of the products  
ΔH°f(products) = (1)(−285.8) + (1)(−1151.2) = −1437.0 kJ

Step 4 – Sum the ΔH°f of the reactants  
ΔH°f(reactants) = (1)(−393.5) + (2)(−424.8) = −393.5 − 849.6 = −1243.1 kJ

Step 5 – Calculate the reaction enthalpy  
ΔH°rxn = ΔH°f(products) − ΔH°f(reactants)  
ΔH°rxn = (−1437.0) − (−1243.1) = −193.9 kJ

Step 6 – Express the answer (three significant figures)  

\[
\boxed{-1.94\times 10^{2}}
\] kJ mol⁻¹
llm_output:

Step 2 – List the standard enthalpies of formation, ΔH°f (kJ mol⁻¹)

\[

\] kJ mol⁻¹

question: The density of liquid hydrogen is \pu{0.071 g cm^{-3}}. Assume the enthalpy change for the reaction \ce{H2 + 0.5 O2 -> H2O} is \pu{-241 kJ} per mole of hydrogen gas. What is the energy released, in \pu{kJ}, when the gas formed from \pu{1 dm^{3}} of liquid hydrogen is combusted?
llm_answer:
Step 1: Convert the volume of liquid hydrogen to a mass.  
1 dm³ = 1000 cm³  

mass = density × volume  
= 0.071 g cm⁻³ × 1000 cm³  
= 71 g  

Step 2: Convert the mass of H₂ to moles.  
Molar mass of H₂ = 2.016 g mol⁻¹  

n(H₂) = 71 g / 2.016 g mol⁻¹ ≈ 35.2 mol  

Step 3: Use the enthalpy of combustion (ΔH = –241 kJ mol⁻¹) to find the energy released.  
|q| = n × |ΔH|  
= 35.2 mol × 241 kJ mol⁻¹  
≈ 8.5 × 10³ kJ  

\[
\boxed{8.5\times10^{3}}\ \text{kJ}
\]

\]

question: What is the oxidation state of phosphorus in phosphine?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Assign oxidation numbers of known elements  
In molecular compounds, hydrogen is normally assigned an oxidation state of +1.

Step 2 – Write the algebraic sum of oxidation numbers for the neutral molecule PH₃  
Let the oxidation state of phosphorus be x.  
x + 3(+1) = 0

Step 3 – Solve for x  
x + 3 = 0  
x = −3

Hence, the oxidation state of phosphorus in phosphine (PH₃) is

\[
\boxed{-3}
\]

x + 3 = 0

\boxed{-3}

question: If ten tonnes of Ambrox (\ce{C16H28O}) are produced every year, what is the number of moles produced per year?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Molar mass of Ambrox  
M = 16(12.01 g mol⁻¹) + 28(1.008 g mol⁻¹) + 1(16.00 g mol⁻¹)  
M ≈ 192.16 + 28.22 + 16.00 ≈ 236.4 g mol⁻¹

Step 2 – Convert annual production to grams  
10 t = 10 × 10³ kg = 10 × 10³ × 10³ g = 1.0 × 10⁷ g

Step 3 – Calculate the amount (n) of substance  
n = mass / molar mass  
n = (1.0 × 10⁷ g) / (236.4 g mol⁻¹) ≈ 4.2 × 10⁴ mol

\[
\boxed{4.2\times10^{4}} \text{ mol yr}^{-1}
\]

question: Assume all processes take place at \pu{298 K}. The enthalpy change of formation of \ce{CH4(g)} is \pu{-74.8 kJ mol^{-1}}, of \ce{CO2(g)} is \pu{-393.5 kJ mol^{-1}} and it is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}} for \ce{H2O(l)}. What is the enthalpy change for the reaction \ce{CH4(g) + 2H2O(l) -> CO2(g) + 4H2(g)} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
llm_answer:
The standard reaction enthalpy is obtained from the standard molar enthalpies of formation  

ΔᵣH° = Σ ν ΔfH°(products) − Σ ν ΔfH°(reactants)

Products  
CO₂(g): 1 mol  ΔfH° = −393.5 kJ mol⁻¹  
H₂(g): 4 mol  ΔfH° = 0 (element in its standard state)  

Σ ν ΔfH°(products) = (1)(−393.5) + (4)(0) = −393.5 kJ  

Reactants  
CH₄(g): 1 mol  ΔfH° = −74.8 kJ mol⁻¹  
H₂O(l): 2 mol  ΔfH° = −285.8 kJ mol⁻¹  

Σ ν ΔfH°(reactants) = (1)(−74.8) + (2)(−285.8)  
          = −74.8 − 571.6 = −646.4 kJ  

Reaction enthalpy  
ΔᵣH° = (−393.5) − (−646.4) = 252.9 kJ  

\boxed{252.9}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}

m \approx 1.1\ \text{g}

question: The average bond enthalpy of \ce{C-C} is \pu{347 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{C-H} is \pu{413 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{O=O} is \pu{498 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{C-O} is \pu{358 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{C=O} is \pu{805 kJ mol^{-1}} and \ce{O-H} is \pu{464 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the enthalpy of combustion of an isomer of octane in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
llm_answer:
Step 1 :  Write the balanced combustion equation for any isomer of octane (C₈H₁₈).

C₈H₁₈  +  12.5 O₂  ⟶  8 CO₂  +  9 H₂O

Step 2 :  List the bonds broken and formed.

Bonds broken  
• in C₈H₁₈ : 7 C–C  and 18 C–H  
• in O₂   : 12.5 O=O  

Bonds formed  
• in CO₂  : 16 C=O  
• in H₂O  : 18 O–H  

(The number of C–C bonds equals n – 1 = 7 for any C₈ isomer; the number of C–H bonds equals the 18 hydrogens.)

Step 3 :  Insert the given average bond enthalpies (kJ mol⁻¹).

C–C 347   C–H 413   O=O 498  
C–O 358   C=O 805   O–H 464  

Step 4 :  Calculate the energy of bonds broken.

7 C–C : 7 × 347  =  2 429 kJ  
18 C–H : 18 × 413 =  7 434 kJ  
12.5 O=O: 12.5 × 498 =  6 225 kJ  

Σ (bonds broken) = 2 429 + 7 434 + 6 225 = 16 088 kJ

Step 5 :  Calculate the energy of bonds formed.

16 C=O : 16 × 805 = 12 880 kJ  
18 O–H : 18 × 464 =  8 352 kJ  

Σ (bonds formed) = 12 880 + 8 352 = 21 232 kJ

Step 6 :  Enthalpy change of combustion.

ΔH_comb = Σ (bonds broken) – Σ (bonds formed)  
ΔH_comb = 16 088 kJ – 21 232 kJ = –5 144 kJ

\[
\boxed{-5.14\times 10^{3}}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]
llm_output:

Bonds broken

• in O₂   : 12.5 O=O  

Bonds formed

Step 6 :  Enthalpy change of combustion.

ΔH_comb = Σ (bonds broken) – Σ (bonds formed)  
ΔH_comb = 16 088 kJ – 21 232 kJ = –5 144 kJ

\]

question: In the reaction \ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}, an initial mixture of \pu{40 mol} of \ce{CO}, \pu{20 mol} of \ce{H2}, and \pu{20 mol} of \ce{CO2} in contact with \pu{40 mol} of steam was allowed to come to equilibrium in a reactor at \pu{1100 K}. At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{CO} leaving the reactor after equilibration?
llm_answer:
Let  

CO + H₂O ⇌ CO₂ + H₂  

ξ = extent of reaction (mol, positive in the forward direction).

1. Moles at equilibrium  

 n_CO   = 40 – ξ  
 n_H₂O = 40 – ξ  
 n_CO₂ = 20 + ξ  
 n_H₂   = 20 + ξ  

2. Total moles  

 Δn = 0 for the reaction, so n_total = 40 + 40 + 20 + 20 = 120 mol (independent of ξ).

3. Expression for K_p (ideal gas)  

Because Δn = 0, the total pressure cancels:  
 K_p = (y_CO₂ y_H₂)/(y_CO y_H₂O) = (n_CO₂ n_H₂)/(n_CO n_H₂O)

Insert the equilibrium mole numbers and K_p = 0.64:  

 0.64 = (20 + ξ)²/(40 – ξ)²  

4. Solve for ξ  

 √0.64 = (20 + ξ)/(40 – ξ)  
 0.8(40 – ξ) = 20 + ξ  
 32 – 0.8ξ = 20 + ξ  
 1.8ξ = 12  
 ξ = 6.67 mol

5. Moles of CO leaving the reactor  

 n_CO = 40 – ξ = 40 – 6.67 = 33.3 mol

\[
\boxed{33.3}\ \text{mol}
\]
llm_output:

CO + H₂O ⇌ CO₂ + H₂

1. Moles at equilibrium  

 n_CO   = 40 – ξ

 n_CO₂ = 20 + ξ

question: An impure sample of calcium carbide of mass \pu{0.752 g} was added to \pu{50 cm^{3}} of water. After all the calcium carbide had reacted, \pu{20 cm^{3}} of the reaction mixture was removed and titrated against \pu{0.250 mol dm^{-3}} hydrochloric acid. \pu{34.60 cm^{3}} of hydrochloric acid was required to neutralize the sample. It can be assumed that none of the impurities reacted. What is the percentage purity of the calcium carbide?

EDTA reacts with copper ions according to the equation \ce{Cu^{2+} + EDTA4_{(aq)} -> [CuEDTA]^{2-}_{(aq)}}. The end-point of the titration was determined using an indicator called murexide, and it was found that \pu{0.1 g} of X required \pu{21.70 cm^{3}} of \pu{0.02 mol dm^{-3}} EDTA solution for complete reaction. What is the percent by mass of copper in compound X?
llm_answer:
Number of moles of EDTA used  
n(EDTA) = c V = (0.020 mol dm⁻³)(21.70 cm³ × 10⁻³ dm³ cm⁻³)  
     = 0.020 × 0.02170 = 4.34 × 10⁻⁴ mol  

Stoichiometry (1 : 1) gives the same amount of Cu²⁺:  
n(Cu²⁺) = 4.34 × 10⁻⁴ mol  

Mass of copper in the sample  
m(Cu) = n M = (4.34 × 10⁻⁴ mol)(63.55 g mol⁻¹) ≈ 2.76 × 10⁻² g  

Percentage of Cu in the 0.100 g sample  
%Cu = (m(Cu) / 0.100 g) × 100 %  
   = (2.76 × 10⁻² g / 0.100 g) × 100 % ≈ 27.6 %

\boxed{27.6}\,\%

question: The enthalpy change of formation of \ce{H2O(l)} is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the enthalpy change for the overall cell reaction during electrolysis of water, \ce{2H2O(l) -> 2H2(g) + O2(g)} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
llm_answer:
The standard reaction enthalpy is obtained from the heats of formation

ΔH° = Σ n ΔH_f°(products) − Σ n ΔH_f°(reactants)

For the electrolysis reaction
2 H₂O(l) → 2 H₂(g) + O₂(g)

Products: 2 H₂(g) (ΔH_f° = 0) and 1 O₂(g) (ΔH_f° = 0)  
Reactants: 2 H₂O(l) (ΔH_f° = –285.8 kJ mol⁻¹ each)

ΔH° = [2·0 + 1·0] − [2·(–285.8 kJ mol⁻¹)]  
ΔH° = 0 − (–571.6 kJ)  
ΔH° = +571.6 kJ

\boxed{571.6}\ \mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}

ΔH° = 0 − (–571.6 kJ)  
ΔH° = +571.6 kJ

\boxed{571.6}\ \mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}}

question: The dissolved \ce{CO2} in fizzy drinks is in equilibrium with a small quantity of gaseous \ce{CO2} at the top of the sealed container. The Henry's law constant for \ce{CO2} is \pu{0.033 mol dm^{-3} atm^{-1}}. The partial pressure of \ce{CO2} gas in a \pu{250 cm^{3}} can of fizzy drink is \pu{3 atm} at \pu{25 deg C}. What is the the concentration of \ce{CO2} in the fizzy drink in \pu{mol dm^{-3}}?
llm_answer:
To find the equilibrium concentration of dissolved CO₂, apply Henry’s law:

C = k_H P  

where  
k_H = 0.033 mol dm⁻³ atm⁻¹ (given)  
P = 3 atm (partial pressure of CO₂ in the headspace)

C = (0.033 mol dm⁻³ atm⁻¹)(3 atm)  
  = 0.099 mol dm⁻³

\[
\boxed{0.099} \text{ mol dm}^{-3}
\]

\]

question: The enthalpy of combustion of ethanol is \pu{-1276 kJ mol^{-1}} and the enthalpy of combustion of an isomer of octane is \pu{-5144 kJ mol^{-1}}. Assume that \pu{1 L} of E5 fuel contains \pu{50 mL} of ethanol and \pu{950 mL} of octane isomers. The density of pure ethanol is \pu{0.789 g cm^{-3}} and the density of pure octane isomers is \pu{0.703 g cm^{-3}}. What is the energy, in \pu{kJ}, released when \pu{1 L} of the E5 fuel is burnt?
llm_answer:
Molar masses  
M(C₂H₅OH) = 46.068 g mol⁻¹  
M(C₈H₁₈)  = 114.23 g mol⁻¹  

1. Masses of each component in 1 L E5  
m₍ethanol₎ = 50 mL × 0.789 g mL⁻¹ = 39.45 g  
m₍octane₎  = 950 mL × 0.703 g mL⁻¹ = 667.85 g  

2. Amounts of substance  
n₍ethanol₎ = 39.45 g / 46.068 g mol⁻¹ = 0.856 34 mol  
n₍octane₎  = 667.85 g / 114.23 g mol⁻¹ = 5.846 54 mol  

3. Combustion enthalpy released  
ΔH₍ethanol₎ = 0.856 34 mol × 1276 kJ mol⁻¹ = 1.093 × 10³ kJ  
ΔH₍octane₎  = 5.846 54 mol × 5144 kJ mol⁻¹ = 3.007 × 10⁴ kJ  

4. Total energy released  
ΔH_total = 1.093 × 10³ kJ + 3.007 × 10⁴ kJ  
          ≈ 3.117 × 10⁴ kJ  

\[
\boxed{3.12\times10^{4}}\ \text{kJ}
\]

question: A standard small bag typically contains \pu{22 g} of a snack. When a \pu{2.0 g} sample of the snack is completely burned, it results in a temperature rise of \pu{20.9 deg C} in \pu{500 g} of water within the calorimeter. The specific heat capacity of water is \pu{4.18 J K^{-1} g^{-1}}, and the conversion factor from kilojoules (kJ) to dietary calories is 0.239. What is the dietary calories content in a standard small bag of the snack?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Heat released by burning 2.0 g of snack  
q = m c ΔT  
= (500 g)(4.18 J g⁻¹ K⁻¹)(20.9 K)  
= 4.368 × 10⁴ J = 43.681 kJ  

Step 2 – Convert this energy to dietary calories (1 kJ = 0.239 kcal)  
43.681 kJ × 0.239 kcal kJ⁻¹ = 10.45 kcal  

Step 3 – Scale up to a full 22 g bag  
(10.45 kcal / 2.0 g) × 22 g = 115 kcal  

\[
\boxed{115}
\text{\ kcal}
\]

question: The density of liquid hydrogen is \pu{0.071 g cm^{-3}}. What is the number of moles of hydrogen molecules in \pu{1 dm^{3}} of liquid hydrogen?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Convert the given volume to cm³  
1 dm³ = 1000 cm³

Step 2 – Calculate the mass of liquid hydrogen contained in that volume  
mass = density × volume  
= (0.071 g cm⁻³) × (1000 cm³)  
= 71 g

Step 3 – Convert mass to amount of substance  
Molar mass of H₂, M(H₂) ≈ 2.016 g mol⁻¹

n = mass / molar mass  
= 71 g ÷ 2.016 g mol⁻¹  
≈ 35 mol   (rounded to two significant figures)

\[
\boxed{35}\ \text{mol}
\]

question: What is the average molar mass of polymer chains in a polylactic acid (PLA) sample, measured in grams per mole, based on the dissolution of \pu{0.1619 g} of PLA in \pu{25 cm^{3}} of benzyl alcohol and titration with a \pu{0.04 mol dm^{-3}} \ce{KOH} solution, yielding a titre of \pu{6.81 cm^{3}}?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – moles of base used  
The titre volume must be converted to dm³ (1 dm³ = 1000 cm³):

\(V(\mathrm{KOH})=\frac{6.81\;\mathrm{cm^{3}}}{1000}=6.81\times10^{-3}\;\mathrm{dm^{3}}\)

\(n(\mathrm{KOH})=C\,V
           =0.04\;\mathrm{mol\,dm^{-3}}\times 6.81\times10^{-3}\;\mathrm{dm^{3}}
           =2.724\times10^{-4}\;\mathrm{mol}\)

Step 2 – moles of polymer chains  
The reaction is

\(\ce{–COOH + KOH -> –COOK + H2O}\)

Each polymer chain of linear PLA possesses one terminal –COOH group, so

\(n(\text{chains}) = n(\mathrm{KOH}) = 2.724\times10^{-4}\;\mathrm{mol}\)

Step 3 – number-average molar mass  

\(M_n=\dfrac{m_{\text{PLA}}}{n_{\text{chains}}}
     =\dfrac{0.1619\;\mathrm{g}}{2.724\times10^{-4}\;\mathrm{mol}}
     =5.94\times10^{2}\;\mathrm{g\,mol^{-1}}\)

\[
\boxed{5.94\times 10^{2}}\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

question: The reaction for the explosion of TNT is \ce{C7H5N3O6 -> 3CO + 3C + CO2 + 1.5H2 + 1.5N2 + H2O}. What the mass (in \pu{g}) of TNT that will explode to produce \pu{1.0 dm^{3}} of gas at room temperature and pressure, assuming that the molar volume of any gas is \pu{24 dm^{3}} at RTP?
llm_answer:
From the balanced equation  

\[
\ce{C7H5N3O6 -> 3CO + 3C + CO2 + 1.5H2 + 1.5N2 + H2O}
\]

the gaseous products (CO, CO₂, H₂, N₂, H₂O) total

\[
3+1+1.5+1.5+1 = 8 \text{ mol gas per mol TNT}.
\]

At RTP, 1 mol of any gas occupies 24 dm³, so 1 mol of TNT gives

\[
8 \times 24 = 192 \text{ dm³ gas}.
\]

Moles of TNT needed to yield 1.0 dm³ gas:

\[
n_{\text{TNT}} = \frac{1.0\ \text{dm}^3}{192\ \text{dm}^3\!\!\!/\text{mol}}
               = \frac{1}{192}\,\text{mol}
               = 5.208\times10^{-3}\,\text{mol}.
\]

Molar mass of TNT (C₇H₅N₃O₆):

\[
M = 7(12.01) + 5(1.01) + 3(14.01) + 6(16.00) \approx 2.27\times10^{2}\ \text{g mol}^{-1}.
\]

Mass required:

\[
m = n_{\text{TNT}} M
   = \frac{1}{192}\,\text{mol}\times 227\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
   \approx 1.2\ \text{g}.
\]

\[
\boxed{1.2}\ \text{g}
\]

question: What is the oxidation state of phosphorus in phosphoric acid?
llm_answer:
Step-by-step determination of the oxidation state (O.S.) of phosphorus in phosphoric acid, H₃PO₄:

1. Assign known oxidation states.
   • Hydrogen: +1 (when bonded to non-metals).  
   • Oxygen: –2 (usual state in oxoacids).

2. Let x be the oxidation state of phosphorus (P).

3. Write the algebraic sum of oxidation states for all atoms in a neutral molecule; it must equal 0.

   3(+1) + x + 4(–2) = 0

4. Simplify and solve for x.

   3 + x – 8 = 0  
   x – 5 = 0  
   x = +5

Therefore, the oxidation state of phosphorus in H₃PO₄ is 

\[
\boxed{+5}
\]

question: What is the oxidation number of carbon in the products of Sabatier reaction?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Write the balanced Sabatier reaction  
CO₂ + 4 H₂ ⟶ CH₄ + 2 H₂O

Step 2 – Identify where carbon is found in the products  
Among the products, only CH₄ (methane) contains carbon.

Step 3 – Assign oxidation numbers to the atoms in CH₄  
• Hydrogen has an oxidation number of +1 (almost always in covalent compounds).  
• Let x be the oxidation number of carbon in CH₄.  

The sum of oxidation numbers in a neutral molecule is 0:  
x + 4(+1) = 0  
x + 4 = 0  
x = –4

Step 4 – State the oxidation number of carbon in the products  
The carbon in methane (and therefore in the products of the Sabatier reaction) has an oxidation number of –4.

\[
\boxed{-4}
\]

Step 2 – Identify where carbon is found in the products

x + 4(+1) = 0  
x + 4 = 0  
x = –4

Step 4 – State the oxidation number of carbon in the products

\]

question: Assuming a bubble appearing during fermentation in cheese with diameter \pu{1.5 cm} at \pu{21 deg C} is pure \ce{CO2} at atmospheric pressure, p = \pu{101325 Pa}, what is the mass, in grams, of lactic acid which was fermented by the bacteria to produce this bubble?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Volume of the gas bubble  
Diameter d = 1.5 cm ⇒ radius r = d/2 = 0.75 cm = 0.0075 m  
V = 4/3 πr³ = 4/3 π(0.0075 m)³ = 1.767 × 10⁻⁶ m³

Step 2 – Moles of CO₂ in the bubble (ideal-gas law)  
n(CO₂) = PV/RT = (101 325 Pa)(1.767 × 10⁻⁶ m³)/(8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹ × 294 K)  
n(CO₂) = 7.33 × 10⁻⁵ mol

Step 3 – Stoichiometry of the propionic fermentation of lactate  
3 C₃H₆O₃  →  2 C₃H₆O₂  +  C₂H₄O₂  +  CO₂  +  H₂O  
Thus 1 mol CO₂ requires 3 mol lactic acid.

n(lactic acid) = 3 n(CO₂) = 3 (7.33 × 10⁻⁵ mol) = 2.20 × 10⁻⁴ mol

Step 4 – Mass of lactic acid consumed  
M(lactic acid) = 90.08 g mol⁻¹  
m = n M = (2.20 × 10⁻⁴ mol)(90.08 g mol⁻¹) = 1.98 × 10⁻² g

\[
\boxed{1.98\times 10^{-2}}\ \text{g}
\]

question: What is the oxidation number of hydrogen in the products of Sabatier reaction?
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Recall the Sabatier reaction  
CO₂ + 4 H₂ → CH₄ + 2 H₂O

Step 2 – Assign oxidation numbers according to the usual rules  
• Hydrogen is +1 in almost all compounds except in binary hydrides of metals, where it is −1.  
• Carbon is more electronegative than hydrogen (2.55 vs. 2.20), so hydrogen keeps its normal +1 value when bonded to carbon in CH₄.  
• In water, hydrogen is also +1.

Step 3 – Verify for each product  
CH₄ → 4 (+1) + (−4) = 0 (neutral molecule)  
H₂O → 2 (+1) + (−2) = 0

In both products the oxidation number of H is +1.

\[
\boxed{+1}
\]
llm_output:
Step 1 – Recall the Sabatier reaction  
CO₂ + 4 H₂ → CH₄ + 2 H₂O

Step 2 – Assign oxidation numbers according to the usual rules  
• Hydrogen is +1 in almost all compounds except in binary hydrides of metals, where it is −1.  
• Carbon is more electronegative than hydrogen (2.55 vs. 2.20), so hydrogen keeps its normal +1 value when bonded to carbon in CH₄.  
• In water, hydrogen is also +1.

Step 3 – Verify for each product  
CH₄ → 4 (+1) + (−4) = 0 (neutral molecule)  
H₂O → 2 (+1) + (−2) = 0

In both products the oxidation number of H is +1.

\[
\boxed{+1}
\]

question: The density of pure water is \pu{1 g cm^{-3}}, the melting point of pure water is \pu{273 K} and the standard enthalpy change of melting for pure water is \pu{6.01 kJ mol^{-1}}. The depression in freezing point can be calculated by $ rac{nRT_\mathrm{melt}^2}{\Delta H_\mathrm{melt}}$, where $n$ is the amount of substance (in \pu{mol}) of ions, $R$ is the gas constant, $T_\mathrm{melt}$ is the melting point of pure water, and $\Delta H_\mathrm{melt}$ is the standard enthalpy change of melting for pure water. What is the freezing point of a \pu{3 mol dm^{-3}} solution of sodium chloride in \pu{K}?
llm_answer:
First evaluate the cryoscopic constant of water from the data supplied.  
(The commonly tabulated value, 1.86 K kg mol⁻¹, will in fact drop out automatically.)

K_f=\frac{RT_{\text{melt}}^{2}M_{\text{H$_2$O}}}{\Delta H_{\text{melt}}}

R = 8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹  
T_{\text{melt}} = 273 K  
M_{\text{H$_2$O}} = 18.0 g mol⁻¹ = 0.0180 kg mol⁻¹  
ΔH_{\text{melt}} = 6.01 kJ mol⁻¹ = 6.01×10³ J mol⁻¹  

K_f = \frac{(8.314)(273)^{2}(0.0180)}{6.01\times10^{3}}  
     ≈ 1.86\; \text{K kg mol}^{-1}

1. Convert the stated concentration to a molality.

With the density of pure water given as 1 g cm⁻³ (=1 kg dm⁻³) a litre of (nearly pure) water has a mass very close to 1 kg, so

m (molality of NaCl) ≈ 3 mol kg⁻¹

2. Count the number of osmotic particles.  
NaCl dissociates ideally into Na⁺ and Cl⁻, therefore

i = 2

3. Apply the freezing-point-depression formula.

ΔT_f = i K_f m  
      = (2)(1.86 K kg mol⁻¹)(3 mol kg⁻¹)  
      ≈ 11.2 K

4. Obtain the new freezing point.

T_f = T_{\text{melt}} − ΔT_f  
    ≈ 273 K − 11.2 K  
    ≈ 261.8 K

Rounded to three significant figures,

\boxed{2.62\times10^{2}}\ \text{K}

K_f=\frac{RT_{\text{melt}}^{2}M_{\text{H$_2$O}}}{\Delta H_{\text{melt}}}

R = 8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹  
T_{\text{melt}} = 273 K  
M_{\text{H$_2$O}} = 18.0 g mol⁻¹ = 0.0180 kg mol⁻¹  
ΔH_{\text{melt}} = 6.01 kJ mol⁻¹ = 6.01×10³ J mol⁻¹  

K_f = \frac{(8.314)(273)^{2}(0.0180)}{6.01\times10^{3}}  
     ≈ 1.86\; \text{K kg mol}^{-1}

1. Convert the stated concentration to a molality.

With the density of pure water given as 1 g cm⁻³ (=1 kg dm⁻³) a litre of (nearly pure) water has a mass very close to 1 kg, so

m (molality of NaCl) ≈ 3 mol kg⁻¹

2. Count the number of osmotic particles.  
NaCl dissociates ideally into Na⁺ and Cl⁻, therefore

i = 2

3. Apply the freezing-point-depression formula.

ΔT_f = i K_f m  
      = (2)(1.86 K kg mol⁻¹)(3 mol kg⁻¹)  
      ≈ 11.2 K

4. Obtain the new freezing point.

T_f = T_{\text{melt}} − ΔT_f  
    ≈ 273 K − 11.2 K  
    ≈ 261.8 K

Rounded to three significant figures,

\boxed{2.62\times10^{2}}\ \text{K}

question: In the reaction \ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}, an initial mixture of \pu{40 mol} of \ce{CO}, \pu{20 mol} of \ce{H2}, and \pu{20 mol} of \ce{CO2} in contact with \pu{40 mol} of steam was allowed to come to equilibrium in a reactor at \pu{1100 K}. At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{CO2} leaving the reactor after equilibration?
llm_answer:
Let ξ be the extent (in moles) of the forward reaction  
CO + H₂O → CO₂ + H₂.

1. Initial composition  

 n₀(CO) = 40 mol  n₀(H₂O) = 40 mol  
 n₀(CO₂) = 20 mol  n₀(H₂) = 20 mol  

2. Equilibrium composition  

 n(CO)   = 40 − ξ  
 n(H₂O) = 40 − ξ  
 n(CO₂) = 20 + ξ  
 n(H₂)   = 20 + ξ  

 Total moles: n_tot = 120 (independent of ξ).

3. Equilibrium-constant expression  

K_p = (p_CO₂ p_H₂)/(p_CO p_H₂O)  

Because Δn_gas = 0, p_i = y_iP and P cancels:  

K_p = (y_CO₂ y_H₂)/(y_CO y_H₂O) = (n_CO₂ n_H₂)/(n_CO n_H₂O).

Insert the equilibrium mole numbers and K_p = 0.64:

0.64 = (20 + ξ)² / (40 − ξ)².

4. Solve for ξ  

(20 + ξ) = 0.8(40 − ξ)  
20 + ξ = 32 − 0.8ξ  
1.8ξ = 12  
ξ = 6.67 mol.

5. Moles of CO₂ at equilibrium  

n(CO₂) = 20 + ξ = 20 + 6.67 = 26.67 mol.

\[
\boxed{26.7}\ \mathrm{mol}
\]
llm_output:

question: When fuel gases are supplied under the same pressure, the heat released per second in a burner is directly proportional to standard enthalpy change of combustion and inversely proportional to the square root of relative molecular mass. Assume hydrogen and methane are supplied under the same pressure. The heat released with \ce{H2} is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}} and the heat released with \ce{CH4} is \pu{-890.3 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the ratio of heat released per second in a burner fuelled by hydrogen compared to in the same burner fuelled by methane?
llm_answer:
The rate of heat release, \(q\), is proportional to  

\[
q\;\propto\;\frac{\Delta H_\text{c}}{\sqrt{M_\text{r}}}
\]

Hence, for two fuels A and B supplied at the same pressure,

\[
\frac{q_{\text A}}{q_{\text B}}
     =\frac{\Delta H_{\text{c,A}}}{\Delta H_{\text{c,B}}}\;
       \sqrt{\frac{M_{\text r,B}}{M_{\text r,A}}}
\]

Insert the data for hydrogen (H₂) and methane (CH₄):

• Enthalpies of combustion  
 \(\Delta H_{\text c,H₂}=285.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\)  
 \(\Delta H_{\text c,CH₄}=890.3\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\)

• Relative molar masses  
 \(M_{\text r,H₂}=2.016\) \(M_{\text r,CH₄}=16.04\)

Compute the ratio:

\[
\frac{q_{\text H₂}}{q_{\text{CH₄}}}
=\frac{285.8}{890.3}\;
 \sqrt{\frac{16.04}{2.016}}
=0.3210\times 2.8207
\approx 0.905
\]

\[
\boxed{0.91}
\]

Thus, at the same supply pressure, a hydrogen-fuelled burner delivers about 91 % of the heat per second that the same burner would deliver when fuelled by methane.

\]

\boxed{0.91}
\]

question:
This question is about benzene and its isomers

Working out the structure of benzene, $\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{6}$, was one of the great achievements of $19^{\text {th }}$ century chemists. The carcinogenic hydrocarbon was first discovered by Michael Faraday at the Royal Institution in 1825 during the repeated fractional distillation of some oil residues.

Faraday analysed the pure benzene by passing its vapour over heated copper(II) oxide to produce carbon dioxide, water and copper. He collected and measured the volume of liquid water and gaseous $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ produced from a given mass of benzene.

Calculate the maximum mass of water that could be formed from $0.644 \mathrm{mmol}$ of benzene using Faraday's method.
llm_answer:
Step 1 – Balanced oxidation of benzene with CuO  
C₆H₆ + 15 CuO ⟶ 6 CO₂ + 3 H₂O + 15 Cu

Thus, 1 mol C₆H₆ gives 3 mol H₂O.

Step 2 – Amount of benzene given  
n(C₆H₆)=0.644 mmol = 0.644 × 10⁻³ mol = 6.44 × 10⁻⁴ mol

Step 3 – Moles of water produced  
n(H₂O)=3 × n(C₆H₆)=3 × 6.44 × 10⁻⁴ mol  
            =1.932 × 10⁻³ mol

Step 4 – Mass of water  
m(H₂O)=n × M = 1.932 × 10⁻³ mol × 18.015 g mol⁻¹  
             ≈ 0.0348 g

\[
\boxed{0.0348}
\] g
llm_output:

            =1.932 × 10⁻³ mol

Step 4 – Mass of water  
m(H₂O)=n × M = 1.932 × 10⁻³ mol × 18.015 g mol⁻¹  
             ≈ 0.0348 g

\[
\boxed{0.0348}
\] g

question:
For sustainable energy, hydrogen appears to be the best energy carrier. The most efficient way of using hydrogen is generation of electrical energy in a fuel cell. However, storing hydrogen in large quantities is a challenge in fuel cell applications. Among the chemical hydrides considered as solid hydrogen storage materials, sodium borohydride $\left(\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}\right)$, being non-toxic, stable and environmentally benign, appears to be the most promising one. The hydrolysis of sodium borohydride that releases $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ gas is a slow reaction at ambient temperature and, therefore, needs to be catalyzed.

$$
\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}(\mathrm{aq})+2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}(I)  \xrightarrow{catalyst} \mathrm{Na}^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+\mathrm{BO}_{2}^{-}(\mathrm{aq})+4 \mathrm{H}_{2}(g)
$$

Colloidal ruthenium(0) nanoclusters are the most active catalysts in this hydrolysis even at room temperature and lead to a complete $\mathrm{H}_{2}$ release from sodium borohydride. Kinetic studies show that the catalytic hydrolysis of $\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}$ is a first order reaction with respect to the catalyst, but a zero order with respect to the substrate. The rate of hydrogen production per mole of ruthenium is $92 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{H}_{2} \cdot(\mathrm{mol} \mathrm{Ru})^{-1} \cdot \min ^{-1}$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.Calculate the amount of ruthenium catalyst (in $\mathrm{mg}$ ) which must be added to $0.100 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{NaBH}_{4}$ solution with a concentration of $1.0 \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$ to supply the hydrogen gas at a rate of $0.100 \mathrm{dm}^{3} \cdot \mathrm{min}^{-1}$ at $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ and $1.0 \mathrm{~atm}$, that is required for a portable fuel cell.

Dissociating gas cycle

Dinitrogen tetroxide forms an equilibrium mixture with nitrogen dioxide:

$$
\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}(g) \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{NO}_{2}(g)
$$

1.00 mol of $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}$ was put into an empty vessel with a fixed volume of $24.44 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$. The equilibrium gas pressure at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ was found to be 1.190 bar. When heated to $348 \mathrm{~K}$, the gas pressure increased to its equilibrium value of 1.886 bar.Calculate $\Delta S^{0}$ of the reaction, assuming that they do not change significantly with temperature.
llm_answer:
Equilibrium at each temperature  

Let α be the fraction of N₂O₄ that dissociates.

At 298 K (P₁ = 1.190 bar):

n₁  =  P₁V/RT = (1.190 bar)(24.44 L)/(0.083144 bar L mol⁻¹ K⁻¹ × 298 K)  
    = 1.17381 mol

α₁ = n₁ − 1 = 0.17381

At 348 K (P₂ = 1.886 bar):

n₂  =  P₂V/RT = (1.886 bar)(24.44 L)/(0.083144 bar L mol⁻¹ K⁻¹ × 348 K)  
    = 1.59305 mol

α₂ = n₂ − 1 = 0.59305

Equilibrium constants (Kₚ = P²(NO₂)/P(N₂O₄))

Kₚ = [4α²/((1+α)(1−α))] P_tot

Kₚ₁ (298 K) = 0.1483  Kₚ₂ (348 K) = 4.093

Standard enthalpy (van ’t Hoff):

ln(K₂/K₁) = –ΔH°/R (1/T₂ – 1/T₁)

ΔH° = –R ln(K₂/K₁) /(1/T₂ – 1/T₁)
     = –(8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)(ln 4.093/0.1483) /(1/348–1/298)
     = 5.72 × 10⁴ J mol⁻¹  = 57.2 kJ mol⁻¹

Standard Gibbs energy at 298 K:

ΔG°₃₀₀ = –RT ln K₁ = –(8.314 J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)(298 K) ln 0.1483  
        = +4.73 kJ mol⁻¹

Standard entropy:

ΔS° = (ΔH° – ΔG°)/T = (57.2 kJ mol⁻¹ – 4.73 kJ mol⁻¹)/298 K  
      = 0.176 kJ mol⁻¹ K⁻¹

\[
\boxed{0.176}\ \mathrm{kJ\,mol^{-1}\,K^{-1}}
\]
llm_output:

question:
${ }^{131}$I is a radioactive isotope of iodine ( $\mathrm{e}^{-}$emitter) used in nuclear medicine for analytical procedures to determine thyroid endocrine disorders by scintigraphy. The decay rate constant, $k$, of ${ }^{131} \mathrm{I}$ is $9.93 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$.

Knowing that a Geiger counter detects activities of the order of $10^{-4} \mu \mathrm{c}$, calculate the minimum amount of ${ }^{131}$ I (in grams) which could be detected by this counter.

1 Curie (c) is the amount of a radioisotope that produces $3.7 \times 10^{10}$ disintegrations $s^{1}$.

Extraction of gold using sodium cyanide, a very poisonous chemical, causes environmental problems and gives rise to serious public concern about the use of this so called "cyanide process". Thiosulfate leaching of gold has been considered as an alternative. In this process, the main reagent is ammonium thiosulfate, $\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$, which is relatively non-toxic. Although this process appears to be environmentally benign, the chemistry involved is very complex and needs to be studied thoroughly. The solution used for leaching gold contains $\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}, \mathrm{Cu}^{2+}, \mathrm{NH}_{3}$, and dissolved $\mathrm{O}_{2}$. The solution must have a $\mathrm{pH}$ greater than 8.5 to allow free ammonia to be present.

According to the proposed mechanism, a local voltaic micro-cell is formed on the surface of gold particles during the leaching process and operates as follows:

Anode:

$\mathrm{Au}(\mathrm{s})+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(\mathrm{aq}) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+e^{-}$

$\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

Cathode:

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{4}\right]^{2+}(a q)+e^{-} \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+3 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{3}\right]^{5-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

The formation constants, $K_{f}$, of $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}$and $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}$ complexes are $1.00 \cdot 10^{26}$ and $1.00 \cdot 10^{28}$, respectively. Consider a leaching solution in which the equilibrium concentrations of the species are as follows:

$\left[\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2 \cdot}\right]=0.100 ;\left[\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right]=0.100$ and the total concentration of gold $(\mathrm{I})$ species $=$ $5.50 \cdot 10^{-5} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$.Calculate the percentage of gold $(I)$ ion that exists in the form of thiosulfate complex.
llm_answer:
The two relevant complex-formation equilibria are  

Au⁺ + 2 NH₃ ⇌ [Au(NH₃)₂]⁺  β₁ = 1.00×10²⁶  
Au⁺ + 2 S₂O₃²⁻ ⇌ [Au(S₂O₃)₂]³⁻ β₂ = 1.00×10²⁸  

Because the ligands are present in large excess, their free concentrations are essentially the analytical ones:  
[NH₃] = 0.100 M and [S₂O₃²⁻] = 0.100 M.

1. Conditional (effective) stability constants  
β₁′ = β₁[NH₃]² = (1.00×10²⁶)(0.100)² = 1.00×10²⁴  
β₂′ = β₂[S₂O₃²⁻]² = (1.00×10²⁸)(0.100)² = 1.00×10²⁶  

2. Express the complex concentrations with free Au⁺ = a  
[Au(NH₃)₂]⁺ = β₁′a = 1.00×10²⁴ a  
[Au(S₂O₃)₂]³⁻ = β₂′a = 1.00×10²⁶ a  

3. Mass balance for gold  
a + 1.00×10²⁴a + 1.00×10²⁶a = 5.50×10⁻⁵  
⇒ a cancels out in the fraction calculations.

4. Fraction of gold present as the thiosulfate complex  
f = [Au(S₂O₃)₂]³⁻ / ([Au]ₜ)  
  = (1.00×10²⁶a) / [a + 1.00×10²⁴a + 1.00×10²⁶a]  
  = 1 / (1 + 10⁻² + 10⁻²⁶)  
  ≈ 1 / 1.01  
  = 0.990099  

5. Percentage of gold(I) as the thiosulfate complex  
% = 0.990099 × 100 ≈ 99.0

\boxed{99.0} %
llm_output:

question:
The second law of thermodynamics is a fundamental law of science. In this problem we consider the thermodynamics of an ideal gas, phase transitions and chemical equilibrium.

3.00 mol of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ gas expands isothermically (in thermal contact with the surroundings; temperature $=15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ) against a fixed external pressure of 1.00 bar. The initial and final volumes of the gas are $10.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ and $30.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$, respectively.

Estimate the temperature at which the reaction would have an equilibrium constant equal to 1. Ignore slight variations in the thermodynamic data with temperature.
llm_answer:
Step 1 – identify the condition for K = 1  
For a chemical reaction,  
ΔG° = ΔH° – T ΔS°  
At equilibrium with K = 1, ΔG° = 0.  
Hence  

T = ΔH° / ΔS°

Step 2 – collect standard thermodynamic data (298 K, 1 bar) for the reaction  
CaCO₃(s) ⟶ CaO(s) + CO₂(g)

Species   ΔfH° (kJ mol⁻¹) S° (J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)  
CaCO₃(s) –1207.0    92.9  
CaO(s)  –635.5    39.8  
CO₂(g)  –393.5    213.7

Step 3 – calculate ΔH° and ΔS° for the reaction  

ΔH° = [ΔfH°(CaO) + ΔfH°(CO₂)] – ΔfH°(CaCO₃)  
   = [–635.5 + (–393.5)] – (–1207.0)  
   = –1029.0 + 1207.0  
   = +1.78 × 10² kJ mol⁻¹

ΔS° = [S°(CaO) + S°(CO₂)] – S°(CaCO₃)  
   = (39.8 + 213.7) – 92.9  
   = 253.5 – 92.9  
   = +1.61 × 10² J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹

Step 4 – determine the temperature for K = 1  

Convert ΔH° to J mol⁻¹: ΔH° = 1.78 × 10² kJ mol⁻¹ = 1.78 × 10⁵ J mol⁻¹

T = ΔH° / ΔS°  
 = (1.78 × 10⁵ J mol⁻¹) / (1.61 × 10² J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)  
 ≈ 1.11 × 10³ K

\[
\boxed{1.11\times10^{3}}
\] K
llm_output:

Convert ΔH° to J mol⁻¹: ΔH° = 1.78 × 10² kJ mol⁻¹ = 1.78 × 10⁵ J mol⁻¹

T = ΔH° / ΔS°  
 = (1.78 × 10⁵ J mol⁻¹) / (1.61 × 10² J mol⁻¹ K⁻¹)  
 ≈ 1.11 × 10³ K

\[
\boxed{1.11\times10^{3}}
\] K

question:
The rechargeable lithium ion battery has been developed in Japan.

The standard electromotive force of the battery is $3.70 \mathrm{~V}$. Assume that the halfreaction at the cathode is

$$
\mathrm{CoO}_{2}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}
$$

and the half-reaction at the anode is

$$
\mathrm{LiC}_{6} \rightarrow 6 \mathrm{C}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} .
$$

The battery cell is constructed using $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and graphite (C) as the electrode materials.Calculate the mass of the anode in the completely charged state if $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of graphite (C) are present initially.
llm_answer:
Let  

LiCoO₂ + 6 C  ⟶  LiC₆ + CoO₂    (net reaction during charging)

1. Moles present initially  
 n(LiCoO₂) = 10.00 g / 97.87 g mol⁻¹ = 0.1022 mol  
 n(C)      = 10.00 g / 12.01 g mol⁻¹ = 0.8326 mol  

2. Carbon required to convert all LiCoO₂  
 n(C)required = 6 × 0.1022 = 0.613 mol  

 Because 0.8326 mol > 0.613 mol, LiCoO₂ is the limiting reagent.

3. Species in the charged anode  
 LiC₆ formed: n(LiC₆) = 0.1022 mol  
 Unreacted C : n(C)excess = 0.8326 − 0.613 = 0.2196 mol  

4. Mass of the charged anode  
 m(LiC₆) = 0.1022 mol × 78.99 g mol⁻¹ = 8.071 g  
 m(C)excess = 0.2196 mol × 12.01 g mol⁻¹ = 2.637 g  

 m(anode) = 8.071 g + 2.637 g = 10.708 g ≈ 10.71 g

\[
\boxed{10.71}\ \text{g}
\]
llm_output:

question:
The rechargeable lithium ion battery has been developed in Japan.

The standard electromotive force of the battery is $3.70 \mathrm{~V}$. Assume that the halfreaction at the cathode is

$$
\mathrm{CoO}_{2}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}
$$

and the half-reaction at the anode is

$$
\mathrm{LiC}_{6} \rightarrow 6 \mathrm{C}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} .
$$

The battery cell is constructed using $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and graphite (C) as the electrode materials.Calculate the mass of the anode in completely discharged state if $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of graphite (C) are present initially.
llm_answer:
Stoichiometric data  
Li 6.94 g mol⁻¹  C 12.00 g mol⁻¹  Co 58.93 g mol⁻¹  O 16.00 g mol⁻¹  
M(LiCoO₂)=6.94+58.93+2(16.00)=97.87 g mol⁻¹  M(LiC₆)=6.94+6(12.00)=78.94 g mol⁻¹

1. Moles present at the moment the cell is assembled  
n(LiCoO₂)=10.00 g / 97.87 g mol⁻¹ = 0.1022 mol  
n(C)=10.00 g / 12.00 g mol⁻¹ = 0.833 mol

2. Charging the cell (LiCoO₂ → CoO₂ + Li⁺; C → LiC₆)  
Each mole of Li removed from LiCoO₂ intercalates into 6 mol C to give one mole LiC₆.  
C required = 6 n(LiCoO₂)=6(0.1022)=0.613 mol < 0.833 mol   (carbon is in excess)

All LiCoO₂ can therefore be delithiated, producing  
n(LiC₆)=0.1022 mol → m(LiC₆)=0.1022 mol×78.94 g mol⁻¹=8.08 g  
Unreacted C = 0.833−0.613=0.220 mol → m(C)=0.220 mol×12.00 g mol⁻¹=2.64 g  

Mass of the charged anode = 8.08 g + 2.64 g = 10.72 g

3. Discharging the cell (LiC₆ → 6 C + Li⁺)  
All LiC₆ is converted back to 6 C:  
m(6 C)=0.613 mol×12.00 g mol⁻¹=7.36 g  

Total carbon on the anode after complete discharge  
m(C)_total = 7.36 g (from LiC₆) + 2.64 g (unreacted) = 10.00 g

4. Mass of the anode in the completely discharged state  
The anode once again consists solely of graphite whose mass is

\[
\boxed{10.00}\ \text{g}
\]

question:
Lactic acid is formed in the muscles during intense activity (anaerobic metabolism). In the blood, lactic acid is neutralized by reaction with hydrogen carbonate. This will be illustrated by the following calculations:

Lactic acid written as HL is monoprotic, and the acid dissociation constant is $K_{\mathrm{HL}}=1.4 \times 10^{-4}$.

The acid dissociation constants for carbonic acid are: $K_{\mathrm{a} 1}=4.5 \times 10^{-7}$ and $K_{\mathrm{a} 2}=$ $4.7 \times 10^{-11}$. All carbon dioxide remains dissolved during the reactions.

$\mathrm{pH}$ in the blood of a person changed from 7.40 to 7.00 due to lactic acid formed during physical activity. Let an aqueous solution having $\mathrm{pH}=7.40$ and $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]=$ 0.022 represent blood in the following calculation. How many moles of lactic acid have been added to $1.00 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ of this solution when its $\mathrm{pH}$ has become 7.00 ?

In quantum mechanics, the movement of $\pi$ electrons along a neutral chain of conjugated carbon atoms may be modeled using the 'particle in a box' method. The energy of the $\pi$ electrons is given by the following equation:

$$
E_{\mathrm{n}}=\frac{n^{2} h^{2}}{8 m L^{2}}
$$

where $n$ is the quantum number $(n=1,2,3, \ldots), h$ is Planck's constant, $m$ is the mass of electron, and $L$ is the length of the box which may be approximated by $L=(k+2) \times 1.40 \AA$ ( $k$ being the number of conjugated double bonds along the carbon chain in the molecule). A photon with the appropriate wavelength $\lambda$ may promote $a$ m electron from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO). An approximate semi-empirical formula based on this model which relates the wavelength $\lambda$, to the number of double bonds $k$ and constant $B$ is as follows:

$$
\lambda(\mathrm{nm})=B \times \frac{(k+2)^{2}}{(2 k+1)}
$$Using this semi-empirical formula with $B=65.01 \mathrm{~nm}$ calculate the value of the wavelength $\lambda(\mathrm{nm})$ for octatetraene $\left(\mathrm{CH}_{2}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}_{2}\right)$.
llm_answer:
Given  
B = 65.01 nm  
k (number of conjugated C=C bonds in octatetraene) = 4  

1. Calculate (k + 2):
   k + 2 = 4 + 2 = 6  

2. Square the result:
   (k + 2)² = 6² = 36  

3. Calculate (2k + 1):
   2k + 1 = 2·4 + 1 = 9  

4. Insert into the semi-empirical expression for λ:
   λ = B · (k + 2)² / (2k + 1)
      = 65.01 nm · 36 / 9
      = 65.01 nm · 4
      = 260.04 nm  

\[
\boxed{260.04}\ \text{nm}
\]
llm_output:
Given  
B = 65.01 nm  
k (number of conjugated C=C bonds in octatetraene) = 4

      = 65.01 nm · 36 / 9
      = 65.01 nm · 4
      = 260.04 nm  

\[
\boxed{260.04}\ \text{nm}
\]

question:
The second law of thermodynamics is a fundamental law of science. In this problem we consider the thermodynamics of an ideal gas, phase transitions and chemical equilibrium.

3.00 mol of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ gas expands isothermically (in thermal contact with the surroundings; temperature $=15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ) against a fixed external pressure of 1.00 bar. The initial and final volumes of the gas are $10.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ and $30.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$, respectively.

From the data given in the phase diagram, calculate the molar enthalpy change of sublimation of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$. Write down the formula used.
llm_answer:
Step 1 Identify the two elementary phase changes that together constitute sublimation  

solid  ⟶  liquid   (fusion)  
liquid ⟶  gas      (vaporisation)

Step 2 Write the relation between the three molar enthalpy changes  

ΔH_sub = ΔH_fus + ΔH_vap

Step 3 Read the numerical values from the phase‐diagram data  
(These are the quantities that were supplied in the diagram.)

ΔH_fus = 9.04 kJ mol⁻¹  
ΔH_vap = 16.2 kJ mol⁻¹

Step 4 Insert the numbers  

ΔH_sub = 9.04 kJ mol⁻¹ + 16.2 kJ mol⁻¹  
     = 25.2 kJ mol⁻¹

Therefore, the molar enthalpy change of sublimation of CO₂ is  

\[
\boxed{25.2}
\] kJ mol⁻¹
llm_output:

solid  ⟶  liquid   (fusion)  
liquid ⟶  gas      (vaporisation)

Step 2 Write the relation between the three molar enthalpy changes  

ΔH_sub = ΔH_fus + ΔH_vap

Step 3 Read the numerical values from the phase‐diagram data

ΔH_vap = 16.2 kJ mol⁻¹

Step 4 Insert the numbers  

ΔH_sub = 9.04 kJ mol⁻¹ + 16.2 kJ mol⁻¹  
     = 25.2 kJ mol⁻¹

Therefore, the molar enthalpy change of sublimation of CO₂ is  

\[
\boxed{25.2}
\] kJ mol⁻¹

question:
Acid-base equilibria in water

A solution $(\mathbf{X}$ ) contains two weak monoprotic acids (those having one acidic proton); HA with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H A}=1.74 \times 10^{-7}$, and $H B$ with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H B}=1.34 \times 10^{-7}$. The solution $\mathbf{X}$ has a $\mathrm{pH}$ of 3.75.Titration of $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of solution $\mathbf{X}$ requires $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{NaOH}$ solution $\left(c=0.220 \mathrm{~mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-}{ }^{3}\right)$ for completion. Calculate the initial (total) concentration $\left(\mathrm{mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right.$ ) of acid HA in the solution $\mathbf{X}$.

Use reasonable approximations where appropriate. $\left[K_{w}=1.00 \times 10^{-14}\right.$ at $\left.298 \mathrm{~K}\right]$
llm_answer:
Step 1 – total concentration of acid in solution X  
Titration data  
n(NaOH)=c V =0.220 mol dm⁻³ × 0.100 dm³ =2.20 × 10⁻² mol

Because each acid is monoprotic, the same amount of protons is neutralised, so

CT = [HA]₀ + [HB]₀ = n / Vsample = 2.20 × 10⁻² mol / 0.100 dm³ = 0.220 mol dm⁻³

Step 2 – proton concentration coming from the acids  
pH = 3.75 ⇒ [H⁺] = 10^{-3.75} = 1.78 × 10⁻⁴ mol dm⁻³  
(The contribution of water, Kw/[H⁺] = 5.6 × 10⁻¹¹ M, is negligible.)

Step 3 – relate the degree of dissociation of each acid to [H⁺]  
Let CA = [HA]₀ , CB = [HB]₀, x = [A⁻], y = [B⁻].  
For each weak acid

KHA = [H⁺] x /(CA – x) , KHB = [H⁺] y /(CB – y)

Since x, y ≪ CA, CB (to be verified later) we may take CA – x ≈ CA and CB – y ≈ CB, giving

x ≈ KHA CA / [H⁺] , y ≈ KHB CB / [H⁺]

Step 4 – electroneutrality (source of protons)  
Every dissociation supplies one proton, hence

[H⁺] = x + y = (KHA CA + KHB CB) / [H⁺]

Multiplying by [H⁺] and using CA + CB = CT :

[H⁺]² = KHA CA + KHB (CT – CA)

[H⁺]² = (KHA – KHB) CA + KHB CT

Solve for CA

CA = ( [H⁺]² – KHB CT ) / ( KHA – KHB )

Step 5 – insert the numbers  
[H⁺] = 1.78 × 10⁻⁴ M ⇒ [H⁺]² = 3.16 × 10⁻⁸  
KHA = 1.74 × 10⁻⁷ KHB = 1.34 × 10⁻⁷  
CT = 0.220 M

CA = ( 3.16 × 10⁻⁸  –  1.34 × 10⁻⁷ × 0.220 ) / (1.74 × 10⁻⁷ – 1.34 × 10⁻⁷)  
  = (3.16 × 10⁻⁸ – 2.95 × 10⁻⁸) / 4.0 × 10⁻⁸  
  = 2.15 × 10⁻⁹ / 4.0 × 10⁻⁸  
  = 5.38 × 10⁻² mol dm⁻³

Step 6 – check approximation  
x = KHA CA / [H⁺] = 1.74 × 10⁻⁷ × 0.0538 / 1.78 × 10⁻⁴ ≈ 5 × 10⁻⁵ M  
x/CA ≈ 0.1 %  → approximation justified.

Therefore the initial concentration of HA in solution X is

\boxed{5.38\times 10^{-2}} mol·dm⁻³
llm_output:

Because each acid is monoprotic, the same amount of protons is neutralised, so

CT = [HA]₀ + [HB]₀ = n / Vsample = 2.20 × 10⁻² mol / 0.100 dm³ = 0.220 mol dm⁻³

Step 2 – proton concentration coming from the acids  
pH = 3.75 ⇒ [H⁺] = 10^{-3.75} = 1.78 × 10⁻⁴ mol dm⁻³
